title: Relative representability and parahoric level structures

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We establish a representability criterion of $v$-sheaf theoretic modifications of formal schemes and apply this criterion to moduli spaces of parahoric level structures on local shtukas. In the proof, we introduce nice classes of equivariant profinite perfectoid covers and study geometric quotients of perfectoid formal schemes by profinite groups. As a corollary, we obtain a construction of (part of) integral models of local and global Shimura varieties under hyperspecial levels from those at hyperspecial levels.

## CONTENTS

1. Introduction 1
2. Preliminaries on adic spaces 4
3. The theory of $v$-sheaves and kimberlites 11
4. Perfectoid formal schemes 19
5. Dilatation theory of $v$-sheaves 31
6. Applications to local shtukas 48

References 63

## 1. InTRODUCTION

In [Art69] and [Art74], Artin established algebraicity criteria of functors and stacks over schemes and these criteria play a central role in moduli problems over schemes. However, recent development in arithmetic geometry shows that certain arithmetically important spaces admit moduli interpretation only in perfect schemes or perfectoid spaces (e.g. [Zhu17], [SW20]). In those cases, moduli problems are formulated as $v$-sheaves. Especially for the construction of integral models, it is important to know whether $v$-sheaf theoretic moduli problems are representable in formal schemes. In this paper, we will tackle this problem and establish a representability criterion in the style of [Art70].

In [Art70], Artin proved that every formal modification of the completion of a locally Noetherian algebraic space is uniquely algebraizable to its algebraic modification. Our first observation is that the conditions of formal modifications can be roughly translated to the $v$-sheaf theory using the language of [Gle24]. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. As

a $v$-sheaf theoretic modification of $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$, we consider a thick prekimberlite $Y$ formally adic over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ with $Y^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$ (see Proposition 2.18 for the relation with formal modifications). Here, we say that $Y$ is thick if the specialization map $\mathrm{sp}_{Y^{\text {an }}}$ is surjective. Since we do not have control over deperfections of $Y^{\text {red }}-\operatorname{Im}\left(\mathrm{sp}_{Y^{\text {an }}}\right)$, this assumption on $Y$ is essential.

We prove the representability of $Y$ by additionally assuming the existence of a nice equivariant profinite perfectoid cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ of $R$ and the representability of $Y$ over the perfectoid colimit $R_{\infty}$. In Section 5.1 and Section 5.2, we introduce the axioms of $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ and simply call $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ a (very) good cover of $R$. The construction of good covers is inspired by [BS22, Remark 3.11], but the notable difference is the existence of a profinite group action of $\Gamma_{\infty}$ on $R_{\infty}$. Identifying the complicated axioms of good covers is one essential part of the proof of our representability criterion. The main source of formal schemes admitting good covers is the completion of smooth schemes (see Remark 5.10). In Section 5.5, we discuss how wide the class of $p$-adic formal schemes admitting good covers is. The difficulty in obtaining examples other than $p$-adic smooth formal schemes lies in the condition (unifsec) in Section 5.2. This question is strongly related to how wide the class of sousperfectoid affinoids is (see [HK22]).

In Section 4, we extend the definition of $p$-adic perfectoid formal schemes introduced in [RC21] and study the basic properties of perfectoid formal schemes. The affine building block of perfectoid formal schemes is a perfectoid ring with a complete linear topology of a finitely generated ideal containing $p$. This notion is equivalent to perfectoid rings in the sense of Gabber-Romero (see [GR18, Definition 16.3.1]), but we call it a complete adic perfectoid ring to clarify the terminology. By construction, $R_{\infty}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring, and the representability of $Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is way easier to verify than that of $Y$.

Now, we state a form of our representability criterion.
Theorem 1. (Corollary 5.43) Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring admitting a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$. Let $Y$ be a thick prekimberlite formally adic over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ with $Y^{\mathrm{an}} \cong$ $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$. Suppose that $Y^{\text {red }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{\text {red }}$ and $Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is representable by a perfectoid formal scheme adic over $R_{\infty}$. Then, $Y$ is representable by a unique proper formal $R$-scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover with $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$.

The notion of maximal good covers is introduced in Section 5.4. The existence of maximal good covers ensures the uniqueness of $\mathfrak{Y}$ (see Lemma 5.33) and $\mathfrak{Y}$ is automatically reduced and distinguished (in the sense of [FK18]). The proof is essentially reduced to the affine case proved in Theorem 5.19. The construction of (affine open formal subschemes of) $\mathfrak{Y}$ is easy to describe as in Corollary 5.28, and the essential difficulties lie in verifying the desired properties of $\mathfrak{Y}$. In Proposition 2.11, we prove a finiteness criterion needed to prove the finiteness of $\mathfrak{Y}$. In Section 3.3, we study geometric quotients of $v$-sheaves by (pro)finite groups, and we use the theory to show that $\mathfrak{Y}$ represents $Y$.

Another form of our representability criterion is Proposition 5.44, which deals with the case where $R$ is $p$-adic and $Y^{\text {an }}$ is finite étale over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$. As an arithmetic application, we expect that this criterion enables us to study moduli spaces of level structures on local shtukas. In this paper, we only deal with parahoric level structures on local shtukas. In our forthcoming work, we will study depth-zero integral models of local Shimura varieties by studying depth-zero level structures using Proposition 5.44.

Let $F$ be a non-archimedean local field over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ and let $O_{F}$ be the ring of integers of $F$. Let $G$ be a connected reductive group over $F$ and let $\mathcal{G}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}$ be a morphism of parahoric group schemes of $G$ over $O_{F}$. Let $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}$ (resp. $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}}$ ) be the $v$-stack over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$ of local $\mathcal{G}$-shtukas (resp. local $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-shtukas). For a $v$-sheaf $X$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$, we say that a map $X \rightarrow \operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$ is a local shtuka over $X_{/ O_{F}}$. As an application of Proposition 5.44, we obtain the following representability of moduli spaces of parahoric level structures.

Theorem 2. (Theorem 6.13) Let $R$ be a reduced excellent $p$-adically complete $O_{F}$-algebra admitting a good cover and let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)_{/ O_{F}}$. The $v$-closure of the generic fiber in $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is representable by a unique proper $p$-adic formal $R$-scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover with $\mathfrak{Y}_{\eta}$ finite étale over $\operatorname{Spf}(R)_{\eta}$.

Thanks to the characterization by Scholze-Weinstein and Pappas-Rapoport, it has direct applications to integral models of local and global Shimura varieties. For local Shimura varieties, we can show the local representability of integral models of local Shimura varieties under hyperspecial levels (see Theorem 6.15) by using the result at hyperspecial levels (see [Bar22], [Ito22]). As a byproduct, we show the representability of $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagrams, modified from [PR24, Section 4.9.3], under hyperspecial levels, but this approach does not enable us to prove the basic properties of local model diagrams (see Proposition 6.19). For global Shimura varieties, we can construct integral models of Shimura varieties under hyperspecial levels as algebraic spaces from those at hyperspecial levels (see Theorem 6.20). We verify that they satisfy the axiom of canonicality in [PR24] and are equal to canonical integral models if they exist.
1.1. The structure of the paper. In Section 2, we explain the basic properties of (reduced excellent) adic spaces and prove a finiteness criterion needed in the proof of Theorem 5.19. In Section 3, we review the $v$-sheaf theory and study geometric quotients of $v$-sheaves. In Section 4, we introduce perfectoid formal schemes and show the basic properties. In Section 5, we introduce (very) good covers and establish our main representability criterion. In Section 6, we study moduli spaces of parahoric level structures on local shtukas as an application of our representability criterion.

Acknowledgements. I would like to thank my advisor Yoichi Mieda for his constant support and encouragement. I would also like to thank Kazuhiro Ito and Alex Youcis for

helpful discussions. This work was supported by the WINGS-FMSP program at the Graduate School of Mathematical Sciences, the University of Tokyo and JSPS KAKENHI Grant number JP24KJ0865.

Notation. Fix a prime number $p$. All rings are assumed to be commutative. The ring of invariants of a ring $R$ with respect to a $\Gamma$-action is denoted by $R^{\Gamma}$. The reduction of a ring $R$ is denoted by $R^{\text {red }}$. The perfection of a scheme $X$ is denoted by $X^{\text {perf }}$. For a scheme $X$ over a ring $A$, its base change to an $A$-algebra $B$ is denoted by $X_{B}$ or $X \otimes_{A} B$.

The pre-adic space associated with a formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ is denoted by $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {ad }}$. The analytic locus of $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {ad }}$ is denoted by $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$. The tilting of a perfectoid ring $R$ is denoted by $R^{s}$, and the tilting of a perfectoid affinoid pair $\left(R, R^{+}\right)$is denoted by $\left(R^{s}, R^{s+}\right)$.

# 2. Preliminaries on adic spaces 

2.1. General properties. In this section, we introduce our notation and explain the basic properties of adic spaces.

An adic ring $R$ is a topological ring endowed with a linear topology of a finitely generated ideal $I \subset R$. When $R$ is complete, we say that $R$ is a complete adic ring. If we like to emphasize the topology on $R$, we say that $R$ is a (complete) $I$-adic ring. The set of topologically nilpotent elements in $R$ is denoted by $R^{\infty}$ and $R / R^{\infty}$ is denoted by $R_{\text {red }}$.

For an affinoid pair $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$, which is usually called a Huber pair, we have a topological space $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)$and a structural presheaf $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}$with a subpresheaf $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}^{+} \subset$ $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}$introduced in [Hub93] and [Hub94]. When $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}$is a sheaf, we say that $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is an adic space. For every open subset $U \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right), \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}(U)$ (resp. $\left.\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)}^{+} \right)$is simply denoted by $\mathcal{O}(U)$ (resp. $\left.\mathcal{O}^{+}(U)\right)$. The set of topologically nilpotent elements in $\mathcal{O}(U)$ is denoted by $\mathcal{O}^{\infty}(U)$.

A rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is defined for every elements $s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \in$ $A$ such that $T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}$ generate an open ideal of $A$. The set of rational subdomains forms an open basis of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)$. There is a universal affinoid pair $\left(A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$such that $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is homeomorphic to $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right)$. When $s$ is topologically nilpotent, $\left(A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is Tate. In this paper, a rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right)$ is called Tate if $s$ is topologically nilpotent.

When $\left(A, A^{+}\right)=(R, R)$ for a complete adic ring $R, \operatorname{Spa}(R, R)$ is simply denoted by $\operatorname{Spa}(R)$. The set of analytic points in $\operatorname{Spa}(R)$ is a quasicompact open subset of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)$ and denoted by $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$. The analytic locus $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is empty if and only if $R$ is discrete (see e.g. [Wed12, Proposition 7.49 (2)]).

Lemma 2.1. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring and let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in R$ be topologically nilpotent elements. If for every $|\cdot| \in \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$, we have $\left|f_{i}\right| \neq 0$ for some $1 \leq i \leq r$, then $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}$ generate an ideal of definition of $R$.

Proof. Let $I=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right) \subset R$ and let $\bar{I}$ be the closure of $I$. Then, $R / \bar{I}$ is a complete adic ring. By assumption, $\operatorname{Spa}(R / \bar{I})^{\text {an }}$ is empty, so $R / \bar{I}$ is discrete and $\bar{I}$ is open. Since $R$ has a finitely generated ideal of definition, it follows from a standard argument that $I$ is open.
Lemma 2.2. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring. Every Tate rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right) \subset$ $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ can be taken so that $s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \in R$ generate an ideal of definition.
Proof. Since $\left(T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right) \subset R$ is open, we can take a finitely generated ideal of definition $I \subset\left(T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right)^{2}$ of $R$. It is easy to see that $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right)=R\left(\frac{f_{1}, \ldots, f_{s}, s T_{1}, \ldots, s T_{s}}{s^{2}}\right)$ for any finite set of generators $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{s} \in I$. The claim follows since $s$ is topologically nilpotent.
Lemma 2.3. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring and let $U \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ be a quasicompact open subset. There is a generator $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ of an ideal of definition of $R$ such that $U=$ $\bigcup_{1 \leq i \leq r} R\left(\frac{f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right)$ for some $1 \leq r \leq n$.
Proof. This can be proved in the same way as [Bos14, §8.4, Lemma 5]. Since $U$ is quasicompact, we can take a finite covering of $U$ by Tate rational subdomains $R\left(\frac{T_{i, 1}, \ldots, T_{i, r_{i}}}{s_{i}}\right)$ indexed by $i \in I$. We may assume that $s_{i}, T_{i, 1}, \ldots, T_{i, r_{i}} \in R$ generate an ideal of definition for all $i \in I$. Then, for every $i \in I, \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is covered by $R\left(\frac{s_{i}, T_{i, 1}, \ldots, T_{i, r_{i}}}{s_{i}}\right)$ with $a_{i} \in\left\{s_{i}, T_{i, 1}, \ldots, T_{i, r_{i}}\right\}$.

Consider the intersection of these coverings of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$. Let $F \subset R$ be the collection of elements of $R$ of the form $\prod_{i \in I} a_{i}$ with $a_{i} \in\left\{s_{i}, T_{i, 1}, \ldots, T_{i, r_{i}}\right\}$. Let $F_{0} \subset F$ be the subset consisting of elements $\prod_{i \in I} a_{i}$ with $a_{i}=s_{i}$ for some $i \in I$. Then, $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is covered by $R\left(\frac{F}{I}\right)$ with $f \in F$ and $U$ is covered by $R\left(\frac{F}{I}\right)$ with $f \in F_{0}$. Thus, we obtain the claim.
2.2. Adic spectra of reduced excellent complete adic rings. In this section, we explain the basic properties of adic spectra of reduced excellent complete adic rings.

Let $R$ be a Noetherian complete adic ring. By [Hub94], Spa $(R)$ is an adic space. For every Tate rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)$, the rational localization $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right)$ admits a Noetherian ring of definition, such as the $s$-adic completion of $R\left[\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right]$. In particular, $R\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right\rangle$ is a strongly Noetherian Tate ring. If we assume in addition that $R$ is reduced and excellent, we can prove more properties of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$.
Lemma 2.4. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring. For every Tate rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right\rangle$ is reduced and uniform. In particular, $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is stably uniform.
Proof. Since $R$ is excellent, $R\left[\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right]$ is excellent and its integral closure $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right)^{+}$in the reduced ring $R\left[\frac{1}{s}\right]$ is finite over $R\left[\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right]$ (see [Mat80, Theorem 78], [Stacks, Tag 03GH]). In particular, $R\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$is equal to the $s$-adic completion of $R\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}}{s}\right)^{+}$, so it is reduced and bounded (see [Mat80, Theorem 79]).
Proposition 2.5. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. The topological ring $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is $I$-adic and finite over $R$.

Proof. Let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ be a generator of $I$. Let $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ be the blowup along $V(I)$. The morphism $\operatorname{Spec}(R)-V(I) \rightarrow Y$ is affine. Let $Y^{+} \rightarrow Y$ be the normalization of $Y$ in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)-V(I)$. Since $R$ is reduced and excellent, $Y^{+} \rightarrow Y$ is finite. For each $1 \leq i \leq n$, let $V_{i} \subset Y$ be the open subset where $f_{i}$ divides $f_{j}$ for every $1 \leq j \leq n$ and let $V_{i}^{+}$be the inverse image of $V_{i}$ in $Y^{+}$. Now, $V_{i}$ and $V_{i}^{+}$is affine and the proof of Lemma 2.4 shows that the $I$-adic completion of $V_{i}^{+}$is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Spf}\left(R\left\langle\frac{f_{1}, \ldots f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$. In particular, $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong \lim _{k \geq 0} \Gamma\left(Y^{+} \otimes_{R}\left(R / I^{k}\right), \mathcal{O}\right)$ as topological rings. Since $Y^{+}$is proper over $R$, it follows from the formal function theorem (see e.g. [EGA3-1, Corollaire 4.1.7]) that $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is $I$-adic and finite over $R$.

Lemma 2.6. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. Let $f \in R$ be an arbitrary element and let $R^{\prime}=R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$. If $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is a homeomorphism onto the image and the image contains $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right)$, then the same properties hold for $R^{\prime}$.

Proof. We keep the notation in the proof of Proposition 2.5. We have $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong$ $\Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \mathcal{O}\right)$. Let $Y^{+}$,red be the reduction of $Y^{+} \otimes_{R}(R / I)$. Then, $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right)$ is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \mathcal{O}\right) \rightarrow \Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \operatorname{red}, \mathcal{O}\right)\right)$. Since Zariski localization preserves normalization, it follows from the same argument that $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong \lim _{k \geq 0} \Gamma\left(Y^{+} \otimes_{R}\left(R^{\prime} / I^{k}\right), \mathcal{O}\right)$ as topological rings. By the formal function theorem, we have $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong \Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \mathcal{O}\right)\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$ where $(-)^{\wedge}$ denotes the $I$-adic completion. Since $R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]$ is Noetherian and $\Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \mathcal{O}\right)$ is finite over $R, \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \otimes_{R} R^{\prime}$. Since $R \rightarrow R^{\prime}$ is flat, we see that $R^{\prime} \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is injective.

It is enough to show that the image contains $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right)$. Since $R^{\prime}=R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$, $Y^{+}$,red $\otimes_{R} R^{\prime}$ is reduced. Thus, we see that $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ker}\left(\Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \mathcal{O}\right) \otimes_{R} R^{\prime} \rightarrow\right.$ $\left.\Gamma\left(Y^{+}, \operatorname{red} \otimes_{R} R^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right)\right) \cong \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right) \otimes_{R} R^{\prime}$ as $R^{\prime}$ is flat over $R$. Thus, the claim follows since the image of $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$contains $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right)$.

Next, we explain the normality of reduced excellent analytic adic spaces.
Definition 2.7. A Tate affinoid pair $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is reduced and excellent if $A^{+}$is reduced, excellent and bounded. If $A$ is moreover normal, $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is normal and excellent.

Note that $A^{+}$is also normal if $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is normal and excellent.
Lemma 2.8. Let $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$be a reduced excellent Tate affinoid pair. Any rational localization $\left(B, B^{+}\right)$of $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is reduced and excellent.
Proof. We may write $\left(B, B^{+}\right)=\left(A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$for $s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \in A^{\infty}$. As in Lemma 2.4, let $A\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right)^{+}$be the integral closure of $A^{+}\left[\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]$ in $A\left[\frac{1}{s}\right]$. Since $A^{+}$is excellent and $A\left[\frac{1}{s}\right]$ is reduced and of finite type over $A^{+}, A\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right)^{+}$is finite over $A^{+}\left[\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]$. As in Lemma 2.4, we see that $B^{+}$is reduced, excellent and bounded.

Lemma 2.9. Let $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$be a reduced excellent Tate affinoid pair. Let $\left\{\left(B_{i}, B_{i}^{+}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}$ be a finite set of rational localizations of $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$such that $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)=\bigcup_{i \in I} \operatorname{Spa}\left(B_{i}, B_{i}^{+}\right)$. Then, $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$is normal if and only if $\left(B_{i}, B_{i}^{+}\right)$is normal for every $i \in I$.

Proof. By [Hub96, Lemma 1.7.6], $A \rightarrow \prod_{i \in I} B_{i}$ is faithfully flat, so $A$ is normal if $B_{i}$ is normal for every $i \in I$ by [Mat80, Corollary 21.3]. On the other hand, suppose that $A$ is normal and let $\left(B_{i}, B_{i}^{+}\right)=\left(A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$for $s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \in A^{\infty}$. Since $A\left[\frac{1}{s}\right]$ is normal, $A\left(\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right)^{+}$is normal and excellent. Thus, $A\left\langle\frac{T_{1}, \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$is normal by [Mat80, Theorem 79], so $B_{i}$ is normal.

Corollary 2.10. Let $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$be a reduced excellent Tate affinoid pair. Let $\left(B, B^{+}\right)$be a Tate affinoid pair étale over $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$. Then, $B$ is reduced, and $B$ is normal if $A$ is normal.
Proof. By Lemma 2.9, we may localize $\left(B, B^{+}\right)$so that $\left(A, A^{+}\right) \rightarrow\left(B, B^{+}\right)$is decomposed into a finite étale homomorphism and a rational localization. By [SGA1, Expose I, Theorem 9.5 (i)], étale homomorphisms preserve reducedness and normality, so the claim follows.

We say that an analytic adic space is reduced (resp. normal) and excellent if it is analytic locally isomorphic to the adic spectrum of a reduced (resp. normal) and excellent Tate affinoid pair. By the proof of Lemma 2.4, $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is reduced and excellent for every reduced excellent complete adic ring $R$.
2.3. Finiteness criterion. The aim of this section is to prove the following finiteness criterion. It is a key ingredient in our affine representability criterion (see Theorem 5.19).

For a complete adic ring $R$ with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$, we say that a complete $I$-adic $R$-algebra $S$ is topologically of finite type if $S / I S$ is of finite type over $R / I$.

Proposition 2.11. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$. Let $U \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ be a quasicompact open subset and let $S \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}(U)$ be an $R$-subalgebra. Suppose that the following conditions hold.
(1) The subspace topology on $S$ from $\mathcal{O}^{+}(U)$ is the I-adic topology.
(2) $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is a homeomorphism onto $U$.
(3) $\left(S_{\text {red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$.

Then, $S$ is reduced, excellent and topologically of finite type over $R$, and $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow U$ is an isomorphism of adic spaces.

Note that the condition (1) is necessary by Proposition 2.5 and the conditions (2) and (3) can be checked after the $v$-sheafification.

By Lemma 2.3, we can take a generator $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ of an ideal of definition such that $U$ is the union of $R\left(\frac{f_{1}, \ldots f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right)$ with $1 \leq i \leq r$ for some $1 \leq r \leq n$. We may assume that $I=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$. We keep the notation from the proof of Proposition 2.5. Let $Y_{0} \subset Y$ (resp. $Y_{0}^{+} \subset Y^{+}$) be the union of $V_{i}$ (resp. $V_{i}^{+}$) with $1 \leq i \leq r$. Then, the $I$-adic completion of $Y_{0}^{+}$ is a formal model of $U$.

By the condition (2), we have $\left|f_{i}\right| \neq 0$ for some $1 \leq i \leq r$ for every $\left|-\right| \in \operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$. Thus, $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}$ generate an ideal of definition of $S$ by Lemma 2.1. Let $Z \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(S)$ be the blowup along $V\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right)$ and let $Z^{+} \rightarrow Z$ be the normalization in $\operatorname{Spec}(S)-V\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right) \rightarrow Z$. For each $1 \leq i \leq r$, let $W_{i} \subset Z$ be the open subset where $f_{i}$ divides $f_{j}$ for every $1 \leq j \leq r$ and let $W_{i}^{+}$be the inverse image of $W_{i}$ in $Z^{+}$.
Lemma 2.12. There is a natural morphism $W_{i}^{+} \rightarrow V_{i}^{+}$for every $1 \leq i \leq r$.
Proof. By construction, $W_{i}$ and $W_{i}^{+}$is the spectrum of $S\left[\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{r}}{f_{i}}\right]$ and $S\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{r}}{f_{i}}\right)^{+}$, respectively. It is enough to show that $f_{j} / f_{i} \in S\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{r}}{f_{i}}\right)^{+}$for every $1 \leq j \leq n$. Since the rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{r}}{f_{i}}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$ maps to $R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ by the condition (2), we have a continuous homomorphism $R\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right\rangle \rightarrow S\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right\rangle$. Thus, $f_{j} / f_{i} \in S\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right\rangle^{+}$. Since $S\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right\rangle^{+}$is the completion of $S\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{r}}{f_{i}}\right)^{+}$, we have $f_{j} / f_{i} \in S\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots . f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right)^{+}$.

By gluing these morphisms, we get an affine morphism $Z^{+} \rightarrow Y_{0}^{+}$. Let $Z_{0}^{+}$be the schemetheoretic image of $Z^{+} \rightarrow Z \times Y_{0}^{+}$. Since $Z^{+}$is integral over $Z$ and $Y^{+}$is of finite type over $R, Z_{0}^{+}$is finite over $Z$.

Let $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}$(resp. $\mathfrak{Z}_{0}^{+}$) be the $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right)$-adic completion of $Y_{0}^{+}$(resp. $Z_{0}^{+}$). Since $S \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}(U)$, we have a morphism $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(S)$. We have the following commutative diagram.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Lemma 2.13. The underlying map $\left|\mathfrak{Z}_{0}^{+}\right| \rightarrow\left|\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}\right|$is surjective.
Proof. By construction, $Y_{0}^{+}$is $I$-torsion free, so the specialization map of $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}$is surjective (see [FK18, Proposition 3.1.5]). Since the specialization map is functorial, it is enough to show that $\left(\mathfrak{Z}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow\left(\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is surjective (see Section 3.2 for the specialization maps of formal schemes over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ ). Since $Y_{0}^{+}$(resp. $Z_{0}^{+}$) is finite over $Y_{0}$ (resp. $Z$ ), it follows from the construction that $\left(\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong \mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{\text {an }} \cong U$ and $\left(\mathfrak{Z}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong \mathfrak{Z}^{\text {an }} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$. Thus, the claim follows from the condition (2).

Since $Z_{0}^{+}$is proper over $\operatorname{Spec}(S)$, we see that $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(S)$ is universally closed.
Now, since $\left(S_{\text {red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$, we can take a homomorphism $P=R\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{m}\right] \rightarrow S$ such that $\operatorname{Spec}(S / I S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(P / I P)$ is universally closed. Then, for every $k \geq 0$, the composition $Y_{0}^{+} \otimes_{R}\left(R / I^{k}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(S / I^{k} S\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(P / I^{k} P\right)$ is proper. Since $R$ is Noetherian, it follows that $\Gamma\left(Y_{0}^{+} \otimes_{R}\left(R / I^{k}\right), \mathcal{O}\right)$ is finite over $P$.

Let $S_{k} \subset \Gamma\left(Y_{0}^{+} \otimes_{R}\left(R / I^{k}\right), \mathcal{O}\right)$ be the image of $S$. Since $P$ is Noetherian, $S_{k}$ is also finite over $P$. Let $I_{k}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(S \rightarrow S_{k}\right)$. The condition (1) means that the subspace topology on $S$, which is defined by the system $\left\{I_{k}\right\}$, is equal to the $I$-adic topology. Thus, for sufficiently

large $k$, we have $I_{k} \subset I S$, so $S / I S$ is finite over $P$. In particular, $S$ is topologically of finite type over $R$.

By Lemma 2.4, $\mathcal{O}^{+}(U)$ is reduced, so $S$ is reduced and excellent. In particular, $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$ is an adic space. Since $\left(\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong U$, the analytification of $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{+} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(S)$ gives a right inverse to $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow U$. Since $\left(\mathfrak{Z}_{0}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$, it is also a left inverse. Thus, we get $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \cong U$.
2.4. Formal modifications. In this section, we explain an interpretation of formal modifications (see [Stacks, Tag 0GDK]) of reduced excellent formal schemes in terms of adic spaces.

The axiom of formal modifications consists of properness, rig-étaleness (see [Stacks, Tag 0ALP]) and rig-surjectivity (see [Stacks, Tag 0AQQ]). First, we treat properness and rigsurjectivity. Recall that a morphism of formal schemes is proper if it is topologically of finite type, separated and universally closed. We say that a formal scheme is thick if its specialization map is surjective (see Section 3.2).

Lemma 2.14. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a thick separated formal scheme topologically of finite type over $R$. If $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is an isomorphism, $\mathfrak{X}$ is proper and rig-surjective over $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ and $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow$ $\mathfrak{X} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \mathfrak{X}$ is rig-surjective.

Proof. Let $\left\{\mathfrak{U}_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ be a finite affine covering of $\mathfrak{X}$. As in Lemma 2.3, we can take a set of generators $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ of an ideal of definition such that for every $1 \leq j \leq n, R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{j}}\right)$ is contained in $\mathfrak{U}_{i}^{\text {an }}$ for some $i \in I$.

We repeat the construction in the proof of Proposition 2.5 for this choice of $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$. For each $1 \leq j \leq n$, let $i_{j} \in I$ be an element such that $R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{j}}\right) \subset \mathfrak{U}_{i_{j}}^{\text {an }}$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}^{+}$(resp. $\mathfrak{V}_{j}^{+}$) be the $I$-adic completion of $Y^{+}$(resp. $V_{j}^{+}$). By the property of $\mathfrak{V}_{j}^{+}$, this inclusion extends to $\mathfrak{V}_{j}^{+} \rightarrow \mathfrak{U}_{i_{j}}$ and the composition $\mathfrak{V}_{j}^{+} \rightarrow \mathfrak{U}_{i_{j}} \hookrightarrow \mathfrak{X}$ is independent of the choice of $i_{j}$. Thus, by gluing the morphisms for all $1 \leq j \leq n$, we get a morphism $\mathfrak{Y}^{+} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$. Since $\mathfrak{X}$ is thick and $\left(\mathfrak{Y}^{+}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$, we see by looking at the specialization maps that $\left|\mathfrak{Y}^{+}\right| \rightarrow|\mathfrak{X}|$ is surjective. Since $Y^{+}$is proper over $R$, it follows that $\mathfrak{X}$ is proper.

Next, we prove rig-surjectivity. It is enough to show that for every adic morphism $x_{0}: \operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $V$ a complete discrete valuation ring, there is a unique lift $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$. Let $K=\operatorname{Frac}(V)$. Since $x_{0}$ is adic, we have $x_{0}^{\text {an }}: \operatorname{Spa}(K, V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }} \cong$ $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$. Thus, $x_{0}^{\text {an }}$ factors through $\mathfrak{U}_{i}^{\text {an }}$ for some $i \in I$. Since $\mathfrak{U}_{i}$ is affine, $x_{0}^{\text {an }}$ uniquely lifts to $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{U}_{i}$ and we get a desired lift of $x_{0}$. It is easy to see that such a lift is independent of the choice of $\mathfrak{U}_{i}$, so we get the uniqueness of a lift of $x_{0}$.

Next, we treat rig-étaleness. Here, we can only deal with the monogeneous case due to essential technical difficulty.

Lemma 2.15. Let $R$ be a Noetherian complete adic ring with the $\varpi$-adic topology for $\varpi \in$ $R$. Let $S$ be a $\varpi$-torsion free complete adic $R$-algebra topologically of finite type. Then, $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is étale if and only if $R \rightarrow S$ is rig-étale.

Proof. First, suppose that $R \rightarrow S$ is rig-étale. By [Stacks, Tag 0AKG], there is a finite type $R$-algebra $S_{0}$ such that $S_{0}\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$ is étale over $R\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$ and $\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge} \cong S$. It follows from [Hub96, Corollary 1.7.3 (iii)] that $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is étale.

Next, suppose that $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is étale. By [Hub96, Corollary 1.7.3 (iii)], there is a finite type $R$-algebra $S_{0}$ such that $S_{0}\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$ is étale over $R\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$ and $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is isomorphic to the integral closure of $\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge}$ in $\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$. Since $S$ is topologically of finite type over $R$ and is a subring of $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$as $S$ is $\varpi$-torsion free, we may enlarge $S_{0}$ in $S_{0}\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$ so that $\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge}$ contains $S$. We will show that there is a finite type $R$-subalgebra $S_{1} \subset S_{0}$ such that $\left(S_{1}\right)^{\wedge} \cong S$.

Since $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is also the integral closure of $S$ in $S\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right],\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge}$ is finite over $S$. In particular, for sufficiently large $n \geq 0$, we have $\varpi^{n}\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge} \subset S$. Let $A \subset S_{0} / \varpi^{n} S_{0}$ be the image of $S \rightarrow\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge} \rightarrow S_{0} / \varpi^{n} S_{0}$ and let $S_{1} \subset S_{0}$ be the inverse image of $A$. Then, $S_{0} / \varpi^{n} S_{0}$ is finite over $A$, so $S_{0}$ is finite over $S_{1}$. Since $S_{0}$ is of finite type over $R$ and $R$ is Noetherian, $S_{1}$ is of finite type over $R$. By construction, we see that $\left(S_{1}\right)^{\wedge} \subset\left(S_{0}\right)^{\wedge}$ is equal to $S$. Thus, $R \rightarrow S$ is rig-étale by [Stacks, Tag 0AKG].

The following lemmas are needed to compare conditions on rig-points with those on analytic points.

Lemma 2.16. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a Noetherian formal scheme. For every nonempty open subset $U \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$, there is a complete discrete valuation ring $V$ with an adic morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$ such that $\operatorname{Spa}(K, V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$ factors through $U$ where $K=\operatorname{Frac}(V)$.
Proof. We may assume that $\mathfrak{X}$ is affine. Let $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$. Since $U$ is nonempty, there is a set of generators $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ of an ideal of definition such that $R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{1}}\right)$ is nonempty and contained in $U$ (cf. Lemma 2.3). By replacing $R$ by $R\left[\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{1}}\right]^{\wedge}$, we may assume that $U=\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$. It is enough to show that there is an adic morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $V$ a complete discrete valuation ring.

Since $R$ is $I$-adically complete, there is a point $x \in V(I) \subset \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ that lies in the closure of $\operatorname{Spec}(R)-V(I) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$. By applying [Stacks, Tag 0CM2] to $\operatorname{Spec}(R)-V(I) \hookrightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$, we see that there is a discrete valuation $R$-algebra $V$ such that $\operatorname{Spec}(V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ sends the closed point to $x$ and the generic point to a point outside $V(I)$. Then, $\operatorname{Spf}\left(V^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is an adic morphism where $V^{\wedge}$ is the completion of $V$.

Lemma 2.17. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a Noetherian formal scheme. For every quasicompact open immersion $U \hookrightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$ with $U \neq \mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$, there is a complete discrete valuation ring $V$ with an adic morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$ such that $\operatorname{Spa}(K, V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}$ does not factor through $U$ where $K=\operatorname{Frac}(V)$.

Proof. We may assume that $\mathfrak{X}$ is affine. Let $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$. By Lemma 2.3, there is a set of generators $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R$ of an ideal of definition such that $U$ is the union of $R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right)$ with $1 \leq i \leq r$ for some $1 \leq r \leq n$. Let $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ be the blowup along $V\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$ and let $V_{i} \subset Y$ be the open subset where $f_{i}$ divides $f_{j}$ for every $1 \leq j \leq n$. Let $Y_{0} \subset Y$ be the union of $V_{i}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq r$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}$ (resp. $\mathfrak{Y}_{0}, \mathfrak{V}_{i}$ ) be the $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$-adic completion of $Y$ (resp. $\left.Y_{0}, V_{i}\right)$. We have $\mathfrak{V}_{i}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong R\left(\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{n}}{f_{i}}\right)$ and $U \cong \mathfrak{Y}_{0}^{\mathrm{an}}$. Since $U \neq \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}, Y_{0} \neq Y$. Since $Y$ is proper over $R$, the image of $Y-Y_{0} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is a nonempty closed subset, so there is a point $y \in Y-Y_{0}$ whose image in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ lies in $V\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$. As in the proof of Lemma 2.16, there is an adic morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}$ such that the closed point maps to $y$. By looking at the specialization map, we see that $\operatorname{Spa}(K, V) \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ does not factor through $U$.

Proposition 2.18. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with the $\varpi$-adic topology for $\varpi \in R$. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a thick separated formal scheme topologically of finite type over $R$. Then, $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is a formal modification if and only if $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an isomorphism.

Proof. First, suppose that $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an isomorphism. Then, $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is proper, rig-étale and rig-surjective by Lemma 2.14 and Lemma 2.15. Moreover, $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \mathfrak{X}$ is rig-surjective by Lemma 2.14. Thus, $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is a formal modification.

Next, suppose that $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is a formal modification. By Lemma 2.15, $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is étale. By [Hub96, Proposition 1.6.8], the diagonal $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}} \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an open immersion. Since $\mathfrak{X}$ is separated, $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ is separated (see [Glc24, Proposition 4.17]) and $\left|\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}\right| \rightarrow$ $\left|\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}} \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}\right|$ is a closed immersion by [Sch17, Lemma 15.6]. Thus, $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}}$ $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}$ is a closed and open immersion. By Lemma 2.16, the rig-surjectivity of $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \mathfrak{X}$ implies $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \times_{\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}} \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an isomorphism. Since $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is étale, it follows that $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an open immersion. Moreover, since $\mathfrak{X}$ is topologically of finite type over $R, \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is a quasicompact open immersion. Thus, since $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is rig-surjective, it follows from Lemma 2.17 that $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an isomorphism.

# 3. THE THEORY OF $v$-SHEAVES AND KIMBERLITES 

3.1. Basic facts on $v$-sheaves. In this section, we review the theory of $v$-sheaves developed in [Sch17] and [AGLR22].

Let Perf be the category of perfectoid spaces over $\mathbb{F}_{p}$. The $v$-topology is a Grothendieck topology on Perf introduced in [Sch17, Definition 8.1]. A sheaf (resp. stack) on Perf with the $v$-topology is called a $v$-sheaf (resp. $v$-stack). Via the Yoneda embedding, perfectoid spaces can be regarded as $v$-sheaves.

A $v$-sheaf $X$ is small if there is a surjection $Y \rightarrow X$ of $v$-sheaves from a perfectoid space $Y$. Moreover, $X$ is quasicompact if we can take $Y$ to be quasicompact. Then, quasicompact maps and quasiseparated maps of $v$-sheaves can be defined (see [Sch17, Section 8]).

A map of $v$-sheaves is said to be qcqs if it is quasicompact and quasiseparated. An important property of $v$-sheaves is that injectivity and surjectivity of qcqs maps can be checked on geometric points (see [Sch17, Lemma 12.11, Proposition 12.15]). The underlying space of a $v$-sheaf $X$ is denoted by $|X|$ ([Sch17, Proposition 12.7]). For a topological space $T$, the functor sending $S \in \operatorname{Perf}$ to the set of continuous maps from $|S|$ to $T$ is a $v$-sheaf and denoted by $\underline{T}$ ([Sch17, p.53]). For example, these properties are used in the following way.

Lemma 3.1. Let $S$ be a $v$-sheaf and let $X$ and $Y$ be $v$-sheaves over $S$. Let $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ be two maps of $v$-sheaves over $S$. If $X$ is small, $Y$ is quasiseparated over $S$, and $f(x)=g(x)$ for every $x \in X\left(C, C^{+}\right)$with $C$ an algebraically closed perfectoid field with an open and bounded valuation subring $C^{+} \subset C$, we have $f=g$.

Proof. The diagonal $\Delta_{Y / S}: Y \rightarrow Y \times_{S} Y$ is a quasicompact injection. It is enough to show that $f \times g: X \rightarrow Y \times_{S} Y$ factors through $\Delta_{Y / S}$. Let $Z=X \times_{Y \times_{S} Y, \Delta_{Y / S}} Y$. Since the map $Z \rightarrow X$ is quasicompact and $X$ is small, $Z$ is small. For every $x \in X\left(C, C^{+}\right)$as above, we have $f(x)=g(x)$, so $x$ lies in $Z$. In particular, $|Z| \rightarrow|X|$ is surjective, so the claim follows from [Sch17, Lemma 12.11].

Let $X$ be a small $v$-sheaf and let $Y$ be a subsheaf of $X$. The intersection of all closed subsheaves of $X$ containing $Y$ is called the $v$-closure of $Y$ in $X$ and denoted by $Y^{\text {cl }}$ (see [AGLR22, Definition 2.2]). Every closed subsheaf of a small $v$-sheaf $X$ is of the form $\underline{S} \times_{\underline{|X|}} X$ with $S \subset|X|$ a weakly generalizing closed subspace (see [AGLR22, Definition 2.3, Lemma 2.7]). Moreover, for a subsheaf $Y \subset X$, we have $Y^{\text {cl }}=\underline{|Y|}^{\text {wge }} \times_{\underline{|X|}} X$ with $|Y|^{\text {wge }}$ the weakly generalizing closure of $|Y|$ in $|X|$ (see [AGLR22, Proposition 2.8]).

Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. The functor taking $S \in \operatorname{Perf}$ to the set of pairs $\left(\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right), f: S^{\sharp} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\text {ad }}\right)$ with $\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right)$ an untilt of $S$ is a $v$-sheaf and denoted by $\mathfrak{X}^{\diamond}$. For an adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}, \operatorname{Spf}(R)^{\diamond}$ is denoted by $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$.

In general, the functor $\mathfrak{X} \mapsto \mathfrak{X}^{\diamond}$ from formal schemes over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ to small $v$-sheaves over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)$ is not fully faithful. However, the $v$-sheafification is fully faithful if we suitably restrict the category of formal schemes (cf. Proposition 4.27, Lemma 5.33).

It is useful that $\operatorname{Spd}(f): \operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is qcqs for an adic homomorphism $f: R \rightarrow S$ of adic rings over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ (see [Gle24, Lemma 2.26]). This implies that $\mathfrak{X}^{\diamond}$ is qcqs over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ for a qcqs adic formal $R$-scheme $\mathfrak{X}$.

There is a $v$-sheaf attached to a scheme $X$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ that is often denoted by $X^{\diamond}$ (see [AGLR22, Section 2.2]). It is a $v$-sheafification of the functor taking an affinoid perfectoid pair $\left(S, S^{+}\right)$over $\mathbb{F}_{p}$ to the set of pairs $\left(\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right), x\right)$ with $\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right)$ an untilt of $S$ and $x \in X\left(S^{\sharp}\right)$. The following lemma exhibits a certain relation between $X^{\diamond}$ and $X^{\diamond}$.

Lemma 3.2. Let $R$ be a $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$-algebra and let $X$ be a proper $R$-scheme. There is a natural isomorphism $X^{\diamond} \cong X^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}(R)^{\diamond}} \operatorname{Spec}(R)^{\diamond}$.

Proof. It follows from the same reason as in the comment after [AGLR22, Remark 2.11]. There is a natural inclusion $X^{\diamond} \rightarrow X^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}(R)^{\diamond}} \operatorname{Spec}(R)^{\diamond}$, and it is surjective by the valuative criterion for properness.

Here, we record the following basic lemma.
Lemma 3.3. Let $R \rightarrow S$ be an adic integral homomorphism of adic rings. Then, $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is proper. Moreover, if $R \rightarrow S$ is injective, $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective.

Proof. We use a valuative criterion for properness ([Sch17, Proposition 18.3]) to the qcqs map $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$. Let $K$ be a perfectoid field in characteristic $p$ with an open and bounded valuation subring $K^{+} \subset K$ and consider the following diagram.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Let $\left(K^{\sharp}, K^{+ \sharp}\right)$ be the untilt of $\left(K, K^{+}\right)$with an identification $\iota:\left(K^{\sharp}\right)^{\diamond} \cong K$ and let $S \rightarrow O_{K^{\sharp}}$ be the corresponding homomorphism. Since it maps $R$ to $K^{+ \sharp}$ and $K^{+ \sharp}$ is integrally closed in $K^{\sharp}$, we see that the map factors through $K^{+ \sharp}$. Thus, we obtain a valuative criterion.

Next, suppose that $R \rightarrow S$ is injective. Take an arbitrary map $R \rightarrow C^{+}$with $C$ an algebraically closed perfectoid field with an open and bounded valuation subring $C^{+} \subset C$. Since $R \rightarrow S$ is injective, the map $\operatorname{Spec}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is surjective. Since $C$ is algebraically closed, the map $R \rightarrow C$ has a lift $S \rightarrow C$. Since $S$ is integral over $R$, it maps $S$ to $C^{+}$. Thus, the map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(C, C^{+}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ admits a lift to $\operatorname{Spd}(S)$.
3.2. Kimberlites and thick closures. In this section, we review the theory of kimberlites developed in [Gle24], [AGLR22] and [Gle].

Let SchPerf be the category of perfect schemes. It is equipped with the $v$-topology (see [BS17, Definition 2.1]) and a sheaf on SchPerf with the $v$-topology is called a scheme-theoretic $v$-sheaf.

Let $X$ be a $v$-sheaf. The functor taking $S \in \operatorname{SchPerf}$ to the set $\operatorname{Hom}\left(S^{\diamond}, X\right)$ is a schemetheoretic $v$-sheaf and denoted by $X^{\text {red }}$ (see [Gle24, Lemma 2.26]). If $X$ is small, $X^{\text {red }}$ is also small. Then, formally adic morphisms can be defined as in [Gle24, Definition 3.20]. A map $Y \rightarrow X$ of $v$-sheaves is formally adic if $\left(Y^{\text {red }}\right)^{\diamond} \cong\left(X^{\text {red }}\right)^{\diamond} \times_{X} Y$.

We explain several terminology to review the definition of kimberlites. A small $v$-sheaf $X$ is formally separated if the diagonal $\Delta_{X}: X \rightarrow X \times X$ is a formally adic closed immersion (see [Gle24, Definition 3.27]). A small $v$-sheaf $X$ is $v$-formalizing if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions (see [Gle24, Definition 4.5, 4.6, Lemma 4.7], [AGLR22, Proposition 2.22]).

(1) There is a surjection of $v$-sheaves from a disjoint union of $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{+}\right)$with $\left(R, R^{+}\right)$a perfectoid affinoid pair to $X$.
(2) For every map $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right) \rightarrow X$ from an affinoid perfectoid space, there is a $v$-cover $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S, S^{+}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$that admits an extension $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{+}\right) \rightarrow X$.
If $X$ is formally separated, $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S, S^{+}\right) \rightarrow X$ admits at most one extension $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{+}\right) \rightarrow X$ (see [Gle24, Proposition 4.9]). Now, a small $v$-sheaf $X$ is a prekimberlite if
(1) $X$ is formally separated and $v$-formalizing, and
(2) $X^{\text {red }}$ is represented by a perfect scheme and $\left(X^{\text {red }}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow X$ is a closed immersion.

For a prekimberlite $X$, the open subsheaf $X \backslash\left(X^{\text {red }}\right)^{\circ}$ is called the analytic locus of $X$ and denoted by $X^{\text {an }}$. The $v$-sheaf $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ is a prekimberlite for a separated formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ (see [Gle24, Proposition 4.17]) and we have $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ, \text { red }}=\left(\mathfrak{X}_{\text {red }}^{\text {perf }}\right)^{\circ}$.

One important property is that a prekimberlite $X$ admits a specialization map $\mathrm{sp}_{X}:|X| \rightarrow$ $\left|X^{\text {red }}\right|$ (see [Gle24, Definition 4.12]). The restriction of $\mathrm{sp}_{X}$ to $X^{\text {an }}$ is denoted by $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}$. When $\mathfrak{X}$ is a separated Noetherian formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}, \mathrm{sp}_{\left(\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}\right)^{\circ}}$ coincides with the usual specialization map of $\mathfrak{X}$ (see e.g. [FK18, Section 3.1]).

For an open subspace $U \subset X^{\text {red }}$, the open subsheaf of $X$ corresponding to $\mathrm{sp}_{X}^{-1}(U)$ is denoted by $\widehat{X}_{/ U}$. When $X$ is represented by a separated formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}, \widehat{X}_{/ U}$ is represented by the open formal subscheme of $\mathfrak{X}$ whose underlying space is $U$ (see the proof of [AGLR22, Theorem 2.16]).

Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a Noetherian formal scheme. The specialization map of $\mathfrak{X}$ is quasicompact and closed (see [FK18, Theorem 3.1.2]), and surjective if $\mathfrak{X}$ is distinguished in the sense of [FK18, Definition 2.1.8] (see [FK18, Proposition 3.1.5]). However, we need to put more assumptions on a prekimberlite $X$ so that $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}$ behaves similarly.

For a perfect scheme $Y$, let $Y^{\circ / \circ}$ be the analytic sheafification of the functor taking $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right) \in \operatorname{Perf}$ to $Y\left(R_{\text {red }}^{+}\right)$. For a prekimberlite $X$, there is a map $\mathrm{SP}_{X}: X \rightarrow\left(X^{\text {red }}\right)^{\circ / \circ}$ introduced in [Gle24, Section 4.4]. We say that $X$ is valuative if $\mathrm{SP}_{X}$ is partially proper. A valuative prekimberlite $X$ is a kimberlite if $X^{\text {an }}$ is a quasiseparated locally spatial diamond and $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}$ is quasicompact (see [Gle24, Definition 4.35]). For a separated formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}, \mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ is a kimberlite and the specialization map of $\mathfrak{X}$ refers to the map $\mathrm{sp}_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ, \text { an }}}$.

The specialization map $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}$ of a kimberlite $X$ becomes a spectral closed map (see [Gle24, Theorem 4.40]). Following [Gle, Definition 4.7], we say that a prekimberlite $X$ is thick if $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}$ is surjective.

Definition 3.4. Let $X$ be a kimberlite and let $Z \subset X^{\text {an }}$ be a closed subsheaf. The closed subsheaf of $X$ corresponding to $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}(Z)^{\circ} \cup Z$ is called the thick closure of $Z$ in $X$.

Note that $\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}(Z) \subset\left|X^{\text {red }}\right|$ is closed when $X$ is a kimberlite. The union $\left|\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}(Z)^{\circ}\right| \cup|Z|$ is closed because its complement is a union of $\left|X^{\text {an }}\right|-|Z|$ and $\mathrm{sp}_{X}^{-1}\left(\left|X^{\text {red }}\right|-\mathrm{sp}_{X^{\text {an }}}(Z)\right)$. It is easy to see that the closed subset is weakly generalizing.

Following these notions, we say that a separated formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ is thick if the specialization map of $\mathfrak{X}$ is surjective. We say that an adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ is thick if $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is thick.
Lemma 3.5. A complete adic ring $R$ with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$ is thick if and only if for every $f \in R$ such that $f^{n} \cdot I^{n} \subset I^{n+1}$ for some $n \geq 1$, we have $f \in R^{\infty}$.
Proof. First, $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is not thick if and only if for some $f \in R-R^{\infty}, \operatorname{Spa}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right], R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]\right)$ contains only discrete points. It is equivalent to the condition that the $I$-adic completion $R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$ is discrete (see e.g. [Wed12, Proposition 7.49 (2)]). It is equivalent to $I^{n} \cdot R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]=I^{n+1} \cdot R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]$ for some $n \geq 1$. Since $I$ is finitely generated, it is equivalent to $f^{n} \cdot I^{n} \subset I^{n+1}$ for some $n \geq 1$.

Following [FK18, Chapter II, Definition 2.1.8], we say that a complete adic ring $R$ is distinguished if $R$ is $I$-torsion free for some ideal of definition $I \subset R$, and a formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ is distinguished if it is Zariski locally isomorphic to the formal spectrum of a distinguished complete adic ring. By [FK18, Proposition 3.1.5], a distinguished separated Noetherian formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ is thick. Here, we verify that this holds without Noetherian assumption.
Lemma 3.6. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. If $R$ is distinguished, $R$ is thick.
Proof. First, suppose that $R$ is $\varpi$-adic for some non-zero-divisor $\varpi \in R$. Then, the claim can be checked by Lemma 3.5. Let $f \in R$ be an element such that $f^{n} \cdot\left(\varpi^{n}\right) \subset\left(\varpi^{n+1}\right)$ for some $n \geq 1$. We can write $f^{n} \varpi^{n}=\varpi^{n+1} x$ for some $x \in R$. Since $\varpi$ is a non-zero-divisor, we have $f^{n}=\varpi x$. Thus, we have $f \in R^{\infty}$.

The general case can be reduced to the above case. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition and let $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ be the blowup along $V(I)$. Since $R$ is $I$-torsion free, $\operatorname{Spec}(R)-V(I)$ is dense in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ and $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is surjective. Let $\mathfrak{Y}$ be the $I$-adic completion of $Y$. Since $\mathfrak{Y}$ is locally monogeneous and distinguished, $\mathfrak{Y}$ is thick. Since the specialization maps are functorial and $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is surjective, $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is thick.

Though thick closures and $v$-closures may differ in general (see [AGLR22, footnote 10, Lemma 2.37]), they will coincide under suitable Noetherian assumptions.
Lemma 3.7. Let $R$ be a Noetherian adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. If $R$ is I-torsion free, $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is dense in $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$.
Proof. This can be proved in the same way as [Lou20, Lemma 4.4]. Let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in I$ be a set of generators and let $\left(S, S^{+}\right)=\left(R \sharp s \sharp\left\langle\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R \sharp s \sharp\left\langle\frac{f_{1} \ldots f_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)\right.$, which is a rational localization of $\left.R \sharp s \sharp\right]$. Since $R$ is Noetherian and $I$-torsion free, $\left(S, S^{+}\right)$is strongly Noetherian and $I$-torsion free. Then, for any rational localization $\left(T, T^{+}\right)$of $\left(S, S^{+}\right), T$ is flat over $S$, so $T$ is $I$-torsion free. In particular, the inverse image of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ in $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S, S^{+}\right)$is dense. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S, S^{+}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective and $\left|\operatorname{Spd}\left(S, S^{+}\right)\right| \cong\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(S, S^{+}\right)\right|$by [Sch17, Proposition 15.4], we see that $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is dense in $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$.

3.3. Geometric quotients. In this section, we introduce geometric quotients of $v$-sheaves by group actions. The theory of $v$-sheaves is quite topological and the theory of geometric quotients works well.
Definition 3.8. Let $\Gamma$ be a group and let $X$ be a $v$-sheaf with a $\Gamma$-action. A map $\pi: X \rightarrow Y$ of $v$-sheaves is a geometric quotient of $X$ by $\Gamma$ if $\pi$ is surjective, and for every geometric point $x \in X\left(C, C^{+}\right)$with $C$ an algebraically closed perfectoid field with an open and bounded valuation subring $C^{+} \subset C$, we have $\pi^{-1}(\pi(x))=\{\gamma \cdot x \mid \gamma \in \Gamma\}$.
Lemma 3.9. Let $X$ be a $v$-sheaf with an action of a group $\Gamma$. Let $\pi: X \rightarrow Y$ be a geometric quotient of $X$ by $\Gamma$. For every map $Z \rightarrow Y$ of $v$-sheaves, the base change $X \times_{Y} Z \rightarrow Z$ is a geometric quotient of $X \times_{Y} Z$ by the natural $\Gamma$-action.
Proof. It is immediate from the definition.
We need some assumptions to show the uniqueness of geometric quotients. For this, we fix a $v$-sheaf $S$ that plays the role of a base and consider small $v$-sheaves over $S$.
Proposition 3.10. Let $X$ be a small $v$-sheaf with an action of a group $\Gamma$ over $S$. Let $\pi: X \rightarrow Y$ be a geometric quotient of $X$ by $\Gamma$ over $S$. Suppose that $Y$ is quasiseparated over $S$.
(1) For every $\gamma \in \Gamma$, we have $\gamma \cdot \pi=\pi$.
(2) For every small $v$-sheaf $Z$ quasiseparated over $S$, a map $f: X \rightarrow Z$ over $S$ factors through $Y$ if and only if $\gamma \cdot f=f$ for every $\gamma \in \Gamma$.
Proof. For (1), we can check the equality $\gamma \cdot \pi=\pi$ at each geometric point of $X$ by Lemma 3.1, so the claim follows. For (2), it is enough to show that $f$ factors through $Y$ if $\gamma \cdot f=f$ for every $\gamma \in \Gamma$. It is enough to check the equality of two maps $f \circ \mathrm{pr}_{i}: X \times_{Y} X \rightrightarrows Z$ $(i=1,2)$. Again, we can check the equality at each geometric point by Lemma 3.1. Since any geometric point of $X \times_{Y} X$ is of the form $(x, \gamma \cdot x)$ for some $\gamma \in \Gamma$, we get the claim.

The main source of geometric quotients by finite groups is as follows.
Proposition 3.11. Let $R \rightarrow S$ be an injective adic homomorphism of complete adic rings. Suppose that a finite group $\Gamma$ acts on $S$ so that $R=S^{\Gamma}$. Then, $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma$.
Proof. Since $R=S^{\Gamma}, R \rightarrow S$ is injective and integral. Thus, $\pi: \operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective by Lemma 3.3. Take a geometric point $x \in \operatorname{Spd}(S)\left(C, C^{+}\right)$with $C$ an algebraically closed perfectoid field with an open and bounded valuation subring $C^{+} \subset$ $C$. It corresponds to an untilt $\left(C^{\sharp}, \iota\right)$ and a continuous homomorphism $S \rightarrow C^{+}{ }^{\sharp}$. Set $\pi^{\text {sch }}: \operatorname{Spec}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ and let $x_{C^{\sharp}}: \operatorname{Spec}\left(C^{\sharp}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(S)$ be the geometric point corresponding to $R \rightarrow C^{\sharp}$. Since $[\operatorname{Spec}(S) / \Gamma] \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is a coarse moduli space (see [Con05, Theorem 3.1]), $\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}\left(x_{C^{\sharp}}\right)\right)$ is the $\Gamma$-orbit of $x_{C^{\sharp}}$. Thus, for every $y \in \pi^{-1}(\pi(x))$, we have $y_{C^{\sharp}}=\gamma \cdot x_{C^{\sharp}}$ for some $\gamma \in \Gamma$, and $y=\gamma \cdot x$ in $\pi^{-1}(\pi(x))$ for such $\gamma$.

The condition in this example can be slightly relaxed in the following way. A merit of using the following condition is the compatibility with base change.
Lemma 3.12. Let $R$ be a ring and let $S$ be an $R$-algebra with a group action of a finite group $\Gamma$ over $R$. The following conditions are equivalent.
(1) For every $R$-algebra $A$ and every element $a \in A \otimes_{R} S, \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ lies in the image of $A \rightarrow A \otimes_{R} S$.
(2) For every element $a \in S[T], \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ lies in the image of $R[T] \rightarrow S[T]$.

Moreover, this condition is satisfied if $R=S^{\Gamma}$.
Proof. We show $(2) \Rightarrow(1)$. Let $A$ be an arbitrary $R$-algebra and let $a \in A \otimes_{R} S$. We may write $a=\sum_{1 \leq i \leq n} a_{i} \otimes s_{i}$ with $a_{i} \in A$ and $s_{i} \in S$. Then, $a$ is equal to the image of $\sum_{1 \leq i \leq n} T_{i} \otimes s_{i}$ through $S\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{n}\right] \rightarrow A \otimes_{R} S$ sending $T_{i}$ to $a_{i}$. Thus, we may assume that $A=R\left[T_{1}, \ldots T_{n}\right]$ and $a=\sum_{1 \leq i \leq n} T_{i} \otimes s_{i}$. We like to show that every coefficient of $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ lies in the image of $R \rightarrow S$. Take a positive integer $N>\# \Gamma$ and let $a^{\prime} \in S[T]$ be the image of $a$ through $S\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{n}\right] \rightarrow S[T]$ sending $T_{i}$ to $T^{N^{\prime}}$. Then, every coefficient of $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ lies in the image of $R \rightarrow S$ if and only if every coefficient of $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a^{\prime}$ lies in the image of $R \rightarrow S$. The latter follows from the assumption (2).

Since every coefficient of $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ is stable under the action of $\Gamma$ for every $a \in S[T]$, the condition (2) is satisfied when $R=S^{\Gamma}$.

As we show in the following, the condition in Lemma 3.12 is transitive and stable under restricting to subalgebras.
Lemma 3.13. Let $R \rightarrow M \rightarrow S$ be a homomorphism of rings and let $\Gamma$ be a finite group acting on $S$ over $R$. Let $H \subset \Gamma$ be a normal subgroup such that $H$ acts on $S$ over $M$ and there is an action of $\Gamma / H$ on $M$ over $R$ that is compatible with the action of $\Gamma$ on $S$. If the action of $\Gamma / H$ on $M$ over $R$ and the action of $H$ on $S$ over $M$ satisfy the condition in Lemma 3.12, the action of $\Gamma$ on $S$ over $R$ satisfies that condition.
Proof. It is enough to check the condition (2) in Lemma 3.12. Let $a \in S[T]$. Since the action of $H$ on $S$ over $M$ satisfies that condition, $\prod_{\gamma \in H} \gamma \cdot a$ is in the image of $M[T] \rightarrow S[T]$. Take an element $b \in M[T]$ mapping to $\prod_{\gamma \in H} \gamma \cdot a$ in $S[T]$. Then, $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ is the image of $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma / H} \gamma \cdot b$ in $S[T]$, so it lies in the image of $R[T] \rightarrow S[T]$ since the action of $\Gamma / H$ on $M$ over $R$ satisfies the condition (2) in Lemma 3.12.
Lemma 3.14. Let $f: R \rightarrow S$ be a homomorphism of rings and let $\Gamma$ be a finite group acting on $S$ over $R$. Let $S^{\prime} \subset S$ be a subring stable under $\Gamma$ and let $R^{\prime}=f^{-1}\left(S^{\prime}\right)$. If the action of $\Gamma$ on $S$ over $R$ satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12, the action of $\Gamma$ on $S^{\prime}$ over $R^{\prime}$ also satisfies that condition.
Proof. For every element $a \in S^{\prime}[T], \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a$ lies in the intersection of the image of $R[T] \rightarrow$ $S[T]$ with $S^{\prime}[T]$. That intersection is equal to the image of $R^{\prime}[T] \rightarrow S^{\prime}[T]$ as $R^{\prime}=f^{-1}\left(S^{\prime}\right)$.

Proposition 3.15. Let $R$ be an adic ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$. Let $S$ be an I-adic R-algebra with an action of a finite group $\Gamma$ over $R$. If $R \rightarrow S$ is injective and satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12, $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma$.

Proof. By the condition in Lemma 3.12, for every element $a \in S, \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma}(T-\gamma \cdot a)$ is a polynomial with coefficients in $R$. Thus, $S$ is integral over $R$ and $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective by Lemma 3.3. Let $\pi^{\text {sch }}: \operatorname{Spec}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$. As in the proof of Proposition 3.11, it suffices to show that for every geometric point $x: \operatorname{Spec}(C) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(S)$ with $C$ an algebraically closed field, $\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}(x)\right)$ is equal to the $\Gamma$-orbit of $x$. Let $S_{C}=S \otimes_{R, \pi^{\text {sch }}(x)} \cdot C$. Since $R \rightarrow S$ is injective, $\pi^{\text {sch }}$ is surjective and $S_{C} \neq 0$. By the condition in Lemma 3.12, for every $a \in S_{C}$, we have $\prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma} \gamma \cdot a \in C$. Then, we see that $\operatorname{Spec}\left(S_{C}\right)^{\Gamma} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(C)$ is bijective. Moreover, $C \rightarrow\left(S_{C}\right)^{\Gamma}$ is integral and $C$ is algebraically closed, so the reduction of $\left(S_{C}\right)^{\Gamma}$ is isomorphic to $C$. Since $\left[\operatorname{Spec}\left(S_{C}\right) / \Gamma\right] \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(S_{C}\right)^{\Gamma}$ is a coarse moduli space, $\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}\right)^{-1}\left(\pi^{\text {sch }}(x)\right)$ is equal to the $\Gamma$-orbit of $x$.

A typical way of constructing a geometric quotient by a profinite group is as follows.
Proposition 3.16. Let $\left\{\Gamma_{i}\right\}_{i \geq 0}$ be a sequence of groups with surjective transition maps $\Gamma_{i+1} \nrightarrow \Gamma_{i}$ such that $\Gamma_{0}=\{1\}$. Let $\left\{X_{i}\right\}_{i \geq 0}$ be a sequence of $v$-sheaves with transition maps $X_{i+1} \rightarrow X_{i}$ such that each $X_{i}$ is equipped with a $\Gamma_{i}$-action compatible with transition maps. Let $\Gamma_{\infty}=\lim _{i \geq 0} \Gamma_{i}$ and let $X_{\infty}=\lim _{i \geq 0} X_{i}$. Let $\Gamma_{i+1}^{i}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\Gamma_{i+1} \nrightarrow \Gamma_{i}\right)$. If $X_{i+1} \rightarrow X_{i}$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{i+1}^{i}$ for every $i \geq 0$, then $X_{\infty} \rightarrow X_{0}$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{\infty}$.

Proof. Let $\pi_{\infty}: X_{\infty} \rightarrow X_{0}$. Since the $v$-site Perf is replete (by the same proof as in [Heu21, Lemma 2.6]) and each transition map is surjective, $\pi_{\infty}$ is surjective. Let $C$ be an algebraically closed perfectoid field with an open and bounded valuation subring $C^{+} \subset C$. Let $x \in$ $X_{\infty}\left(C, C^{+}\right)$and let $y \in \pi_{\infty}^{-1}\left(\pi_{\infty}(x)\right)$. Let $\pi_{\infty}^{i}: X_{\infty} \rightarrow X_{i}$. We construct a convergent sequence $\left\{\gamma_{i}\right\}_{i \geq 0}$ of $\Gamma$ so that $\pi_{\infty}^{i}\left(\gamma_{j} \cdot y\right)=\pi_{\infty}^{i}(x)$ for every $i \leq j$. We do this by induction. If $i=0$, we can take $\gamma_{0}=1$. Suppose that we construct the $i$-th term $\gamma_{i}$. Then, $\pi_{\infty}^{i+1}\left(\gamma_{i} \cdot y\right)$ is an element of $X_{i+1}\left(C, C^{+}\right)$which maps to $\pi_{\infty}^{i}(x)$ through the transition map $X_{i+1} \rightarrow X_{i}$. Thus, there is an element $\delta \in \Gamma_{i+1}^{i}$ such that $\delta \cdot \pi_{\infty}^{i+1}\left(\gamma_{i} \cdot y\right)=\pi_{\infty}^{i+1}(x)$. We can take $\gamma_{i+1}$ to be the product of a lift of $\delta$ and $\gamma_{i}$. If we let $\gamma=\lim \gamma_{i} \in \Gamma$, we have $\gamma \cdot y=x$.

Another way to construct geometric quotients is to pass to closed subsheaves.
Lemma 3.17. Let $\pi: X \rightarrow Y$ be a proper map of small $v$-sheaves that is a geometric quotient by a group $\Gamma$. Let $Z \subset X$ be a $\Gamma$-stable closed subsheaf and let $Z_{Y} \subset Y$ be the image of $Z$ under $\pi$. Then, we have $Z \cong X \times_{Y} Z_{Y}$ and $Z \rightarrow Z_{Y}$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma$.

Proof. Since $\pi$ is proper, $Z_{Y} \subset Y$ is a closed subsheaf. For every geometric point $y$ of $X \times_{Y} Z_{Y}$, there is a geometric point $x$ of $Z$ such that $\pi(x)=\pi(y)$. Since $\pi$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma$, there is some $\gamma \in \Gamma$ such that $y=\gamma \cdot x$. Since $Z$ is stable under $\Gamma, y$

is a geometric point of $Z$. Thus, we have $Z=X \times_{Y} Z_{Y}$ as closed subsheaves of $X$. By Lemma 3.9, $Z \rightarrow Z_{Y}$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma$.

# 4. PERFECTOID FORMAL SCHEMES 

The notion of $p$-adic perfectoid formal schemes is introduced in [RC21]. It is constructed from formal spectra of perfectoid rings introduced in [BMS18]. Here, we introduce not necessarily $p$-adic perfectoid formal schemes and establish some basic properties.
4.1. $F$-standard ideals. In this section, we recall $F$-standard ideals introduced in [Tak25, Section 2.1] and explain the basic properties.

An ideal $I$ of a perfect ring $A$ is $F$-standard if $I^{p}=\operatorname{Frob}(I)$. An $F$-standard ideal $I \subset A$ defines an ideal $[I] \subset W(A)$ consisting of elements $\sum_{n \geq 0}\left[a_{n}\right] p^{n}$ with $a_{n} \in I$. For $n=m / p^{k} \in \mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]_{\geq 0}$ with $m, k \geq 0$, we set $I^{n}=\operatorname{Frob}\left(I^{m}\right)^{-k}$. This is independent of the choice of $m$ and $k$ since $I$ is $F$-standard, and $I^{n}$ is also $F$-standard.

When a perfect ring $A$ is equipped with a linear topology of a finitely generated ideal, we say that $A$ is an adic perfect ring. By [Tak25, Lemma 2.5], every adic perfect ring admits an $F$-standard ideal of definition. Note that such an ideal of definition is not necessarily finitely generated.

Lemma 4.1. Let $A$ be a perfect ring and let $I \subset A$ be an $F$-standard ideal. The ideal $[I] \subset W(A)$ is $p$-adically closed and $W(A) /[I]$ is $p$-torsion free and $p$-adically complete.
Proof. Since $[I] \cap\left(p^{n}\right)=p^{n}[I]$ and $[I]$ is $p$-adically complete, we see that $[I] \subset W(A)$ is a closed ideal and $W(A) /[I]$ is $p$-adically complete. Moreover, $W(A) /[I]$ is $p$-torsion free as $[I] \cap(p)=p[I]$.

Lemma 4.2. Let $A$ be a perfect ring. For $F$-standard ideals $I, J \subset A$, the ideals $I \cap J, I J$ are $F$-standard. Moreover, $[I \cap J]=[I] \cap[J]$ and $[I J]$ is the $p$-adic closure of $[I][J]$ in $W(A)$.
Proof. Since we have $\operatorname{Frob}(I \cap J) \subset(I \cap J)^{p} \subset I^{p} \cap J^{p}=\operatorname{Frob}(I) \cap \operatorname{Frob}(J), I \cap J$ is $F$ standard. By definition, we have $[I \cap J]=[I] \cap[J]$. On the other hand, since $(I J)^{p}=$ $I^{p} J^{p}=\operatorname{Frob}(I) \operatorname{Frob}(J)=\operatorname{Frob}(I J), I J$ is $F$-standard. Next, we show $[I][J] \subset[I J]$. Let $a=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left[a_{n}\right] p^{n} \in I$ and $b=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left[b_{n}\right] p^{n} \in J$. Then, $a b=\sum_{n, m=0}^{\infty}\left[a_{n} b_{m}\right] p^{n+m}$, so $a b \in[I J]$ as $a_{n} b_{m} \in I J$. To prove the claim, it is enough to show that $[I J]=[I][J]+p[I J]$ since $[I J] \subset W(A)$ is closed. Let $x=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left[a_{n}\right] p^{n}$ be an element of $[I J]$. Then, $a_{0} \in I J$, so we may write $a_{0}=\sum_{1 \leq i \leq m} b_{i} c_{i}$ with $b_{i} \in I$ and $c_{i} \in J$ for each $1 \leq i \leq m$. Then, $x-\sum_{1 \leq i \leq m}\left[b_{m}\right]\left[c_{m}\right] \in$ $[I J] \cap(p)=p[I J]$, so we obtain $x \in[I][J]+p[I J]$.

From this lemma, we have $\left(p^{n},[I]^{m}\right)=\left(p^{n},\left[I^{m}\right]\right)$ for every $n, m \geq 0$.

Lemma 4.3. Let $A$ be a perfect ring and let $I \subset A$ be an $F$-standard ideal. Let $A^{\wedge}$ be the $I$-adic completion of $A$. The $(p,[I])$-adic completion of $W(A)$ is isomorphic to $W\left(A^{\wedge}\right)$. In particular, $W(A)$ is $(p,[I])$-adically complete if $A$ is $I$-adically complete.
Proof. It is enough to show that the $[I]$-adic completion of $W_{n}(A)$ is isomorphic to $W_{n}\left(A^{\wedge}\right)$ for every $n \geq 0$. For every $m \geq 0$, there are natural maps $W_{n}\left(A / I^{p^{m}} m\right) \rightarrow W_{n}(A) /\left[I^{m}\right] \rightarrow$ $W_{n}\left(A / I^{m}\right)$ since we have $\sum\left[a_{n}\right] p^{n}=\left(a_{0}, a_{1}^{p}, a_{2}^{p^{2}}, \ldots\right)$ in $W(A)$. Thus, $\left\{W_{n}\left(A / I^{m}\right)\right\}_{m \geq 0}$ and $\left\{W_{n}(A) /\left[I^{m}\right]\right\}_{m \geq 0}$ are isomorphic as pro-systems. Thus, we have $\lim _{m \geq 0} W_{n}(A) /[I]^{m}=$ $\lim _{m \geq 0} W_{n}\left(A / I^{m}\right)=W_{n}\left(A^{\wedge}\right)$.
4.2. Adic perfectoid rings. In this section, we introduce affine building blocks of perfectoid formal schemes, which we call complete adic perfectoid rings. This notion is equivalent to perfectoid rings in the sense of Gabber-Romero (see [GR18, Definition 16.3.1]), but we use another term in order to clarify the terminology.

Definition 4.4. An adic ring $R$ on which $p$ is topologically nilpotent is said to be an adic perfectoid ring if the underlying $p$-adic ring $R$ is a perfectoid ring. Moreover, if $R$ is a complete adic ring, we say that $R$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring.

When we simply say that $R$ is a perfectoid ring, $R$ is endowed with the $p$-adic topology. We will consider tilting from adic perfectoid rings to adic perfect rings. For a perfectoid ring $R$ and $f \in R^{\flat}$, the image of the Teichmüller lift $[f] \in W\left(R^{\natural}\right)$ in $R$ is denoted by $f^{\sharp}$. The map $W\left(R^{\natural}\right) \rightarrow R$ is denoted by $\theta_{R}$ and a generator of $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{R}\right)$ is denoted by $\xi_{R}$.
