The image of $\xi_{R}$ along $W\left(R^{\natural}\right) \rightarrow R^{\natural}$ is denoted by $\xi_{R, 0}$.
Lemma 4.5. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring. There is an ideal of definition of $R$ generated by $p$ and $f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{n}^{\sharp}$ for some $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in R^{\natural}$. Moreover, the adic topology on $R^{\natural}$ generated by $\xi_{R, 0}, f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$ is independent of the choice of $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$.
Proof. Let $I$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition of $R$ such that $p \in I$. Since the image of the map $f \mapsto f^{\sharp}$ is $p$-adically dense in $R$, we can take a set of generators of $I$ consisting of $p$ and $f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{n}^{\sharp}$. It is enough to show that the adic topology on $R^{\natural}$ generated by $\xi_{R, 0}, f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$ is independent of the choice of $I$ and $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$.

Let $I^{\natural}=\left(\xi_{R, 0}, f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right)$. The ideal $I^{\natural}$ is independent of the choice of $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}$ since $I^{\natural}$ is the inverse image of the ideal $I / p R$ along $R^{\natural} \rightarrow R^{\natural} / \xi_{R, 0} R^{\natural} \cong R / p R$. From this description, we see that $J^{\natural} \subset I^{\natural}$ for any finitely generated ideal of definition $J$ of $R$ such that $p \in J \subset I$. Let $J$ be another finitely generated ideal of definition of $R$ such that $p \in J$. For sufficiently large $N \geq 0$, we have $(p)+J^{N} \subset I$ and $(p)+I^{N} \subset J$, so it implies that $\left(\xi_{R, 0}\right)+J^{\natural, N} \subset I^{\natural}$ and $\left(\xi_{R, 0}\right)+I^{\natural, N} \subset J^{\natural}$. Thus, the two adic topologies on $R^{\natural}$ given by $I^{\natural}$ and $J^{\natural}$ are equal.

Let $I$ be an ideal of $R$ such that $p \in I$. As in the above proof, the inverse image of the ideal $I / p R$ along $R^{\natural} \rightarrow R^{\natural} / \xi_{R, 0} R^{\natural} \cong R / p R$ is denoted by $I^{\natural}$. Note that since $\xi_{R}$ is distinguished,

$p$ and $\xi_{R, 0}^{\sharp}$ generate the same ideal in $R$, so $I$ is generated by $\xi_{R, 0}^{\sharp}, f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{n}^{\sharp}$. For an ideal $J \subset R^{b}$, the ideal of $R$ generated by $f^{\sharp}$ for all $f \in J$ is denoted by $J^{\sharp}$. The above argument shows that for an ideal $p \in I \subset R$, we have $I=\left(I^{\natural}\right)^{\sharp}$.

Definition 4.6. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring and let $I$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition of $R$ such that $p \in I$. The adic perfect ring $R^{b}$ with the $I^{\natural}$-adic topology is said to be the tilting of $R$, which is independent of the choice of $I$.

Lemma 4.7. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring and let $J \subset R^{b}$ be an open $F$-standard ideal. The ideal $J^{\sharp}$ is equal to the image of $[J] \subset W\left(R^{b}\right)$ under $\theta_{R}$.

Proof. Since $J$ is open, $\xi_{R, 0}^{n} \in J$ for some $n \geq 0$, so we have $p^{n} \in J^{\sharp}$ since $\xi_{R}$ is distinguished. Then, the claim follows from the fact that $[J] \subset W\left(R^{b}\right)$ is the $p$-adic closure of the ideal generated by $[f]$ for all $f \in J$.

We will prove that the completeness of adic perfectoid rings is preserved under tilting.
Lemma 4.8. Let $A$ be a perfect ring and let $\xi \in W(A)$ be a distinguished element. Let $\xi_{0}$ be the image of $\xi$ along $W(A) \rightarrow A$ and let $I \subset A$ be an $F$-standard ideal such that $\xi_{0} \in I$. If we endow $W(A)$ with the $(p,[I])$-adic topology, the map $W(A) \rightarrow W(A)$ given by the multiplication by $\xi$ is a homeomorphism onto the image.

Proof. It is easy to see that the multiplication by $\xi$ is continuous. We show that it is a homeomorphism onto its image.

Let $n \geq 1$ be an integer. We show that if $x \in W(A)$ satisfies $\xi x \in\left(p^{n},\left[I^{n}\right]\right)$, we have $x \in\left(p^{s},\left[I^{t}\right]\right)$ for every $s, t \geq 0$ with $s+t<n$. Suppose that $x$ is not contained in $\left(p^{s},\left[I^{t}\right]\right)$ and let $x=\sum_{m \geq 0}\left[a_{m}\right] p^{m}$. Then, there exists $0 \leq k<s$ such that $a_{k} \notin I^{t}$. Take the minimal $k$ such that $a_{k} \notin I^{t}$. Then, we are in the situation $(*)$ that $a_{0}, \ldots, a_{k-1} \in I^{\ell}$ and $a_{k} \notin I^{\ell}$, but $\xi x \in\left(p^{k+2},\left[I^{\ell}\right]\right)$ for $k \leq s-1 \leq n-2$ and $\ell=t \geq 0$.

Suppose that we are in the above situation for some $k$ and $\ell \geq 1$. We may suppose that $a_{k} \in I^{\ell-1}$. Let $\xi=\sum_{m \geq 0}\left[\xi_{m}\right] p^{m}$. Since $\xi$ is distinguished, $\xi_{1}$ is a unit and we may assume that $\xi_{1}=1$. Then, $\xi x$ is congruent to $\sum_{m_{1}+m_{2} \leq k+1}\left[a_{m_{1}} \xi_{m_{2}}\right] p^{m_{1}+m_{2}}$ modulo $p^{k+2}$. It lies in $\left(p^{k+2},\left[I^{\ell}\right]\right)$, so we have $\left[\xi_{0} a_{k}\right] p^{k}+\left(\left[\xi_{0} a_{k+1}\right]+\left[a_{k}\right]\right) p^{k+1} \in\left(p^{k+2},\left[I^{\ell}\right]\right)$. Then, we have $\xi_{0} a_{k}, \xi_{0} a_{k+1}+a_{k} \in I^{\ell}$. Since $\xi_{0} \in I$ and $a_{k} \notin I^{\ell}$, we have $a_{k+1} \notin I^{\ell-1}$. Thus, if $k+1 \leq n-2$, the hypothesis $(*)$ holds for $k+1$ and $\ell-1$.

If we continue this procedure until $\ell=0$, we see that the hypothesis $(*)$ holds for some $k \leq s+t-1 \leq n-2$ and $\ell=0$. This is a contradiction because $a_{k} \in A=I^{0}$. Thus, we see that $x \in\left(p^{s},\left[I^{t}\right]\right)$ and we obtain the claim.

Proposition 4.9. Let $R$ be a perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be an ideal such that $p \in I$ and $I^{\natural} \subset R^{b}$ is $F$-standard. Then, $W\left(R^{b}\right)$ is $\left(p,\left[I^{\natural}\right]\right)$-adically complete if and only if $R$ is I-adically complete.

Proof. First, suppose that $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is $\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)$-adically complete. By Lemma 4.8, $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{R}\right)$ is a closed ideal, so the quotient $R=W\left(R^{s}\right) / \operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{R}\right)$ is complete with respect to the quotient topology. The claim follows since $I$ is the image of $\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)$ along $\theta_{R}$.

Next, suppose that $R$ is $I$-adically complete. First, we show that $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is separated. Suppose that we have $a \in \bigcap_{n \geq 0}\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right)$. Then, $\theta_{R}(a) \in \bigcap_{n \geq 0} I^{n}$, so $\theta_{R}(a)=0$. If we write $a=\xi a^{\prime}$, then we also have $a^{\prime} \in \bigcap_{n \geq 0}\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right)$ by Lemma 4.8. Thus, we have $\bigcap_{n \geq 0}\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right) \subset \xi^{m} W\left(R^{s}\right)$ for every $m \geq 0$. Since $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is $\xi$-adically complete by Lemma 4.3, we have $\bigcap_{n \geq 0}\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right)=0$. Next, we show that $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is complete. Let $\left(a_{n}\right)_{n \geq 0}$ be a sequence in $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ such that $a_{n+1}-a_{n} \in\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right)$. Since $R$ is $I$-adically complete, $\left(\theta_{R}\left(a_{n}\right)\right)$ converges to an element $\bar{b} \in R$. Let $b$ be a lift of $\bar{b}$ in $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ and let $a_{n}^{\prime}=a_{n}-b$. Then, $\theta_{R}\left(a_{n}^{\prime}\right) \in\left(p^{n},\left(I^{s, n}\right)^{\sharp}\right)$, so by replacing $a_{n}$ with an element of $a_{n}+\left(p^{n},\left[I^{s, n}\right]\right)$, we may assume that $a_{n}^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{R}\right)$. By Lemma 4.8, the sequence $\left(a_{n}^{\prime} / \xi\right)$ is convergent, so we may repeat this procedure to $\left(a_{n}^{\prime} / \xi\right)$. After all, we see that there is a sequence $\left(b_{m}\right)_{m \geq 0}$ such that for every $k \geq 0, a_{n}-\sum_{0 \leq m<k} b_{m} \xi^{m}$ modulo $\xi^{k}$ is convergent to 0 in $W\left(R^{s}\right) /\left(\xi^{k}\right)$. Since $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is $\xi$-adically complete, $\sum_{m \geq 0} b_{m} \xi^{m}$ is a limit of $\left(a_{n}\right)$.

Corollary 4.10. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring. Then, $R$ is complete if and only if $R^{s}$ is complete.

Proof. Let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition such that $p \in I$. By Proposition 4.9, $R$ is complete if and only if $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is $\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)$-adically complete, and $R^{s}$ is complete if and only if $W\left(R^{s}\right)$ is $\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)$-adically complete. Thus, the claim follows.

Corollary 4.11. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition such that $p \in I$. The $I$-adic completion $R^{\wedge}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring. Its tilt $R^{\wedge, \text {,s }}$ is isomorphic to the $I^{s}$-adic completion of $R^{s}$.

Proof. Let $J_{n}=\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)^{n} \cap\left(\xi_{R}\right)$. The short exact sequence $0 \rightarrow\left(\xi_{R}\right) \rightarrow W\left(R^{s}\right) \rightarrow R \rightarrow 0$ gives rise to a short exact sequence $0 \rightarrow\left(\xi_{R}\right) / J_{n} \rightarrow W\left(R^{s}\right) /\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)^{n} \rightarrow R / I^{n} \rightarrow 0$. By Lemma 4.8, the limit of $\left(\xi_{R}\right) / J_{n}$ is isomorphic to the $\left(p,\left[I^{s}\right]\right)$-adic completion of $\left(\xi_{R}\right)$. Let $R^{s, \wedge}$ be the $I^{s}$-adic completion of $R^{s}$. By taking the limit of the above sequences, we obtain a short exact sequence $0 \rightarrow \xi_{R} \cdot W\left(R^{s, \wedge}\right) \rightarrow W\left(R^{s, \wedge}\right) \rightarrow R^{\wedge} \rightarrow 0$ by Lemma 4.3. As $\xi_{R}$ is distinguished, we see that $R^{\wedge}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring with tilt $R^{s, \wedge}$.

The tilting equivalence holds in our setting as well. For an adic perfectoid ring $R$, an adic (resp. complete adic) perfectoid $R$-algebra refers to an adic (resp. complete adic) perfectoid ring $S$ with a continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow S$.

Proposition 4.12. Let $R$ be an adic perfectoid ring. The category of adic (resp. complete adic) perfectoid $R$-algebras is equivalent to the category of adic (resp. complete adic) perfect $R^{s}$-algebras.

Proof. Let $R$ and $S$ be adic perfectoid rings. By the tilting equivalence of perfectoid rings (see [BS22, Theorem 3.10]), it is enough to show that a homomorphism $f: R \rightarrow S$ is continuous if and only if $f^{s}: R^{s} \rightarrow S^{s}$ is continuous. Since $R$ and $S$ are $p$-adic, $f$ is continuous if and only if $f / p: R / p R \rightarrow S / p S$ is continuous. Since $R^{b}$ and $S^{b}$ is $\xi_{R, 0}$-adic, $f^{b}$ is continuous if and only if $f / \xi_{R, 0}: R^{b} / \xi_{R, 0} R^{b} \rightarrow S^{b} / \xi_{R, 0} S^{b}$ is continuous. Thus, the claim follows from the isomorphism $R / p R \cong R^{b} / \xi_{R, 0} R^{b}$.

For a continuous homomorphism $f: R \rightarrow S$ of adic perfectoid rings, the homomorphism $R^{b} \rightarrow S^{b}$ between the tiltings is denoted by $f^{b}$.
Lemma 4.13. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$ and let $S$ be an I-adically complete I-completely étale $R$-algebra. Then, $S$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring.
Proof. We may assume that $I^{b}$ is $F$-standard. By the topological invariance of étale sites, there is a unique étale $W\left(R^{b}\right) /\left(p^{n},\left[I^{b}\right]^{n}\right)$-algebra $S_{n}^{\prime}$ such that $S_{n}^{\prime} \otimes_{W\left(R^{b}\right) /\left(p^{n},\left[I^{b}\right]^{n}\right)}(R / I) \cong$ $S / I S$ for every $n \geq 0$. Then, $S_{\infty}^{\prime}=\lim _{n \geq 0} S_{n}^{\prime}$ is $\left(p,\left[I^{b}\right]\right)$-completely étale over $W\left(R^{b}\right)$ and we have $S \cong S_{\infty}^{\prime} / \xi_{R} S_{\infty}^{\prime}$. By [BS22, Lemma 2.18], $S_{\infty}^{\prime}$ is equipped with the unique $\delta$-structure compatible with that of $W\left(R^{b}\right)$. Now, the Frobenius on $S_{\infty}^{\prime}$ induces a homomorphism $S_{\infty}^{\prime} /\left(p^{n},\left[I^{b, 1 / p}\right]^{n}\right) \rightarrow S_{n}^{\prime}$ after the base change to $W\left(R^{b}\right) /\left(p^{n},\left[I^{b}\right]^{n}\right)$. It induces a universally homeomorphic étale morphism, so it is an isomorphism. Thus, the Frobenius on $S_{\infty}^{\prime}$ is an isomorphism, so $S \cong S_{\infty}^{\prime} / \xi_{R} S_{\infty}^{\prime}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring.
4.3. Continuous arc-topology. In this section, we introduce continuous arc-topology on complete adic perfectoid rings and establish continuous arc-descent following [BM21], [BS22, Section 8.2] and [Ito22].
Definition 4.14. An adic homomorphism $R \rightarrow S$ of complete adic perfectoid rings is a continuous arc-cover if for every continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow V$ to a valuation ring of rank 1 , there is an extension $V \rightarrow W$ of valuation rings of rank 1 and a continuous homomorphism $S \rightarrow W$ lifting the composition $R \rightarrow V \rightarrow W$.

As in [BS22, Remark 8.9], a continuous arc-cover can be constructed as a product of valuation rings of rank 1 as follows.
Example 4.15. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition. Let $X_{R}$ be a set of representatives of rank 1 continuous valuations on $R$ and let $S=\prod_{x \in X_{R}} V_{x}$ be the product of $V_{x}$ with the $I$-adic topology. We can take each $V_{x}$ so that $V_{x}$ is $p$-complete and $\operatorname{Frac}\left(V_{x}\right)$ is algebraically closed. Then, $S$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring and $R \rightarrow S$ is a continuous arc-cover.

As usual, the continuous arc-site satisfies tilting equivalence.
Lemma 4.16. Let $f: R \rightarrow S$ be a continuous homomorphism of complete adic perfectoid rings. Then, $f$ is a continuous arc-cover if and only if $f^{b}$ is a continuous arc-cover.

Proof. Note that a $p$-adically complete valuation ring $V$ with an algebraically closed fraction field is perfectoid and $V^{b}$ is a perfect valuation ring with an algebraically closed fraction field. By Proposition 4.12, we see that for every continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow V$, the existence of a lift $S \rightarrow W$ to an extension $V \rightarrow W$ is equivalent to the existence of a lift $S^{b} \rightarrow W^{b}$ to an extension $V^{b} \rightarrow W^{b}$. As in Proposition 4.12, $f$ is adic if and only if $f^{b}$ is adic.

The argument of [Ito22] for $\varpi$-complete arc-hyperdescent works in our setting as well. As in [Ito22, Definition 2.1], hyperdescent for the continuous arc-topology is referred to as continuous arc-hyperdescent.

Proposition 4.17. The functors

$$
R \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}\left(R^{b}\right), \quad R \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}\left(W\left(R^{b}\right)\right), \quad R \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}(R)
$$

from the category of complete adic perfectoid rings to the $\infty$-category of small $\infty$-categories satisfy continuous arc-hyperdescent.

Proof. As in the proof of [Ito22, Theorem 3.1], it is enough to show that the bounded analogues of the given functors (where Perf is replaced by $\operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}$ for some $a \leq b$ ) satisfy arc-descent.

Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition such that $p \in I$ and let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in I^{b}$ be a finite set of generators. Let $R \rightarrow S$ be a continuous arc-cover of complete adic perfectoid rings and let $R \rightarrow S^{\bullet}$ be the Čech nerve of the continuous arc-cover.

First, we show the continuous arc-descent along $R \rightarrow S^{\bullet}$ of the functor $S^{\bullet} \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}\left(S^{\bullet, b}\right)$. By [Ito22, Proposition 2.9 (2)], it is enough to show that the arc-descent holds for the functor $S^{\bullet} \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}\left(S^{\bullet, b} /{ }^{b}\left(f_{1}^{n}, f_{2}^{n}, \ldots, f_{r}^{n}\right)\right)$ for every $n \geq 0$. Since $R^{b} \rightarrow S^{b}$ is a continuous arcoover by Lemma $4.16, R^{b} \rightarrow S^{b} \times R^{b}\left[\frac{1}{f_{1}}\right] \times \cdots \times R^{b}\left[\frac{1}{f_{r}}\right]$ is an arc-cover of perfect rings. Thus, the claim follows from [Ito22, Theorem 3.1].

The continuous arc-descent of the functor $S^{\bullet} \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}\left(W\left(S^{\bullet, b}\right)\right)$ follows from the same argument as in [Ito22, Section 4.1]. Moreover, the continuous arc-descent of the functor $S^{\bullet} \mapsto$ $\operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}\left(S^{\bullet} /{ }^{b}\left(f_{1}^{2, n}, \ldots, f_{r}^{2, n}\right)\right)$ also follows from the same argument for every $n \geq 0$. Thus, the continuous arc-descent of the functor $S^{\bullet} \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}_{[a, b]}\left(S^{\bullet}\right)$ follows from [Ito22, Proposition 2.9 $(2)]$.

The following corollary follows formally from the continuous arc-descent of $R \mapsto \operatorname{Perf}(R)$ by looking at the space of endomorphisms of $R \in \operatorname{Perf}(R)$.

Corollary 4.18. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset$ $R$. Let $R \rightarrow S$ be a continuous arc-cover of complete adic perfectoid rings. The complex $0 \rightarrow R \rightarrow S \rightarrow S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S \rightarrow \cdots$ is acyclic. Here, $\widehat{\otimes}_{R}$ denotes the I-adically completed tensor product.

However, this descent is sometimes insufficient as it ignores the descent of topologies. We will show that the above descent holds as topological rings.

Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition with $p \in I$. We regard $R$ as a Banach ring with a norm $|x|_{I}=p^{-n}$ with $n=\sup \left\{m \geq 0 \mid x \in I^{m}\right\}$ for $x \in R$. Then, we get the spectral seminorm $|x|_{I}^{\text {sp }}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left|x^{n}\right|_{I}^{1 / n}$.

Let $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$ be the set of bounded multiplicative norms on $R$. Then, $|\cdot|_{I}^{\text {sp }}$ is equal to the supremum over $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$ (see e.g. [Ked19, Lemma 1.5.22]). First, we compare $|\cdot|_{I}$ with $|\cdot|_{I}^{\text {sp }}$.
Proposition 4.19. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition with $p \in I$. The topology defined by $|\cdot|_{\text {I }}^{\text {sp }}$ equals the $I$-adic topology on $R$.
Proof. First, suppose that $R$ is in characteristic $p$. Let $J$ be the minimum $F$-standard ideal containing $I$. Since $|x|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left|x^{p^{n}}\right|_{I}^{p^{-n}}$ and $J=\bigcup_{n \geq 0} \operatorname{Frob}^{-n}\left(I^{p^{n}}\right)$, we see that for every $m \geq 1, x \in J^{m}$ implies $|x|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \leq p^{-m}$, and $|x|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \leq p^{-m-1}$ implies $x \in J^{m}$. Thus, the topology defined by $|\cdot|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }}$ is equal to the $J$-adic topology on $R$. Thus, the claim follows from [Tak25, Lemma 2.5].

Next, let $R$ be an arbitrary complete adic perfectoid ring. It is obvious that the $I$-adic topology is finer than or equal to the topology defined by $|\cdot|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }}$. We show the converse direction. Let $m \geq 1$ and let $J_{m} \subset R$ be the ideal consisting of elements $x \in R$ with $|x|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \leq p^{-m}$. Since $p^{m} \in J_{m}$ and the set of elements $f^{\sharp}$ with $f \in R^{\mathrm{s}}$ is $p$-adically dense in $R$, it is enough to determine the set of $f \in R^{\mathrm{s}}$ with $f^{\sharp} \in J_{m}$. Recall that $|\cdot|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }}$ is equal to the supremum over $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$. Each $x \in \mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$ corresponds to a continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow V_{x}$ to a $p$-complete valuation ring $V_{x}$ of rank 1 with an algebraically closed fraction field. Through the tilting equivalence, it corresponds to a continuous homomorphism $R^{\mathrm{s}} \rightarrow V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}$. Here, the norms on $V_{x}$ and $V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}$ correspond under the equation $|a|_{V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}}=|a^{\sharp}|_{V_{x}}$ for every $a \in V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}$. Since $I$ is generated by $\left(I^{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{\sharp}, R \rightarrow V_{x}$ is bounded if and only if for every $f \in I^{\mathrm{s}},|f^{\sharp}|_{V_{x}} \leq p^{-1}$. This is equivalent to $|f|_{V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}} \leq p^{-1}$, so $R \rightarrow V_{x}$ is bounded if and only if $R^{\mathrm{s}} \rightarrow V_{x}^{\mathrm{s}}$ is bounded. This means that the tilting equivalence induces $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R) \cong \mathcal{M}_{I^{s}}\left(R^{\mathrm{s}}\right)$ and for $f \in R^{\mathrm{s}}, f^{\sharp} \in J_{m}$ if and only if $|f|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \leq p^{-m}$. Let $J_{m}^{\mathrm{s}} \subset R^{\mathrm{s}}$ be the ideal consisting of elements $x \in R^{\mathrm{s}}$ with $|x|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \leq p^{-m}$. Since $|\cdot|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }}$ is power-multiplicative, $J_{m}^{\mathrm{s}}$ is $F$-standard. The above argument shows that $J_{m}=\left(p^{m},\left(J_{m}^{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{\sharp}\right)$ and the argument in characteristic $p$ shows that the linear topology given by $\left\{J_{m}^{\mathrm{s}}\right\}$ is equal to the $I^{s}$-adic topology. Thus, we see that the linear topology given by $\left\{J_{m}\right\}_{m \geq 0}$ is equal to the $\left(p,\left(I^{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{\sharp}\right)$-adic topology.
Corollary 4.20. Let $R \rightarrow S$ be a continuous arc-cover of complete adic perfectoid rings. The topology on $R$ equals the subspace topology induced by the topology on $S$.
Proof. Let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition with $p \in I$. Since $R \rightarrow S$ is adic, $I S \subset S$ is an ideal of definition. Since $I^{n} \subset(I S)^{n} \cap R$ for every $n \geq 0$, we have $|f|_{\mid}^{\text {sp }} \geq|f|_{\mid S}^{\text {sp }}$ for every $f \in R$. By Proposition 4.19, it is enough to prove the converse inequality. Each $x \in \mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$ corresponds to a continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow V_{x}$ to a $p$-complete valuation ring $V_{x}$ of

rank 1 with an algebraically closed fraction field. Since $R \rightarrow S$ is a continuous arc-cover, we may assume by replacing $V_{x}$ that it admits a lift $S \rightarrow V_{x}$. The map $S \rightarrow V_{x}$ is bounded with respect to $|\cdot|_{I S}$ if and only if $R \rightarrow V_{x}$ is bounded with respect to $|\cdot|_{I}$, so by taking the supremum over $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$, we have $|f|_{\text {I }}^{\text {sp }} \leq|f|_{\text {IS }}^{\text {sp }}$.

# 4.4. Perfectoid formal schemes. 

Definition 4.21. A perfectoid formal scheme is a formal scheme Zariski locally isomorphic to the formal spectrum of a complete adic perfectoid ring. A perfectoid formal scheme in characteristic $p$ is called a perfect formal scheme.

Proposition 4.22. A formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ is perfectoid if and only if every affine open formal subscheme of $\mathfrak{X}$ is the formal spectrum of a complete adic perfectoid ring.

Proof. It is enough to show that if $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $R$ a complete adic ring is perfectoid, then $R$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition such that $p \in I$. Since $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is perfectoid, $\operatorname{Spec}(R / I)$ is Zariski locally semiperfect, so $R / I$ is semiperfect. Let $R^{b}=\lim _{x \mapsto x^{p}}(R / I)$ and let $I^{b}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(R^{b} \rightarrow R / I\right)$. Then, $R^{b}$ is perfect and complete with respect to the linear topology given by $\left\{\operatorname{Frob}^{n}\left(I^{b}\right)\right\}_{n \geq 0}$.

The quotient $R^{b} / \operatorname{Frob}\left(I^{b}\right) \rightarrow R^{b} / I^{b}$ is isomorphic to the Frobenius map $R / I \rightarrow R / I$. For each affine open formal subscheme $\operatorname{Spf}(S) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $S$ a complete adic perfectoid ring, we have $S / I S \cong S^{b} /(I S)^{b}$ and the kernel of the Frobenius map on $S^{b} /(I S)^{b}$ is finitely generated since $(I S)^{b}$ is finitely generated. Thus, $\operatorname{Ker}(\operatorname{Frob}: R / I \rightarrow R / I)$ is Zariski locally finitely generated, so it is finitely generated. In particular, there is a finitely generated ideal $J \subset R^{b}$ such that $I^{b}=J+\operatorname{Frob}\left(I^{b}\right)$. By the completeness of $R^{b}$, we have $I^{b}=J$ and we see that $I^{b}$ is finitely generated. In particular, $R^{b}$ is $I^{b}$-adically complete.

Let $\operatorname{Spf}(S) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ be a distinguished open formal subscheme with $S$ a complete adic perfectoid ring. Note that we can take an open covering of $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ consisting of such $\operatorname{Spf}(S)$. Let us write $\operatorname{Spf}(S)=D_{f^{b}}(\operatorname{Spf}(R))$ with some $f \in R^{b}$. By construction, we have $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S^{b}\right)=D_{f}\left(\operatorname{Spf}\left(R^{b}\right)\right)$. In particular, we have $(I S)^{b}=I^{b} S^{b}$ and $S^{b}$ is a complete $I^{b}$-adic perfect ring. Take a Zariski finite covering $\coprod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} \operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with each $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{\lambda}\right)$ as above. Then, $R^{b} \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} S_{\lambda}^{b}$ is a continuous arc-cover of complete adic perfect rings. By Proposition 4.17, the homomorphism $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{S_{\lambda}}\right) \rightarrow W\left(S_{\lambda}^{b}\right)$ of invertible $W\left(S_{\lambda}^{b}\right)$-modules descends to a homomorphism $K \rightarrow W\left(R^{b}\right)$ with $K$ an invertible $W\left(R^{b}\right)$-module.

Now, we have a surjection $W\left(R^{b}\right) \rightarrow R$. The following diagram commutes for each $\lambda \in \Lambda$ by the functoriality of the construction.
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Now, $K \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} \operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{S_{\lambda}}\right)$ and $W\left(R^{b}\right) \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} W\left(S_{\lambda}^{b}\right)$ are injective by Proposition 4.17, and $R \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} S_{\lambda}$ is also injective by the sheaf condition. Moreover, the images of these maps can be described by gluing conditions. Thus, we see that $K$ maps isomorphically to $\operatorname{Ker}\left(W\left(R^{b}\right) \rightarrow R\right)$ in $W\left(R^{b}\right)$. It is enough to show that $K$ is generated by a distinguished element of $W\left(R^{b}\right)$.

We proceed as in [BS22, Lemma 3.6]. Let $J \subset R^{b}$ be an $F$-standard ideal of definition and let $M=W\left(R^{b}\right) /\left(K^{p}+\varphi(K) \cdot W\left(R^{b}\right)+\left(p^{2},[J]\right)\right)$. Since $R^{b} \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} S_{\lambda}^{b}$ is $I^{b}$-completely faithfully flat, $W\left(R^{b}\right) \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} W\left(S_{\lambda}^{b}\right)$ is $(p,[J])$-completely faithfully flat. In particular, $M \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} M \otimes_{W\left(R^{b}\right)} W\left(S^{b}\right)$ is faithfully flat. Since $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{S_{\lambda}}\right)$ is generated by a distinguished element, $p=0$ in $M \otimes_{W\left(R^{b}\right)} W\left(S^{b}\right)$ for every $\lambda \in \Lambda$ by [BS22, Theorem 3.10]. Thus, we have $p=0$ in $M$. Let $p=a+\varphi(b) c+p^{2} d+e$ with $a \in K^{p}, b \in K, c, d \in W\left(R^{b}\right)$ and $e \in[J]$. We have $p(1-p d-\delta(b) c)+e \in K^{p}$. We show that $\delta(b)$ is a unit. If $\delta(b)$ is not a unit, there is a maximal ideal $J \subset \mathfrak{m} \in R^{b}$ such that $\delta(b) \in(p,|\mathfrak{m}|)$. The map $R^{b} \rightarrow R^{b} / \mathfrak{m}$ factors through $S_{\lambda}^{b}$ for some $\lambda \in \Lambda$, so the image of $K$ in $W\left(R^{b} / \mathfrak{m}\right)$ is generated by $p$. Since $\delta(b)$ maps to $p \cdot W\left(R^{b} / \mathfrak{m}\right)$ and $e$ maps to 0 in $W\left(R^{b} / \mathfrak{m}\right)$, we have $p(1-p d) \in\left(p^{2}\right)$ in $W\left(R^{b} / \mathfrak{m}\right)$, but this is a contradiction. Thus, $\delta(b)$ is a unit and $b \in K$ is a distinguished element. Then, $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{S_{\lambda}}\right)$ is generated by $b$ for every $\lambda \in \Lambda$, and we see that $K$ is generated by $b$.

The above proof also justifies the following construction.
Definition 4.23. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a perfectoid formal scheme. The tilting of $\mathfrak{X}$ is a perfect formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}^{b}$ such that $\left|\mathfrak{X}^{b}\right|=|\mathfrak{X}|$ and $\mathcal{O}_{\mathfrak{X}^{b}}(U)=\mathcal{O}_{\mathfrak{X}}(U)^{b}$ for every affine open subspace $U \subset|\mathfrak{X}|$.

The tilting equivalence naturally extends to the category of perfectoid formal schemes.
Proposition 4.24. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring. The category of perfectoid formal schemes over $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is equivalent to the category of perfect formal schemes over $\operatorname{Spf}\left(R^{b}\right)$. For a perfectoid formal scheme $\mathfrak{X}$ over $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with a tilting $\mathfrak{X}^{b}$ over $\operatorname{Spf}\left(R^{b}\right)$, there is an isomorphism $\mathfrak{X} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \operatorname{Spec}(R / I) \cong \mathfrak{X}^{b} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}\left(R^{b}\right)} \operatorname{Spec}\left(R^{b} / I^{b}\right)$ for every ideal of definition $I \subset R$ with $p \in I$. Moreover, there is an isomorphism $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ} \cong\left(\mathfrak{X}^{b}\right)^{\circ}$.

Proof. The first claim follows since the functor $\mathfrak{X} \mapsto \mathfrak{X}^{b}$ is an equivalence by Proposition 4.12. For the remaining claims, we may assume that $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(S)$. Since $\mathfrak{X}^{b}=\operatorname{Spf}\left(S^{b}\right)$ and $S / I S \cong S^{b} /(I S)^{b}$, we have $\mathfrak{X} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \operatorname{Spec}(R / I) \cong \mathfrak{X}^{b} \times_{\operatorname{Spf}\left(R^{b}\right)} \operatorname{Spec}\left(R^{b} / I^{b}\right)$. We have an isomorphism $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{b}\right)$ by Proposition 4.12.

In the above situation, we say that $\mathfrak{X}$ is the untilt of $\mathfrak{X}^{b}$ over $R$. Since $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ} \cong\left(\mathfrak{X}^{b}\right)^{\circ}, \mathfrak{X}$ is thick if and only if $\mathfrak{X}^{b}$ is thick.
4.5. Fully faithfulness of $v$-sheafification. In this section, we study the fully faithfulness of the $v$-sheafification functor. First, we recall the following result.

Proposition 4.25. ([SW20, Proposition 18.3.1]) The functor $X \mapsto X^{\circ}$ from perfect schemes of characteristic $p$ to small $v$-sheaves on Perf is fully faithful.

We extend this result to the category of perfectoid formal schemes. For this, we apply continuous arc-descent (Proposition 4.17).
Lemma 4.26. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring and let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition. There exists a set of continuous homomorphisms $\left\{R \rightarrow V_{\lambda}\right\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda}$ with $V_{\lambda}$ a p-complete discrete valuation ring with an algebraically closed fraction field such that the complete I-adic ring $S=\prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} V_{\lambda}$ satisfies that $R \rightarrow S$ is a continuous arc-cover and $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is a v-cover.
Proof. For each point $x \in|\operatorname{Spd}(R)|$, take a continuous homomorphism $R \rightarrow V_{x}$ with $V_{x}$ a $p$ complete discrete valuation ring with an algebraically closed fraction field such that $x$ is the image of the closed point along $\operatorname{Spd}\left(V_{x}\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right], V_{x}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ with $\varpi \in V_{x}$ a pseudo-uniformizer. Let $S=\prod_{x \in|\operatorname{Spd}(R)|} V_{x}$. The map $|\operatorname{Spd}(S)| \rightarrow|\operatorname{Spd}(R)|$ is surjective, so $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective by [Gle24, Lemma 2.26] and [Sch17, Lemma 12.11]. Note that $R \rightarrow S$ is automatically a continuous arc-cover since each homomorphism $R \rightarrow V$ to a valuation ring $V$ of rank 1 corresponds to a point $\operatorname{Spd}\left(V\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right], V\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ with $\varpi \in V$ a pseudo-uniformizer.

Proposition 4.27. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a perfectoid formal scheme and let $\mathfrak{Y}$ be a formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. The map $\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Spf}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)}(\mathfrak{X}, \mathfrak{Y}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)}\left(\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}, \mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}\right)$ is bijective.
Proof. By following the argument given in the proof of [AGLR22, Theorem 2.16], we may assume that $\mathfrak{X}$ and $\mathfrak{Y}$ are affine. Let $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ and $\mathfrak{Y}=\operatorname{Spf}(A)$ with $R$ a complete adic perfectoid ring. Let $f: \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ be an arbitrary map. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition and take a continuous arc-cover $R \rightarrow S=\prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} V_{\lambda}$ as in Lemma 4.26. For each $\lambda \in \Lambda,\left|\cdot\right|_{\lambda}$ denotes the continuous valuation on $R$ corresponding to $V_{\lambda}$. Let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in R$ be a finite set of generators of $I$. Take a decomposition $\Lambda=\prod_{0 \leq i \leq r} \Lambda_{i}$ so that $\left|\cdot\right|_{\lambda}$ is discrete for $\lambda \in \Lambda_{0}$ and $\left|f_{j}\right|_{\lambda} \leq\left|f_{i}\right|_{\lambda} \neq 0$ for $1 \leq i, j \leq r$ and $\lambda \in \Lambda_{i}$. Let $S_{i}=\prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda_{i}} V_{\lambda}$. First, the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{0}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is represented by a unique homomorphism $f_{0}: A \rightarrow A_{\text {red }}^{\text {perf }} \rightarrow R_{\text {red }} \rightarrow S_{0}$ by [SW20, Proposition 18.3.1]. For $1 \leq i \leq r$, the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{i}\left[\frac{1}{f_{i}}\right], S_{i}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{i}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is represented by a unique continuous homomorphism $f_{i}: A \rightarrow S_{i}$. By [Gle24, Proposition 4.9], $f_{i}$ represents the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{i}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$. The product $\left(f_{i}\right)_{0 \leq i \leq r}: A \rightarrow \prod_{0 \leq i \leq r} S_{i}=S$ represents the composition $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$. Thus, we see that $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is represented by a unique continuous homomorphism $A \rightarrow S$.

Take a continuous arc-cover $g: S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S \rightarrow S^{\prime}$ as in Lemma 4.26. Let $i_{1}, i_{2}: S \rightarrow S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S$ be homomorphisms such that $i_{1}(s)=s \otimes 1$ and $i_{2}(s)=1 \otimes s$ for $s \in S$. Since the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is represented by a unique continuous homomorphism $A \rightarrow S^{\prime}$, we have $g \circ i_{1} \circ\left(f_{i}\right)=g \circ i_{2} \circ\left(f_{i}\right)$. Since $g$ is injective and the equalizer of $i_{1}$ and $i_{2}$ is $R$

by Corollary 4.18, we see that the product $\left(f_{i}\right)$ factors through $R \subset S$. By Corollary 4.20, $\left(f_{i}\right)$ induces a continuous homomorphism $A \rightarrow R$ and we see that it represents $f$ by the surjectivity of $\operatorname{Spd}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$.
4.6. Analytic locus. In this section, we study analytic loci of perfectoid formal schemes and prove a perfectoid analogue of [Lou17, Proposition 3].

Lemma 4.28. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring and let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}$ be elements of $R^{b}$ such that $\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right) \subset R^{b}$ is open and $\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\sharp}\right) \subset R$ is open. Let $J \subset R^{b}$ be the minimum $F$-standard ideal containing $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}$. We have $\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\sharp}\right)^{r} \cdot\left(J^{\sharp}\right)^{n} \subset\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\sharp}\right)^{n}$ for every $n \geq 0$.

Proof. As in [Tak25, Definition 2.3], an element of $J$ can be written as a linear combination of elements $f_{1}^{a_{1}} \cdots f_{r}^{a_{r}}$ with $a_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \geq 0$ and $\sum_{1 \leq i \leq r} a_{i}=1$. Thus, as in Lemma 4.2, $[J]$ is the $p$-adic closure of the ideal of $W\left(R^{b}\right)$ generated by $\left[f_{1}\right]^{a_{1}} \cdots\left[f_{r}\right]^{a_{r}}$ with $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{r}$ as above. By Lemma 4.7, $J^{\sharp}$ is generated by elements $\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}\right)^{a_{1}} \cdots\left(f_{r}^{\sharp}\right)^{a_{r}}$ with $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{r}$ as above. Thus, $\left(J^{\sharp}\right)^{n}$ is generated by elements $\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}\right)^{a_{1}} \cdots\left(f_{r}^{\sharp}\right)^{a_{r}}$ with $a_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \geq 0$ and $\sum_{1 \leq i \leq r} a_{i}=n$. Since we have $\sum_{1 \leq i \leq r}\left[a_{i}\right] \geq n-r$, we see that $\left(J^{\sharp}\right)^{n} \subset\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\sharp}\right)^{n-r}$ and the claim holds.

Proposition 4.29. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring. For every Tate rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R),\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is a perfectoid affinoid pair.
Proof. By [Hub93, Lemma 3.10], we may assume that $s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}$ lie in the image of $(-)^{\sharp}: R^{b} \rightarrow R$. Let $s^{s}, T_{1}^{s}, \ldots, T_{r}^{s}$ be elements of $R^{b}$ such that $s=\left(s^{s}\right)^{\sharp}$ and $T_{i}=\left(T_{i}^{s}\right)^{\sharp}$ for every $1 \leq i \leq r$. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated ideal of definition of $R$ with $p \in I$. We may take a finite set of generators $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{s}$ of $I^{b}$ such that $f_{1}^{\sharp}, \ldots, f_{s}^{\sharp}$ generate $I$. By adding $\left(f_{1}^{\sharp}\right)^{N}, \ldots,\left(f_{s}^{\sharp}\right)^{N}$ to $T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}$ for sufficiently large $N \geq 0$, we may assume that $T_{1}^{s}, \ldots, T_{r}^{s}$ generate an open ideal.

First, we show that $\left(R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle, R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is a complete perfect Tate affinoid pair. By Proposition 4.19, the inverse of the Frobenius on $R^{b}$ is continuous, so $R^{b} \xrightarrow{x \mapsto x^{1 / p}} R^{b} \rightarrow$ $R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$ factors through $R^{b} \rightarrow R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$ by the universality of $R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$. It gives the inverse to the Frobenius on $R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$ and we see that $R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$ is perfect. In particular, $\left(R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle, R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{s} \ldots T_{r}^{s}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is uniform by [SW20, Proposition 6.1.6].

Next, we show that $\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is uniform. Let $a \in R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$be an arbitrary element. The $s$-adic completion $R\left[\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]^{\wedge}$ of $R\left[\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]$ is a ring of definition of $R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle$. It is enough to show that $s^{k} a \in R\left[\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]^{\wedge}$ for some $k \geq 0$ independent of $a$. Since $R[1 / s]$ is dense in $R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle$, we may replace $a$ by an element of $R[1 / s]$. Moreover, the image of $(-)^{\sharp}: R^{b} \rightarrow R$ is dense, so we may assume that $a=b^{\sharp} / s^{n}$ for some $b \in R^{b}$ and $n \geq 1$. Now, since $a \in R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$, we have $\left|b^{\sharp}\right| \leq\left|s^{n}\right|$ for every $|\cdot| \in R\left(\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)$.

By the tilting equivalence between $R$ and $R^{b}$ (see the proof of Proposition 4.19), we have $|b| \leq\left|\left(s^{b}\right)^{n}\right|$ for every $|\cdot| \in R^{b}\left(\frac{T_{1}^{a} \ldots T_{r}^{b}}{s^{b}}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{b}\right)$. Then, we have $b /\left(s^{b}\right)^{n} \in R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{a} \ldots T_{r}^{b}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle^{+}$and since $R^{b}\left\langle\frac{T_{1}^{a} \ldots T_{r}^{b}}{s^{b}}\right\rangle$ is uniform, we have $\left(s^{b}\right)^{k} b /\left(s^{b}\right)^{n} \in R^{b}\left[\frac{T_{1}^{a} \ldots T_{r}^{b}}{s^{b}}\right]$ for some $k \geq 0$ independent of $a$. Thus, by replacing $b$ and $n$, we may assume that $\left(s^{b}\right)^{k} b \in\left(s^{b}, T_{1}^{a}, \ldots, T_{r}^{b}\right)^{n}$. Let $J \subset R^{b}$ be the minimum $F$-standard ideal containing $\left(s^{b}, T_{1}^{a}, \ldots, T_{r}^{b}\right)$. By Lemma 4.2, $\left[\left(s^{b}\right)^{k} b\right]$ lies in the $p$-adic closure of $[J]^{n}$ in $W\left(R^{b}\right)$. It follows that $s^{k} b^{\sharp} \in\left(J^{\sharp}\right)^{n}$. By Lemma 4.28, we have $s^{k+r+1} b^{\sharp} \in\left(s, T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right)^{n}$. It follows that $s^{k+r+1} b^{\sharp} / s^{n} \in R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right]$.

Finally, we show that $\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is a perfectoid affinoid pair. Let $J \subset R^{b}$ be the minimum $F$-standard ideal containing $s^{b}, T_{1}^{a}, \ldots, T_{r}^{b}$. Then, $R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right] \subset R^{b}\left[1 / s^{b}\right]$ is perfect and its $s^{b}$-adic completion $R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right]^{\wedge}$ is a ring of definition of $R^{b}\left(\frac{T_{1}^{a} \ldots T_{r}^{b}}{s^{b}}\right)$. Moreover, $W\left(R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right]\right) \subset W\left(R^{b}\left[1 / s^{b}\right]\right)$ is the $p$-adic completion of $W\left(R^{b}\right)\left[\left[J J /\left[s^{b}\right]\right] \subset W\left(R^{b}\right)\left[1 /\left[s^{b}\right]\right]$. By Lemma 4.3, $W\left(R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right]^{\wedge}\right)$ is the $\left(p,\left[s^{b}\right]\right)$-adic completion of $W\left(R^{b}\right)\left[\left[J J /\left[s^{b}\right]\right]\right.$. We see from the tilting equivalence between $R$ and $R^{b}$ that the composition $W\left(R^{b}\right) \rightarrow R \rightarrow R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle$ induces $W\left(R^{b}\right)\left[[J J /\left[s^{b}\right]\right] \rightarrow R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$. Since $\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$is uniform, it induces a continuous homomorphism $W\left(R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right]^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$.

Let $S$ be the untilt of $R^{b}\left[J / s^{b}\right]^{\wedge}$ over $R$. From the previous homomorphism, we have $S \rightarrow R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}$. Since $s^{b}$ is a topologically nilpotent non-zero-divisor of $S^{b}, s$ is a topologically nilpotent non-zero-divisor of $S$. Let $S^{+} \subset S[1 / s]$ be the integral closure of $S$. Then, $\left(S[1 / s], S^{+}\right)$is a perfectoid affinoid pair and we have a continuous homomorphism $\left(S[1 / s], S^{+}\right) \rightarrow\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right)$. It is enough to show that this map is an isomorphism. By the tilting equivalence between $R$ and $R^{b}$, the composition $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S[1 / s], S^{+}\right) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spa}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)$ factors through the rational subdomain $R\left(\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(R)$. From the universality, we get a continuous homomorphism $\left(R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle, R\left\langle\frac{T_{1} \ldots T_{r}}{s}\right\rangle^{+}\right) \rightarrow\left(S[1 / s], S^{+}\right)$. It is easy to see that this is the inverse to the previous map by looking at the image of elements of the form $b^{\sharp} / s^{n} \in S$ with $b \in J^{n}$.

In particular, the analytic locus of a perfectoid formal scheme is a perfectoid space.
Proposition 4.30. Let $R$ be a thick complete adic perfectoid ring. The homomorphism $R=\Gamma(\operatorname{Spf}(R), \mathcal{O}) \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is a homeomorphism onto the image and the image contains $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right)$.

Proof. First, we show that $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is injective. Suppose that $a \in R$ maps to 0 . We take a continuous arc-cover $R \rightarrow S=\prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} V_{\lambda}$ as in Lemma 4.26. It is enough to show that the image of $a$ in $V_{\lambda}$ is zero for every $\lambda \in \Lambda$. Let $K_{\lambda}=\operatorname{Frac}\left(V_{\lambda}\right)$ and consider the map $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)$. If it factors through $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$, the claim follows from our assumption on $a$. Otherwise, $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)$ factors through $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)$. It is enough to show that the restriction of $a$ to $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)$ is zero. Now, since $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is thick, the specialization map of $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is surjective. Thus, for every point $x \in \operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)$,

there is a point $\operatorname{Spa}(K, V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ specializing to $x$. Since the pullback of $a$ along $\operatorname{Spf}(V) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is zero, we see that $a$ is zero at $x$. Since $R_{\text {red }}$ is reduced, the restriction of $a$ to $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\text {red }}\right)$ is zero and we get the claim.

Next, we show that the image of $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$contains $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\right)$. For each $a \in \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\right)$, we define $a_{\lambda} \in V_{\lambda}^{\infty}$ for every $\lambda \in \Lambda$ so that $a_{\lambda}$ is the pullback of $a$ along $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ if $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right)$ is an analytic point of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)$, and $a_{\lambda}=0$ otherwise. The collection $\left(a_{\lambda}\right)_{\lambda \in \Lambda}$ defines an element of $S$. We show that it descends to $R$.

Let $i_{1}, i_{2}: S \rightarrow S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S$ be homomorphisms such that $i_{1}(s)=s \otimes 1$ and $i_{2}(s)=1 \otimes s$ for $s \in S$. Let $b=i_{1}\left(\left(a_{\lambda}\right)\right)-i_{2}\left(\left(a_{\lambda}\right)\right) \in S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S$. The restriction of $\left(a_{\lambda}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }}$ is equal to the pullback of $a$ along $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$, so the restriction of $b$ to $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S\right)^{\text {an }}$ is zero. Moreover, the restriction of $\left(a_{\lambda}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Spec}\left(S_{\text {red }}\right)$ is zero since $a \in \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\right)$ and $a_{\lambda}=0$ when $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right)$ is a discrete point of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)$. Thus, the restriction of $b$ to $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\left(S \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S\right)_{\text {red }}\right)$ is zero. By the same argument as in the proof of injectivity, we see that $b=0$. Thus, the element $\left(a_{\lambda}\right)$ descends to $R$. It follows from [Sch17, Theorem 8.7] that it maps to $a$ under $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$since $\operatorname{Spa}(S)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is a $v$-cover of perfectoid spaces.

Finally, we prove that $R \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is a homeomorphism onto the image. Since $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is a perfectoid space, and in particular uniform, $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda^{\text {an }}} V_{\lambda}$ is a homeomorphism onto the image with $\Lambda^{\text {an }} \subset \Lambda$ consisting of indices of analytic points $\operatorname{Spa}\left(K_{\lambda}, V_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ (see e.g. [SW20, Theorem 5.2.1]). It suffices to show that the composition $R \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda} V_{\lambda} \rightarrow \prod_{\lambda \in \Lambda^{\text {an }}} V_{\lambda}$ is a homeomorphism onto the image. This follows from Proposition 4.19 since discrete valuations on $R$ do not contribute to the supremum over $\mathcal{M}_{I}(R)$ for an ideal of definition $I \subset R$.

Corollary 4.31. Let $R$ be a complete adic perfectoid ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. Then, $R$ is thick if and only if $R$ is distinguished.

Proof. Since $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is $I$-torsion free, the claim follows from Lemma 3.6 and Proposition 4.30 .

Remark 4.32. Since $R$ is thick if and only if $R^{b}$ is thick, it follows that $R$ is distinguished if and only if $R^{b}$ is distinguished.

# 5. Dilatation THEORY OF $v$-SHEAVES 

5.1. Very good covers. In this section, we introduce very good covers of complete adic rings as preliminaries to good covers.

Let $R$ be a complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$. Let $R_{\bullet}=(R=$ $\left.R_{0} \hookrightarrow R_{1} \hookrightarrow \cdots\right)$ be a sequence of rings with injective transition maps and let $\Gamma_{\bullet}=(\{1\}=$ $\left.\Gamma_{0} \leftarrow \Gamma_{1} \leftarrow \cdots\right)$ be a sequence of finite groups with surjective transition maps. We set $\Gamma_{\infty}=\lim _{n \geq 0} \Gamma_{n}$ and $\Gamma_{m}^{n}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\Gamma_{m} \rightarrow \Gamma_{n}\right)$ for every $0 \leq n \leq m \leq \infty$.

Definition 5.1. An action of $\Gamma_{\bullet}$ on $R_{\bullet}$ is a family of an action of $\Gamma_{n}$ on $R_{n}$ for each $n \geq 0$ such that the action of $\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}$ on $R_{n+1}$ is an action as an $R_{n}$-algebra for every $n \geq 0$.

In particular, an action of $\Gamma_{\bullet}$ on $R_{\bullet}$ induces an action of $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ on $R_{m}$ over $R_{n}$ for every $0 \leq n \leq m<\infty$.

Definition 5.2. A pair $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ with an action of $\Gamma_{\bullet}$ on $R_{\bullet}$ is a very good cover of a complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ if
(1) the action of $\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}$ on $R_{n+1}$ over $R_{n}$ satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12,
(2) $R_{n+1} / R_{n}$ is a finite projective $R_{n}$-module for every $n \geq 0$, and
(3) the $I$-completed colimit $R_{\infty}=\operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0}^{\wedge} R_{n}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring.

We list some basic properties of very good covers.
Lemma 5.3. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a very good cover of a complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$.
(1) $R_{m}$ is finite projective over $R_{n}$ and the action of $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ on $R_{m}$ over $R_{n}$ satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12 for every $0 \leq n \leq m<\infty$.
(2) $R_{n}$ is I-adically complete and is a direct summand of $R_{\infty}$ as an $R_{n}$-module for every $n \geq 0$.

Proof. Let $S_{0}=R_{0}=R$ and $S_{n}=R_{n} / R_{n-1}$ for $n \geq 1$. Since $S_{n}$ is finite projective over $R_{n}$, we can take a decomposition $R_{n+1}=R_{n} \oplus S_{n+1}$ and we have $R_{n}=S_{0} \oplus \cdots \oplus S_{n}$. In particular, $R_{m}=R_{n} \oplus S_{n+1} \oplus \cdots \oplus S_{m}$ and $R_{m}$ is finite projective over $R_{n}$. Then, (1) follows from Lemma 3.13. Moreover, $R_{n}$ is finite projective over $R$ and $R_{n}$ is $I$-adically complete. Then, we have $R_{\infty}=\operatorname{colim}_{m \geq n}^{\wedge}\left(R_{n} \oplus S_{n+1} \oplus \cdots \oplus S_{m}\right)=R_{n} \oplus\left(\widehat{\oplus}_{m>n} S_{m}\right)$, so $R_{n}$ is a direct summand of $R_{\infty}$ as an $R_{n}$-module.

Lemma 5.4. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a very good cover of a complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. The map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is proper and a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ for every $0 \leq n \leq m \leq \infty$.

Proof. As in the proof of Proposition 3.15, $R_{m}$ is integral over $R_{n}$ and we have the claim for $m<\infty$ by Lemma 3.3 and Proposition 3.15. Since properness and geometric quotients are preserved under limits (apply [Sch17, Proposition 18.3] for the former, and see Proposition 3.16 for the latter), we have the claim for $m=\infty$.

The main source of complete adic rings admitting very good covers is as follows.
Proposition 5.5. Let $E$ be a complete discrete valuation field over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ with perfect residue field and let $O_{E}$ be the ring of integers of $E$. For every $r \geq 0, O_{E}\left\langle T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right\rangle$ admits a very good cover.

Proof. Let $\pi \in O_{E}$ be a uniformizer of $E$. For $n \geq 0$, we set $E_{n}=E\left[\pi^{1 / p^{n}}, \zeta_{p^{n}}\right]$ with $\zeta_{p^{n}}$ a $p^{n}$-th root of unity. We take the family $\left\{\zeta_{p^{n}}\right\}$ so that $\zeta_{p^{n+1}}^{p}=\zeta_{p^{n}}$. Then, $E_{n}$ is a finite Galois extension of $E$. Let $O_{E_{n}}$ be the ring of integers of $E_{n}$ and let $R_{n}=O_{E_{n}}\left\langle T_{1}^{1 / p^{n}}, \ldots, T_{r}^{1 / p^{n}}\right\rangle$,

$\Gamma_{n}=\operatorname{Gal}\left(E_{n} / E\right) \times\left(\mathbb{Z} / p^{n}\right)^{\oplus r}$. There is a natural inclusion $R_{n} \hookrightarrow R_{n+1}$ and a natural surjection $\Gamma_{n+1} \nrightarrow \Gamma_{n}$ for every $n \geq 0$. Moreover, there is an action of $\Gamma_{n}$ on $R_{n}$ such that the action of $\left(\sigma, a_{1}, \ldots, a_{r}\right) \in \operatorname{Gal}\left(E_{n} / E\right) \times\left(\mathbb{Z} / p^{n}\right)^{\oplus r}$ sends $x \in O_{E_{n}}$ to $\sigma(x)$, and sends $T_{i}^{1 / p^{\sigma}}$ to $\zeta_{p^{n}}^{a_{i}} T_{i . .}^{1 / p^{\sigma}}$ for $1 \leq i \leq r$. This defines an action of $\Gamma_{\bullet}$ on $R_{\bullet}$. It is easy to see that $R_{n}=R_{n+1}^{\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}}$ and $R_{n+1} / R_{n}$ is finite free over $R_{n}$ (since $O_{E_{n+1}} / O_{E_{n}}$ is finite free over $O_{E_{n}}$ ). It is enough to show that $R_{\infty}$ is a perfectoid ring. Consider the $p$-completed colimit $O_{E_{\infty}}=\operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0}^{\wedge} O_{E_{n}}$ and let $E_{\infty}=O_{E_{\infty}}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$. Then, $E_{\infty}$ is a perfectoid field and $O_{E_{\infty}}$ is a perfectoid ring. Since $R_{\infty}$ is $\pi$-torsion free, it is enough by [BMS18, Lemma 3.10] to check that the Frobenius $R_{\infty} / \pi^{1 / p} R_{\infty} \rightarrow R_{\infty} / \pi R_{\infty}$ is an isomorphism. Since $O_{E_{\infty}}$ is a perfectoid ring, it follows from the description $R_{\infty} / \pi R_{\infty}=\operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0}\left(O_{E_{n}} / \pi O_{E_{n}}\right)\left[T_{1}^{1 / p^{r}}, \ldots, T_{r}^{1 / p^{r}}\right]$.

The class of complete adic rings admitting very good covers is closed under étale localization and completion.
Lemma 5.6. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$. Let $S$ be an I-adically complete I-completely étale $R$-algebra. If $R$ admits a very good cover, $S$ admits a very good cover.
Proof. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a very good cover of $R$. Let $S_{\bullet}=R_{\bullet} \otimes_{R} S$. The condition in Lemma 3.12 is stable under base change, so the action of $\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}$ on $S_{n+1}$ over $S_{n}$ satisfies that condition. By construction, $S_{n+1} / S_{n}$ is finite projective over $S_{n}$. Moreover, $S_{\infty}=R_{\infty} \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring by Lemma 4.13.
Lemma 5.7. Let $R$ be a complete adic ring over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ and let $J \subset R$ be a finitely generated open ideal. If $R$ admits a very good cover, the $J$-adic completion $R^{\wedge}$ admits a very good cover. Moreover, $R^{\wedge}$ admits a very good cover as a p-adic ring if $R$ is p-torsion free, p-adic and Noetherian and $R / p R$ is $F$-finite.
Proof. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a very good cover of $R$. Let $R_{\bullet}^{\wedge}=R_{\bullet} \otimes_{R} R^{\wedge}$. The condition in Lemma 3.12 is stable under base change, so the action of $\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}$ on $R_{n+1}^{\wedge}$ over $R_{n}^{\wedge}$ satisfies that condition. By construction, $R_{n+1}^{\wedge} / R_{n}^{\wedge}$ is finite projective over $R_{n}^{\wedge}$. Moreover, $R_{\infty}^{\wedge}$ is isomorphic to the $J$-adic completion of $R_{\infty}$, so $R_{\infty}^{\wedge}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring by Corollary 4.11. Thus, $\left(R_{\bullet}^{\wedge}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a very good cover of the $J$-adic ring $R^{\wedge}$.

We show the second claim. It is enough to show that the $p$-adic completion $\operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0}^{\wedge} R_{n}^{\wedge}$ is perfectoid. Since $R_{\infty}$ is perfectoid, we can take an element $\pi \in R_{\infty}$ such that $\pi^{p}=p u$ for some $u \in R_{\infty}^{\times}$. We may approximate $\pi$ by an element of $R_{n}$ for sufficiently large $n$ and replace $R$ with $R_{n}$ to assume that $\pi \in R$.

Since $R$ is Noetherian, $R \rightarrow R^{\wedge}$ is flat, so $R_{\bullet}^{\wedge}$ is $p$-torsion free. By [BMS18, Lemma 3.10 (ii)], it is enough to show that the Frobenius $\operatorname{colim} R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi R_{n}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \operatorname{colim} R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi^{p} R_{n}^{\wedge}$ is an isomorphism. Since $R_{\infty}$ is perfectoid, $\operatorname{colim} R_{n} / \pi R_{n} \rightarrow \operatorname{colim} R_{n} / \pi^{p} R_{n}$ is an isomorphism. Since $R_{n}$ is a direct summand of $R_{\infty}, R_{n} / \pi R_{n} \rightarrow \operatorname{colim}_{m \geq n} R_{m} / \pi R_{m}$ is injective, so the Frobenius $R_{n} / \pi R_{n} \rightarrow R_{n} / \pi^{p} R_{n}$ is injective. Since $R \rightarrow R^{\wedge}$ is flat, $R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi R_{n}^{\wedge} \rightarrow R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi^{p} R_{n}^{\wedge}$ is

injective, so $\operatorname{colim} R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi R_{n}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \operatorname{colim} R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi^{p} R_{n}^{\wedge}$ is injective. On the other hand, since $R / p R$ is $F$-finite, the composition $R \rightarrow R / \pi R \rightarrow R / \pi^{p} R \rightarrow R_{n} / \pi^{p} R_{n}$ is finite. Thus, for every $n \geq 0$, there is $m \geq n$ such that the image of the Frobenius $R_{m} / \pi R_{m} \rightarrow R_{m} / \pi^{p} R_{m}$ contains $R_{n} / \pi^{p} R_{n}$. By passing to the $J$-adic completion, we see that the image of the Frobenius $R_{m}^{\wedge} / \pi R_{m}^{\wedge} \rightarrow R_{m}^{\wedge} / \pi^{p} R_{m}^{\wedge}$ contains $R_{n}^{\wedge} / \pi^{p} R_{n}^{\wedge}$. In particular, $\operatorname{colim} R_{n} / \pi R_{n} \rightarrow \operatorname{colim} R_{n} / \pi^{p} R_{n}$ is surjective.

Thanks to Lemma 5.6, the following notion is purely local in the Zariski topology.
Definition 5.8. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. We say that $\mathfrak{X}$ admits a very good cover if $\mathfrak{X}$ is Zariski locally isomorphic to the formal spectrum of a complete adic ring admitting a very good cover.

The main source of formal schemes admitting very good covers is as follows.
Proposition 5.9. Let $E$ be a complete discrete valuation field over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ with perfect residue field and let $O_{E}$ be the ring of integers of $E$. Every p-adic smooth formal $O_{E}$-scheme admits a very good cover.
Proof. After Zariski localization, every $p$-completely smooth $O_{E}$-algebra is $p$-completely étale over $O_{E}\left\langle T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right\rangle$ for some $r \geq 0$ (by the topological invariance of étale sites). Thus, the claim follows from Proposition 5.5 and Lemma 5.6.
Remark 5.10. By Lemma 5.7 and Proposition 5.9, formal schemes admitting very good covers arise as the completion of smooth schemes. Here are arithmetically important examples: the $p$-adic completion of integral models of Shimura varieties at hyperspecial levels, and Rapoport-Zink spaces at hyperspecial levels with the $p$-adic uniformization (see [Mic20, Corollary 4.9]).
5.2. Good covers. In this section, we introduce good covers of reduced excellent complete adic rings, which are refinements of very good covers modeled on analytic loci. They satisfy a minimal set of properties of very good covers needed in the proof of our representability criterion.

Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $p \in I \subset R$. Let $R_{\bullet}=\left(R=R_{0} \rightarrow R_{1} \rightarrow \cdots\right)$ be a sequence of reduced finite $R$-algebras. Let $\Gamma_{\bullet}=(\{1\}=$ $\left.\Gamma_{0} \leftarrow \Gamma_{1} \leftarrow \cdots\right)$ be a sequence of finite groups with surjective transition maps that acts on $R_{\bullet}$ in the sense of Definition 5.1. To simplify the notation, for every $n \geq 0$ and every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$, the pullback of $U_{n}$ in $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{m}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is denoted by $U_{m}$ for every $m \geq n$. Later, this notation is also used for $m=\infty$.

As a refinement of the condition (1) in Definition 5.2, we first put the following condition: (quot) for every $n \geq 0, \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n+1}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{n+1}^{n}$, and for every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$, the pullback $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)$ is injective and satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12 with respect to the $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$-action.

The latter condition of (quot) is analytically local on $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$.
Lemma 5.11. If there is a covering $\left\{V_{n, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ by Tate rational subdomains such that $\mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, i}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(V_{m, i}\right)$ is injective and satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12, then every Tate rational domain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ satisfies the same conditions.
Proof. Since $R_{m}$ is finite over $R_{n}$, we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \otimes_{R_{n}} R_{m}$. First, suppose that $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$ for some $i \in I$. Then, we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \otimes_{\mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{m, i}\right)$. Since $V_{n, i}$ is strongly Noetherian, $\mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, i}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ is flat (see [Hub96, Lemma 1.7.6]). Thus, $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow$ $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)$ is injective. It also satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12 since that condition is stable under base change. Thus, the case where $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$ is done.

Now, by refining the covering $\left\{V_{n, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$, we may suppose that $U_{n}$ is covered by a collection $\left\{V_{n, j}\right\}_{j \in J}$ for some $J \subset I$. Since $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, j}\right)$ is injective and the same holds for $U_{m}, \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)$ is injective. Moreover, we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right) \cap \prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, j}\right)$ in $\prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{m, j}\right)$, so the condition in Lemma 3.12 is satisfied by Lemma 3.14.

As a refinement of the condition (3) in Definition 5.2, we next put the following condition: (perfd) $\lim _{n \geq 0} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is represented by a complete $I$-adic perfectoid $R$ algebra $R_{\infty}$.
By Proposition 4.27, we get a homomorphism $R_{n} \rightarrow R_{\infty}$ for every $n \geq 0$. Since $R_{n}$ is reduced and excellent, and $R_{\infty}$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring, we have a sequence of stably uniform analytic adic spaces (see Lemma 2.4 and Proposition 4.29)

$$
\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{1}\right)^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{0}\right)^{\mathrm{an}}=\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}
$$

By construction, the $v$-sheafification of this sequence is a limit sequence. We will impose that this is a limit sequence of analytic adic spaces. First, we put a density condition:
(density) for every $n \geq 0$ and every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$, the image of $\operatorname{colim}_{n \leq m<\infty} \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is dense.
Another condition on the sequence is the existence of functorial and uniform sections. It is one of the essential conditions and is a refinement of the condition (2) in Definition 5.2.
(unifsec) for every $n \geq 0$ and every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$, we have a continuous $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$-linear section $s_{n, U_{n}}: \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ of the pullback. The family $\left\{s_{n, U_{n}}\right\}$ is functorial in $U_{n}$ for fixed $n$, and uniform in $n$ for fixed $U_{n}$ in a sense that there is an open ideal $\mathcal{J} \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ that maps to $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{m}\right)$ under $s_{m, U_{m}}$ for every $m \geq n$.
From now on, a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}$ of the pullback is always assumed to be $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ linear. We will show that the above two conditions are analytically local.
Lemma 5.12. Let $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ be a Tate rational subdomain with a uniform family of continuous sections $\left\{s_{m, U_{m}}\right\}$ for $m \geq n$. Then, the image of $\operatorname{colim}_{n \leq m<\infty} \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is dense if and only if $\left\{s_{m, U_{m}}(a)\right\}_{m \geq n}$ converges to $a$ in $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ for every $a \in \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$.

Proof. The if direction is obvious. We show the only if direction. Let $a \in \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ be an arbitrary element. By assumption, there is a sequence $\left\{b_{m}\right\}_{m \geq n}$ with $b_{m} \in \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)$ that converges to $a$ in $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$. Let $\mathcal{J} \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ be an open ideal that maps to $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{m}\right)$ under $s_{m, U_{m}}$ for every $m \geq n$. For every $N \geq 0$, there is $k \geq 0$ such that for every $m \geq k$, we have $a-b_{m} \in I^{N} \cdot \mathcal{J}$. Then, we have $s_{m, U_{m}}(a)-b_{m} \in I^{N} \cdot \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{m}\right)$ and $a-s_{m, U_{m}}(a) \in I^{N} \cdot \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ for $m \geq k$. Since $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is $I$-adic, $\left\{s_{m, U_{m}}(a)\right\}$ converges to $a$.
Lemma 5.13. The conditions (density) and (unifsec) hold if and only if there is a covering $\left\{V_{0, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ with a family of continuous sections $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, i}}\right\}_{n \geq 0, i \in I}$ such that
(1) the family $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, i}}\right\}_{n \geq 0}$ is uniform in $n$ for each $i \in I$,
(2) $s_{n, V_{n, i}}$ and $s_{n, V_{n, j}}$ induce the same continuous section $\mathcal{O}\left(V_{\infty, i} \cap V_{\infty, j}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, i} \cap V_{n, j}\right)$ for every $i, j \in I$, and
(3) $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, i}}(a)\right\}_{n \geq 0}$ converges to a in $\mathcal{O}\left(V_{\infty, i}\right)$ for every $a \in \mathcal{O}\left(V_{\infty, i}\right)$ and $i \in I$.

Before going to the proof, we explain the condition (2) more precisely. For each $i \in I$, we define $s_{n, U_{n}}$ for every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$. Let $\varpi \in \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{n, i}\right)$ be a topologically nilpotent unit. By the universality and uniformity of rational localization, we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \cong\left(\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{\infty, i}\right) \widehat{\otimes}_{\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{n, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) /\overline{(\varpi \text {-torsion })}\right)\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$. Take an open ideal $\mathcal{J}_{i} \subset$ $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{\infty, i}\right)$ as in (unifsec). Then, the base change $\mathcal{J} \widehat{\otimes}_{\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{n, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ of $s_{n, V_{n, i}}$ induces a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}$. The condition (2) says that this construction gives the same continuous section $s_{n, V_{n, i} \cap V_{n, j}}$ for different $i, j \in I$. In this case, we see that $s_{n, U_{n}}$ is independent of the choice of $i \in I$ such that $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$.
Proof. The only if direction follows from Lemma 5.12. We will prove the converse direction.
By the above remark, the condition (2) enables us to define a functorial family of continuous sections $s_{n, U_{n}}$ for $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$ for some $i \in I$. For every $m \geq n$, the image of $\mathcal{J} \widehat{\otimes}_{\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{m, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{m}\right)$ contains the image of $\mathcal{J} \widehat{\otimes}_{\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{n, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ in $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$, so the family $\left\{s_{n, U_{n}}\right\}_{n \geq 0}$ is uniform in $n$. Moreover, (density) holds for $U_{n}$ since we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \cong$ $\left(\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{\infty, i}\right) \widehat{\otimes}_{\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(V_{n, i}\right)} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) /\overline{(\varpi \text {-torsion })}\right)\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$. Thus, (density) and (unifsec) hold for $U_{n} \subset V_{n, i}$ for some $i \in I$.

By refining the covering $\left\{V_{n, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$, it is enough to treat the case where $U_{n}$ can be covered by $V_{n, j}$ for some $J \subset I$. Since the family $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, j}}\right\}_{j \in J}$ is functorial in $V_{n, j}$, we can glue it to a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}$. Moreover, the uniformity of $s_{n, U_{n}}$ in $n$ follows from that of $s_{n, V_{n, j}}$ for every $j \in J$. Since $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is equipped with the subspace topology of $\prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{\infty, j}\right)$, the condition (3) for $U_{n}$ follows from the condition (3) for all $V_{n, j}$. Thus, (density) and (unifsec) hold for $U_{n}$.
Definition 5.14. A pair $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a good cover of a reduced excellent complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ if it satisfies (quot), (perfd), (density) and (unifsec).
Lemma 5.15. A very good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ of a reduced excellent complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ is a good cover of $R$.

Proof. The condition (3) in Definition 5.2 implies that the limit $\lim _{n \geq 0} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is represented by $R_{\infty}=\operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0}^{\wedge} R_{n}$. Thus, $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (perfd). For every $n \geq 0$ and every Tate rational subdomain $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, R_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ is flat by [Hub96, Lemma 1.7.6] and $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{m}\right)$ is the base change of $R_{n} \rightarrow R_{m}$ for every $n \leq m<\infty$. Thus, (quot) holds by the condition (1) in Definition 5.2 .

We will verify (density) and (unifsec). By Lemma 5.3 (2), there is a continuous section $s_{n}: R_{\infty} \rightarrow R_{n}$ of the natural inclusion. Let $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ be a Tate rational subdomain and let $\varpi \in \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ be a topologically nilpotent unit. Since we have $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \cong$ $\left.\left(R_{\infty} \widehat{\otimes}_{R_{n}} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) /\left(\varpi\right.\right.\right.$-torsion $\left.\left.)\right)\left[\frac{1}{\varpi}\right]$, (density) holds for $U_{n}$ and $s_{n}$ induces a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}: \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$. As the image of $R_{\infty} \widehat{\otimes}_{R_{n}} \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ in $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ maps to $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ under $s_{n, U_{n}}$, we see that $\left\{s_{n, U_{n}}\right\}_{n \geq 0}$ is uniform in $n$. Thus, $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (unifsec).

Lemma 5.16. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. Let $S$ be an I-adically complete I-completely étale R-algebra. If $R$ admits a good cover, $S$ admits a good cover.

Proof. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a good cover of $R$. Let $S_{\bullet}=R_{\bullet} \otimes_{R} S$. By Elkik's algebraization theorem (see [Elk73]), $S_{n}$ is isomorphic to the $I$-adic completion of an étale $R_{n}$-algebra. For every $0 \leq n<\infty, S_{n}$ is a reduced finite $S$-algebra.

Now, $S_{\infty}=R_{\bullet} \widehat{\otimes}_{R} S$ is a complete adic perfectoid ring by Lemma 4.13 and represents $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}(S)=\lim _{n \geq 0} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$. Since the conditions (quot), (density) and (unifsec ) are local by Lemma 5.11 and Lemma 5.13, it is enough to check these conditions for sufficiently small Tate rational subdomains $U_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$. In particular, we may assume that $U_{n} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ factors through a Tate rational subdomain $V_{n} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ and is a composition of a finite étale morphism to $V_{n}$ and a rational localization. Then, $U_{\infty} \cong V_{\infty} \times_{V_{n}} U_{n}$ and $s_{n, V_{n}}$ induces a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}$ as in Lemma 5.13. It is easy to see that this construction is functorial and satisfies the density condition as in Lemma 5.13. Moreover, the latter condition of (quot) follows from the fact that $\mathcal{O}\left(V_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ is flat.

Lemma 5.17. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring with an ideal of definition $I \subset R$. Let $S$ be a reduced finite $R$-algebra that is finite étale over $R$ outside $V(I) \subset \operatorname{Spec}(R)$. If $R$ admits a good cover, $S$ admits a good cover.

Proof. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a good cover of $R$. Let $S_{n}$ be the reduction of $R_{n} \otimes_{R} S$ for every $0 \leq n<\infty$ and let $S_{\infty}^{0}$ be the perfectoidization of $R_{\infty} \otimes_{R} S$. By [BS22, Theorem 10.9], $S_{\infty}^{0}$ is a perfectoid ring and $R_{\infty} \otimes_{R} S \rightarrow S_{\infty}^{0}$ is an isomorphism outside $V(I)$. Let $S_{\infty}=\left(S_{\infty}^{0}\right)^{\wedge}$ be the $I$-adic completion. By construction, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}(S)$ and $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (perfd). By the same argument as in Lemma 5.16, we see that $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (quot), (density) and (perfd).

Thanks to Lemma 5.16, the following notion is purely local in the Zariski topology.

Definition 5.18. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. We say that $\mathfrak{X}$ admits a good cover if $\mathfrak{X}$ is Zariski locally isomorphic to the formal spectrum of a reduced excellent complete adic ring admitting a good cover.
5.3. Affine representability. The aim of this section is to prove the following theorem.

Theorem 5.19. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring admitting a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ and let $I \subset R$ be an ideal of definition. Let $S_{\infty}$ be a distinguished complete I-adic perfectoid $R_{\infty}$-algebra. Suppose that the following conditions hold.
(1) $\Gamma_{\infty}$ acts on $S_{\infty}$ compatibly with the action on $R_{\infty}$.
(2) $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{\infty}\right)^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\mathrm{an}}$ is an open immersion.
(3) $S_{\infty, \text { red }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{\infty, \text { red }}$.

Then, there is a good cover $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ of a reduced excellent distinguished complete I-adic ring $S$ with the following conditions.
