(1) There is a $\Gamma_{\bullet}$-equivariant homomorphism $R_{\bullet} \rightarrow S_{\bullet}$ such that for every $n \geq 0, S_{n}$ is topologically of finite type over $R_{n}$ and $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is an open immersion.
(2) There is a $\Gamma_{\infty}$-equivariant isomorphism $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \lim _{n \geq 0} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$ such that the induced map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is represented by the given map $R_{\infty} \rightarrow S_{\infty}$.

For every $0 \leq n \leq m \leq \infty$, the map $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{m}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is denoted by $\pi_{m}^{n}$. First, we construct the open subspace of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ that should be equal to $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Let $U_{n} \subset$ $\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}\right|$ be the image of $\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}\right| \subset\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}\right|$ under $\pi_{\infty}^{n}$.
Lemma 5.20. The subset $U_{n} \subset\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}\right|$ is open and $\left(\pi_{m}^{n}\right)^{-1}\left(U_{n}\right)=U_{m}$ for every $m \geq n$.
Proof. By the condition (quot), $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is a geometric quotient of $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$. Since $U_{\infty} \subset\left|\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)\right|$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}$, we see that $\left(\pi_{m}^{n}\right)^{-1}\left(U_{n}\right)=U_{m}$ for every $m \geq n$. Since $\pi_{\infty}^{n}$ is surjective and $U_{\infty}$ is open, it follows from [Sch17, Proposition 12.9] that $U_{n}$ is open.

From now on, $U_{n}$ is identified with the open subspace of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Since $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is quasicompact, $U_{n}$ is quasicompact. Thus, we can take a finite covering $\left\{V_{0, j}\right\}_{j \in J}$ of $U_{0}$ by Tate rational subdomains of $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$. Its pullback $\left\{V_{n, j}\right\}_{j \in J}$ to $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is a finite covering of $U_{n}$ by Tate rational subdomains of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Since the family of continuous sections $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, j}}\right\}$ is functorial, we get a continuous section $s_{n, U_{n}}: \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$. Moreover, since the family of continuous sections $\left\{s_{n, V_{n, j}}\right\}$ is uniform, there is an open ideal $\mathcal{J} \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ such that $s_{n, U_{n}}(\mathcal{J}) \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$ for every $n \geq 0$.

Lemma 5.21. The image of $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} \mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is dense.
Proof. The proof of Lemma 5.12 works since $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is $I$-adic by Proposition 4.30.
Note that the existence of a continuous section implies that $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is a closed embedding. Moreover, $S_{\infty} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$ is an open embedding by Proposition 4.30.

Let $S_{n}=\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \cap S_{\infty}$ where the intersection is taken inside $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$. Since $\mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\left(U_{\infty}\right) \subset$ $S_{\infty} \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$, we have $\mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\left(U_{n}\right) \subset S_{n} \subset \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$. By Lemma 5.21, $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n} \rightarrow S_{\infty}$ has a dense image. In particular, the completion of $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n}$ with respect to the subspace topology from $S_{\infty}$ is isomorphic to $S_{\infty}$. This subspace topology can be identified as follows.
Lemma 5.22. The subspace topology on $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n}$ is the I-adic topology. Moreover, the subspace topology on $S_{n}$ is the I-adic topology for every $n \geq 0$.
Proof. For every $n, m \geq 0$, we have $\left(I^{m} \cdot \mathcal{J}\right) \cap \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) \subset I^{m} \cdot \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right) \subset\left(I^{m} \cdot \mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{\infty}\right)\right) \cap$ $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$. The first inclusion follows from the property of $s_{n, U_{n}}$. Thus, the subspace topology on $S_{n}$ is the $I$-adic topology as $S_{n} \supset \mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\left(U_{n}\right)$. The claim for $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n}$ follows by the same argument.

As a consequence, we can verify the condition (perfd) on $S_{\bullet}$.
Corollary 5.23. $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \lim _{n<\infty} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$.
Proof. For every perfectoid affinoid pair $\left(A, A^{+}\right)$in characteristic $p$, a map from $\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right)$ to $\lim _{n<\infty} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$ corresponds to an untilt $\left(A^{\sharp}, \iota\right)$ and a compatible family of continuous homomorphisms $S_{n} \rightarrow A^{\sharp+}$. Since $A^{\sharp+}$ is complete, this family corresponds to a map from the $I$-adic completion of $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n}$ to $A^{\sharp+}$. Thus, we have $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \lim _{n<\infty} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$.

Since $U_{\infty}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}, U_{n}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{n}$. Thus, $\Gamma_{\infty}$ acts on $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right)$ factoring through $\Gamma_{n}$. Since $S_{\infty}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}, \Gamma_{\infty}$ acts on $S_{n}$ factoring through $\Gamma_{n}$. It means that $\Gamma_{\bullet}$ acts on $S_{\bullet}$. By construction, we have a $\Gamma_{\bullet}$-equivariant homomorphism $R_{\bullet} \rightarrow S_{\bullet}$. We next verify the condition (quot) on $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$.
Lemma 5.24. For every $0 \leq n \leq m<\infty, S_{n} \rightarrow S_{m}$ is injective and satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12 with respect to the $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$-action.
Proof. By construction, $S_{n} \rightarrow S_{m}$ is injective. It is enough to show the latter claim. By the condition (quot), $\prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, j}\right) \rightarrow \prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{m, j}\right)$ satisfies the condition in Lemma 3.12 with respect to the $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$-action. Since we have $\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{m}\right) \cap \prod_{j \in J} \mathcal{O}\left(V_{n, j}\right)=\mathcal{O}^{+}\left(U_{n}\right)$, the claim follows from Lemma 3.14.

Thus, we verify the first condition of (quot) on $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ by Proposition 3.15. In particular, we see from Proposition 3.16 that $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$ is a geometric quotient of $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right)$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$.
Corollary 5.25. For every $0 \leq n \leq m \leq \infty, \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{m}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ is surjective.
Proof. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{m}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ is qcqs by [Gle24, Lemma 2.26], it is enough to show that it is surjective on points. By Lemma 3.9, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$. Thus, for every geometric point $x \in \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)$, both fibers of $x$ in $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{m}\right)$ and in $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ consist of a single $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$-orbit. The claim follows since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{m}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ is $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$-equivariant.

Corollary 5.26. The map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ is an isomorphism onto $U_{n}$.
Proof. By Lemma 5.20, $U_{n}$ is a geometric quotient of $U_{\infty}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$. Thus, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ factors through $U_{n}$. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}\right)$ is qcqs by [Gle24, Lemma 2.26], $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow U_{n}$ is qcqs. Since both spaces are geometric quotients of $U_{\infty}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$, it is an isomorphism by Proposition 3.10.

Next, we will verify that $S_{n}$ is topologically of finite type over $R_{n}$. For this, we apply Proposition 2.11 to $S_{n}$. The first condition is verified in Lemma 5.22 and the second condition follows from Corollary 5.26 by [Sch17, Proposition 15.4]. It is enough to verify the last condition.

Lemma 5.27. $\left(S_{n, \text { red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$.
Proof. Since $S_{\infty}$ is isomorphic to the $I$-adic completion of $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n}$, we have $S_{\infty, \text { red }} \cong$ $\operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty} S_{n, \text { red }}$. Moreover, by the condition (perfd) and [SW20, Proposition 18.3.1], we have $R_{\infty, \text { red }} \cong \operatorname{colim}_{n<\infty}\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)^{\text {perf }}$. Since $S_{\infty, \text { red }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{\infty, \text { red }}$, for some $m \geq 0$, there is a homomorphism $P_{m}=R_{m, \text { red }}\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right] \rightarrow S_{m, \text { red }}$ such that if we set $P_{n}=R_{n, \text { red }}\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right] \rightarrow S_{n, \text { red }}$ as the base change of the map for $n \geq m$, $P_{\infty}^{\text {perf }} \rightarrow S_{\infty, \text { red }}$ is surjective. Then, the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty, \text { red }}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n, \text { red }}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)}$ $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty, \text { red }}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(P_{n}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty, \text { red }}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(P_{\infty}\right)$ is a closed immersion for $n \geq$ $m$. Then, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty, \text { red }}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n, \text { red }}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty, \text { red }}\right)$ is injective and surjective by Corollary 5.25 , so it is an isomorphism. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty, \text { red }}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n, \text { red }}\right)$ is a $v$-cover, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(P_{n}^{\text {perf }}\right)$ is a closed immersion by [Sch17, Proposition 10.11]. By [Gle24, Lemma 3.31], $P_{n}^{\text {perf }} \rightarrow S_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ is surjective. Thus, $S_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ for $n \geq m$.

We treat the case with $n<m$. Since $R_{m}$ is finite over $R_{n}, S_{m, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$. Since $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ is finite, we can take a finitely generated $R_{n, \text { red }}$-subalgebra $S^{0} \subset S_{m, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ stable under $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ so that $S_{0}^{\text {perf }} \cong S_{m, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$. Since $R_{n, \text { red }}$ is Noetherian, $\left(S^{0}\right)^{\Gamma_{m}^{n}}$ is of finite type over $R_{n, \text { red }}$, so $\left(S^{0}\right)^{\Gamma_{m}^{n}, \text { perf }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$. Since it represents a geometric quotient of $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{m, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}\right)$ by $\Gamma_{m}^{n}$ by Proposition 3.11, $S_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ is isomorphic to $\left(S^{0}\right)^{\Gamma_{m}^{n}, \text { perf }}$ by [Gle24, Lemma 2.26], Proposition 3.10 and [SW20, Proposition 18.3.1]. Thus, we get the claim.

Now, it follows from Proposition 2.11 that $S_{n}$ is reduced and excellent, topologically of finite type over $R_{n}$ and $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{n}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow U_{n}$ is an isomorphism. Since $S_{\infty}$ is distinguished, $S_{n}$ is distinguished by construction. Let $S=S_{0}$. By Lemma $5.24, S_{n}$ is integral over $S$. Since $R_{n}$ is a finite $R$-algebra, $S_{n}$ is topologically of finite type over $R$, so $S_{n}$ is finite over $S$.

By Lemma 5.11 and Lemma 5.13, we see that $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (quot), (density) and (unifsec). Thus, we see that $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a good cover.

Here, we record an explicit construction of $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ for a reference.

Corollary 5.28. In Theorem 5.19, $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ can be taken so that $S_{n}=\mathcal{O}\left(U_{n}\right) \cap S_{\infty}$ in $\mathcal{O}\left(U_{\infty}\right)$.
5.4. Maximal good covers. In this section, we study the properties of good covers satisfying the condition in Corollary 5.28. Here, we repeat the condition.
(maximal) $R_{\infty}$ is distinguished and $R_{n} \rightarrow R_{\infty} \cap \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is an isomorphism for every $n \geq 0$.
The intersection is taken inside $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$. Note that $R_{\infty} \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$ is an open immersion by Proposition 4.30 and $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is a closed immersion by the condition (unifsec).

Definition 5.29. A pair $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a maximal good cover of a reduced excellent distinguished complete adic ring $R$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ if it is a good cover satisfying (maximal).

We say that a subring $A$ of a ring $B$ in characteristic $p$ is purely inseparably integrally closed in $B$ if $x^{p} \in A$ implies $x \in A$ for every $x \in B$.

Lemma 5.30. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a maximal good cover of a reduced excellent distinguished complete adic ring $R$. For every $n \geq 0$, we have $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right) \subset R_{n} \subset \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$, $R_{n}$ is distinguished, and $R_{n, \text { red }}$ is purely inseparably integrally closed in $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}$.

Proof. The first claim follows from Proposition 4.30, and since $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$is $I$-torsion free, $R_{n}$ is $I$-torsion free. We prove the second claim. Let $x \in \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}$ be an element such that $x^{p} \in R_{n, \text { red }}$. Take an arbitrary lift $y \in \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$of $x$. Then, $y^{p} \in R_{n}$, so in particular, $y^{p} \in R_{\infty}$. Since $R_{\infty, \text { red }}$ is perfect, we have $y \in R_{\infty}$. Thus, $y \in R_{\infty} \cap \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)=R_{n}$ and $x \in R_{n, \text { red }}$.

Lemma 5.31. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a maximal good cover of a reduced excellent distinguished complete adic ring $R$. For every element $f \in R,\left(R_{\bullet}\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a maximal good cover of $R\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$. Here, $(-)^{\wedge}$ denotes the I-adic completion with $I \subset R$ an ideal of definition.

Proof. Let $R_{n}^{\prime}=R_{n}\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]^{\wedge}$. Since $R_{\infty}$ is thick, $R_{\infty}^{\prime}$ is thick. Let $R_{n}^{\prime \prime}=R_{\infty}^{\prime} \cap \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$. By applying Corollary 5.28 to $R_{\infty}^{\prime}$, we see that $\left(R_{\bullet}^{\prime \prime}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a maximal good cover. It is enough to show that a natural homomorphism $R_{n}^{\prime} \rightarrow R_{n}^{\prime \prime}$ is an isomorphism. By Lemma 5.30 and Lemma 2.6, we have $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{\infty}\right) \subset R_{n}^{\prime} \subset R_{n}^{\prime \prime} \subset \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)$.

Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right)$ are both geometric quotients of $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}^{\prime}\right)$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$ that are qcqs over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$, we have $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ by Proposition 3.10. In particular, $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime} \hookrightarrow R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime \prime}$ is an isomorphism up to perfection. Since we have $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime} \hookrightarrow R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime \prime} \hookrightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}$, it is enough to show that $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime}$ is purely inseparably integrally closed in $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}$.

By the proof of Lemma 2.6, $R_{n, \text { red }}^{\prime} \hookrightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}$ is isomorphic to $R_{n, \text { red }}\left[\frac{1}{f}\right] \hookrightarrow$ $\Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)_{\text {red }}\left[\frac{1}{f}\right]$. Thus, the claim follows from Lemma 5.30.

Thanks to Lemma 5.31, the following notion is purely local in the Zariski topology.

Definition 5.32. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent distinguished formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. We say that $\mathfrak{X}$ admits a maximal good cover if $\mathfrak{X}$ is Zariski locally isomorphic to the formal spectrum of a reduced excellent distinguished complete adic ring admitting a maximal good cover.

Lemma 5.33. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent distinguished formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ admitting a maximal good cover. Let $\mathfrak{Y}$ be a Noetherian formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ and let $f: \mathfrak{X}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}$ be a map over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)$ such that the restriction of $f$ to $\left(\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}\right)^{\circ}$ is represented by a morphism $g: \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{ad}}$ of adic spaces. Then, $f$ is represented by a unique morphism $\mathfrak{X} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}$ and its restriction to $\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}$ is equal to $g$.

Proof. By following the argument given in the proof of [AGLR22, Theorem 2.16], we may assume that $\mathfrak{X}$ and $\mathfrak{Y}$ are affine. Let $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ and $\mathfrak{Y}=\operatorname{Spf}(A)$ with $R$ a reduced excellent distinguished complete adic ring admitting a maximal good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$. By Proposition 4.27, the composition $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R) \xrightarrow{f} \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is represented by a continuous homomorphism $A \rightarrow R_{\infty}$. The induced morphism $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(A)$ is equal to the composition $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }} \xrightarrow{g} \operatorname{Spa}(A)$ since $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(A)$ is uniquely represented by a morphism $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}(A)$ as $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is a perfectoid space. In particular, $A$ maps to $R_{\infty} \cap \Gamma\left(\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right)=R$. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is surjective, this homomorphism $A \rightarrow R$ represents $f$. Since $R \rightarrow R_{\infty}$ is injective, the uniqueness of $f$ follows from Proposition 4.27. By construction, the restriction of $f$ to $\operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is equal to $g$.

As a corollary, we obtain a certain uniqueness of the representability of $v$-sheaves.
Corollary 5.34. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a Noetherian formal scheme and let $\mathfrak{Y}$ and $\mathfrak{Z}$ be reduced excellent distinguished formal schemes over $\mathfrak{X}$ admitting maximal good covers. Suppose that $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \rightarrow$ $\mathfrak{X}^{\text {ad }}$ and $\mathfrak{Z}^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\text {ad }}$ are open immersions of adic spaces and isomorphic to each other. Then, any isomorphism $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \cong \mathfrak{Z}^{\circ}$ over $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ is representable by a unique isomorphism $\mathfrak{Y} \cong \mathfrak{Z}$ over $\mathfrak{X}$.

Proof. Let $f: \mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Z}^{\circ}$ be an isomorphism over $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$. Since the restriction of $f$ to $\mathfrak{Y}^{\text {an }}$ is represented by $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \mathfrak{Z}^{\mathrm{an}} \hookrightarrow \mathfrak{Z}^{\mathrm{ad}}, f$ is uniquely represented by a morphism $f_{0}: \mathfrak{Y} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Z}$ lifting $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \mathfrak{Z}^{\mathrm{an}}$ by Lemma 5.33. Moreover, $f_{0}$ is a morphism over $\mathfrak{X}$ again by Lemma 5.33. By applying the same argument to the inverse of $f$, we obtain the inverse of $f_{0}$ over $\mathfrak{X}$ and we see that $f_{0}$ is an isomorphism.
5.5. Examples of $p$-adic formal schemes with maximal good covers. In this section, we present an example of $p$-adically complete rings admitting maximal good covers other than Proposition 5.9. The result of this section will not be used in the rest of the paper. In this section, the $p$-adic completion is denoted by $(-)^{\wedge}$.

Proposition 5.35. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent p-adically complete ring. Let $S$ be a ptorsion free finite type $R$-algebra that is integrally closed in $S\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ and $S\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is standard étale over $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$. If $R$ admits a good cover, $S^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.

Proof. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a good cover of $R$. For each $n \geq 0$, let $S_{n}$ be the integral closure of $S \otimes_{R} R_{n}$ in $\left(S \otimes_{R} R_{n}\right)_{\{p\}}^{[\underline{1}]}$. Since $S_{n}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is étale over $R_{n}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S_{n}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is reduced, so $S_{n}$ is a reduced finite $S$-algebra. We will show that $\left(S_{\bullet}^{\wedge}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a maximal good cover of $S^{\wedge}$.

Sine $S\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is standard étale over $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$, we may write as $S\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]=R[x]_{(p h)} /(g)$ with $g$ a monic polynomial in $R[x]$ and $h \in R[x]$ such that $g^{\prime}$ is invertible in $R[x]_{(p h)}$. We may assume that $x \in S$. Let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in S$ be a generator of $S$ as an $R$-algebra. For some $N \geq 0$, we have $(p h)^{N} f_{i} \in R[x] /(g)$ for every $1 \leq i \leq r$. Since $(p h)^{-N} \in S\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$, we may assume that $(p h)^{N} f_{1}$ is a power of $p$. Then, $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spa}\left(R[x]_{(p)} /(g), R[x] /(g)\right)$ is isomorphic to a rational localization $R\left(\frac{(p h)^{N} f_{1}, \ldots(p h)^{N} f_{r}}{(p h)^{N}}\right)$.

By [BS22, Theorem 10.11], $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \times{ }_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}(R[x] /(g))$ is represented by a perfectoid ring $R_{\infty}^{\prime}$. Then, $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S^{\wedge}\right) \times{ }_{\operatorname{Spd}(R[x] /(g))} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}^{\prime}\right)$ is represented by an affinoid perfectoid pair $\left(S_{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S_{\infty}\right)$ obtained as a rational localization $R_{\infty}^{\prime}\left\langle\frac{(p h)^{N} f_{1}, \ldots(p h)^{N} f_{r}}{(p h)^{S}}\right\rangle$. In particular, the pullback of an étale morphism $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], R\right)$ to $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], R_{\infty}\right)$ is represented by an affinoid perfectoid pair $\left(S_{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S_{\infty}\right)$.

Since (density) and (unifsec) are local by Lemma 5.13, we may argue as in Lemma 5.16 to show that we have a functorial and uniform family of continuous sections $\left\{s_{n, U_{n}}\right\}$ with the density condition. By setting $U_{n}=\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{n}^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S_{n}^{\wedge}\right)$, the density condition for $\left\{s_{n, U_{n}}\right\}$ implies that $S_{\infty}=\operatorname{colim}^{\wedge} S_{n}^{\wedge}$. In particular, we have the condition (perfd). The condition (quot) can be verified as in Lemma 5.16. By construction, $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ satisfies (maximal).

Let $E$ be a complete discrete valuation field over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ with perfect residue field and let $O_{E}$ be the ring of integers of $E$.

Corollary 5.36. Let $R$ be a p-torsion free normal finite type $O_{E}$-algebra. If $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is standard étale over a polynomial algebra over $E, R^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.

Proof. By assumption, there is a homomorphism $P \rightarrow R$ from a polynomial algebra $P$ over $O_{E}$ such that $P\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \rightarrow R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is standard étale. Thus, the claim follows from Proposition 5.5 and Proposition 5.35 .

For applications to integral models of Shimura varieties, it is natural to hope for a generalization to the case where $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is smooth over $E$. The main technical difficulty lies in the condition (unifsec). It implies that $\left(R^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], R^{\wedge}\right)$ is sousperfectoid in the sense of [HK22], but it is not known yet whether every smooth affinoid $E$-algebra is sousperfectoid. Here, we record some weaker results.

Corollary 5.37. Let $R$ be a p-torsion free normal finite type $O_{E}$-algebra. If $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is smooth over $E$, there is a proper morphism $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ such that $Y\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \cong \operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]\right)$ and $Y^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.

Proof. We can take a set of elements $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in p R$ so that $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]\right)$ is covered by $D\left(f_{i}\right)$ for $1 \leq i \leq r$ and each $D\left(f_{i}\right)$ is standard étale over a polynomial algebra over $E$. Let $Y \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ be the blowup along $V\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right)$ and let $Y^{+}$be the normalization of $Y$ in $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]\right)$. Let $V_{i}^{+} \subset Y^{+}$be the locus where $f_{i}$ divides $f_{j}$ for $1 \leq j \leq r$. We have $V_{i}^{+}[\frac{1}{p}]=D\left(f_{i}\right)$, so $\left(V_{i}^{+}\right)^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover by Corollary 5.36. Thus, $\left(Y^{+}\right)^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.

Corollary 5.38. Let $R$ be a p-torsion free normal domain of finite type over $O_{E}$. If $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is smooth over $E$, and $R / p R$ and $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ are of the same dimension, there is a nonempty open subset $U \subset \operatorname{Spec}(R / p R)$ such that $\operatorname{Spec}(R)_{/ U}^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.

Proof. We can take an affine open subset $V \subset \operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]\right)$ that is standard étale over an affine space over $E$. Let $Z$ be the Zariski closure of $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]\right)-V$ in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$. Since $R / p R$ is of the same dimension as $R\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], Z \otimes_{O_{E}}\left(O_{E} / p O_{E}\right)$ has a strictly smaller dimension than $\operatorname{Spec}(R / p R)$. In particular, $\operatorname{Spec}(R / p R)-Z$ is nonempty. Thus, we can take a distinguished open subset $D_{f} \subset \operatorname{Spec}(R)-Z$ such that $D_{f} \cap \operatorname{Spec}(R / p R)$ is nonempty. By construction, $D_{f}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is standard étale over an affine space over $E$, so $D_{f}^{\wedge}$ admits a maximal good cover.
5.6. Relative representablity. The aim of this section is to prove our main representability criterion by showing that the construction in Corollary 5.28 can be glued in the Zariski topology.

We say that a perfect scheme $X$ over an affine perfect scheme $\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is perfectly quasiprojective over $A$ if $X$ is perfectly of finite type over $A$ and admits an ample line bundle.

Proposition 5.39. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent formal scheme over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ admitting a good cover. Let $Y \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ be a quasiseparated map of small $v$-sheaves. Let $U \subset \mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}$ be a quasicompact open immersion with a lift $U^{\circ} \rightarrow Y$. Suppose that the following condition holds.

For every complete adic perfectoid ring $R$ with an adic morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(R) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$, there is a unique distinguished perfectoid formal $R$-scheme $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ over $Y$ such that $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ is adic over $R, \mathfrak{Y}_{R}^{\text {red }}$ is perfectly quasi-projective over $R_{\text {red }}, \mathfrak{Y}_{R}^{\circ} \rightarrow$ $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is a closed immersion and there is an isomorphism $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong$ $U \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ that represents the base change of $U^{\circ} \rightarrow Y$ to $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$.
Then, the $v$-closure of $U^{\circ}$ in $Y$ is representable by a unique reduced excellent distinguished formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover with $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong U$. Moreover, $\mathfrak{Y}$ is separated and topologically of finite type over $\mathfrak{X}$.

Remark 5.40. The uniqueness of $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ is a mild condition. For example, if $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is a kimberlite, $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ represents the thick closure of $U \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\mathrm{an}}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$ in $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ and the uniqueness follows from Proposition 4.27.

Proof. First, suppose that $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ where $R$ admits a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$ be the unique perfectoid formal $R_{\infty}$-formal scheme over $Y$ satisfying the given condition. For every $\gamma \in \Gamma_{\infty}, \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty} \otimes_{R_{\infty}, \gamma} R_{\infty}$ also satisfies the given condition, so there is a unique isomorphism $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty} \otimes_{R_{\infty}, \gamma} R_{\infty} \cong \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$. Thus, we have an action of $\Gamma_{\infty}$ on $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$.

Since $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\text {red }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{\infty, \text { red }}$, we can take a finite cover $\left\{\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ of $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$. Let $U_{n}=U \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{m}} \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$ and $V_{\infty, i}=\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}^{\text {an }} \subset \operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Then, $\left\{V_{\infty, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ is a finite cover of $U_{\infty}$. By [Sch17, Lemma 12.17], that cover can be defined over $U_{m}$ for sufficiently large $m \geq 0$. In particular, $V_{\infty, i}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}^{m}$ for every $i \in I$. Since $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}$ is distinguished, we see by looking at the specialization map that $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}$ is also stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}^{m}$. Thus, we may apply Theorem 5.19 to $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}$ and obtain a maximal good cover $\left(S_{\bullet, i}, \Gamma_{\bullet}^{m}\right)_{\bullet \geq m}$ by Corollary 5.28 .

We show that the collection $\left\{\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{m, i}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}$ can be glued to a formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$. For every $i, j \in I, \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}^{m}$. Since $\left(S_{m, i}\right)_{\text {red }}^{\text {perf }} \rightarrow\left(S_{\infty, i}\right)_{\text {red }}$ is integral, $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{\infty, i}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{m, i}\right)$ is closed, so there is an open subspace $W_{m, i}^{j} \subset \operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{m, i}\right)$ whose pullback $W_{\infty, i}^{j} \subset \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}$ equals $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$. Similarly, there is an open subspace $W_{m, j}^{i} \subset$ $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{m, j}\right)$ whose pullback $W_{\infty, j}^{i} \subset \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$ equals $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$. By construction, $W_{m, i}^{j}$ and $W_{m, j}^{i}$ admit maximal good covers, and $W_{m, i}^{j, \text { an }} \cong W_{m, j}^{i, \text { an }}$ as open subspaces of $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R_{n}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Moreover, $\left(W_{m, i}^{j}\right)^{\circ}$ and $\left(W_{m, j}^{i}\right)^{\circ}$ are geometric quotients of $\left(\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}\right)^{\circ}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{m}$ that are qcqs over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$, so we have $\left(W_{m, i}^{j}\right)^{\circ} \cong\left(W_{m, j}^{i}\right)^{\circ}$ by Proposition 3.10. It follows from Corollary 5.34 that there is a unique isomorphism $W_{m, i}^{j} \cong W_{m, j}^{i}$ of formal schemes compatible with the isomorphisms on the analytic loci and the $v$-sheafifications. Thus, we obtain a formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$ by gluing the affine formal schemes $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{m, i}\right)$ for $i \in I$.

By construction, $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ}$ is a geometric quotient of $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\circ}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{m}$ that is qcqs over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$. Since $Y$ is quasiseparated over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$, we obtain a map $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ} \rightarrow Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ by Proposition 3.10. By Corollary $5.25, \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ} \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is surjective. It is also injective since $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\circ} \rightarrow Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ factors through $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ} \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$. Thus, the base change of $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ} \rightarrow Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ to $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is a closed immersion, so it is a closed immersion itself by [Sch17, Proposition 10.11]. By construction, $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\text {an }} \cong U_{m}$ and $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$ is distinguished, so $U_{m}^{\circ}$ is dense in $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}^{\circ}$ by Lemma 3.7. Thus, the $v$-closure of $U_{m}$ in $Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{m}\right)$ is representable by $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$. By Theorem $5.19, \mathfrak{Y}_{m}$ admits a maximal good cover and is topologically of finite type over $R_{m}$. Moreover, since $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$ is quasi-projective over $R_{\text {red }}$, and in particular, separated, $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$ is affine. By applying Theorem 5.19 to $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i} \cap \mathfrak{V}_{\infty, j}$, we see that $W_{m, i}^{j}$ is affine for every $i, j \in I$ and $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$ is separated. The uniqueness of $\mathfrak{Y}_{m}$ follows from Corollary 5.34 .

Now, we will show that we can take $m=0$ if we choose a suitable finite cover $\left\{\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. It is enough to choose so that each $\mathfrak{V}_{\infty, i}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}$. Since $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty, \text { red }}$ is perfectly quasiprojective over $R_{\infty, \text { red }}, \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty, \text { red }}$ admits an ample line bundle. Since $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty, \text { red }}=\lim _{n \geq m} \mathfrak{Y}_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$,

that line bundle can be defined over $\mathfrak{Y}_{n, \text { red }}^{\text {perf }}$ for sufficiently large $n \geq m$. Then, $\mathfrak{Y}_{n, \text { red }}$ is quasiprojective over $R_{\text {red }}$, so any $\Gamma_{n}$-orbit of $\mathfrak{Y}_{n, \text { red }}$ admits a $\Gamma_{n}$-stable affine open neighborhood. In particular, $\mathfrak{Y}_{n}$ admits a $\Gamma_{n}$-stable finite affine covering. Its pullback to $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$ yields a desired $\Gamma_{\infty}$-stable finite affine covering.

Finally, we treat the general case. Take an affine covering of $\mathfrak{X}$ by $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $R$ admitting a good cover. The $v$-closure of $U^{\circ} \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{0}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ in $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{0}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is representable by a unique reduced excellent distinguished formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ admitting a maximal good cover with $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}^{\text {an }} \cong U \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}} \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\text {an }}$. By the uniqueness of $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$, the collection $\left\{\mathfrak{Y}_{R}\right\}$ can be glued to a formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ over $\mathfrak{X}$. It is easy to see that $\mathfrak{Y}$ satisfies the desired condition.

Remark 5.41. If $U=\mathfrak{X}^{\text {an }}, \mathfrak{Y}$ is automatically proper by Lemma 2.14. In addition, if $\mathfrak{X}$ is locally monogeneous, e.g. if $\mathfrak{X}$ is $p$-adic, $\mathfrak{Y} \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$ is a formal modification by Proposition 2.18.

Remark 5.42. As seen from the proof, when $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ where $R$ admits a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$, we only need the existence of $\mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}}$ to show the existence of $\mathfrak{Y}$. Moreover, if $Y^{\text {red }}$ is representable by a separated perfectly finite type perfect $R_{\text {red }}$-scheme, we do not need the quasi-projectivity assumption since an affine covering of $Y^{\text {red }}$ yields a $\Gamma_{\infty}$-stable affine covering of $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$.

The following corollary shows the representability of $v$-sheaf theoretic modifications.
Corollary 5.43. Let $R$ be a reduced excellent complete adic ring admitting a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$. Let $Y$ be a thick prekimberlite formally adic over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ with $Y^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$. Suppose that $Y^{\text {red }}$ is perfectly of finite type over $R_{\text {red }}$ and $Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is representable by a perfectoid formal scheme adic over $R_{\infty}$. Then, $Y$ is representable by a unique proper formal $R$-scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover with $\mathfrak{Y}^{\mathrm{an}} \cong \operatorname{Spa}(R)^{\mathrm{an}}$.

Proof. Since $Y$ is formally separated, $Y^{\text {red }}$ is separated. By Remark 5.42, it is enough to check the condition for $R_{\infty}$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$ be the perfectoid formal scheme representing $Y \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)}$ $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$. It is enough to show that $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$ is thick. By Proposition 4.27, $\Gamma_{\infty}$ acts on $\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}$. The open subspace $V=\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\text {red }}-\operatorname{sp}_{\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}}\left(\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\text {an }}\right) \subset \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\text {red }}$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}$. By construction, $V^{\circ} \subset \mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\circ}$ is open and stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}$. Let $V_{0} \subset|Y|$ be the image of $V^{\circ}$. By [Sch17, Proposition 12.9], $\left|\mathfrak{Y}_{\infty}^{\circ}\right| \rightarrow|Y|$ is a quotient map, so $V_{0}$ is open. By construction, $V_{0}^{\text {red }} \cap \operatorname{sp}_{Y}\left(Y^{\text {an }}\right)=\phi$, so $V_{0}^{\text {red }}$ is empty as $Y$ is thick. Since there is a map $V \rightarrow V_{0}^{\text {red }}$, we see that $V$ is empty.
5.7. Variant. In this section, we provide another form of our relative representability criterion that is suitable for application. Here, we only deal with $p$-adic formal schemes. For a $v$ sheaf $X$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right), X_{\eta}$ denotes $X \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Q}_{p}, \mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)$ and $X_{s}$ denotes $X \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{F}_{p}\right)$. Recall the notation in Section 3.1 and Section 4.2.

Proposition 5.44. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent $p$-adic formal scheme admitting a good cover. Let $Y \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ be a quasiseparated map of small $v$-sheaves. Let $Z \subset Y_{\eta}$ be a closed subsheaf that is finite étale over $\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}$. Suppose that the following condition holds.

For every perfectoid ring $R$ with $\operatorname{Spf}(R) \rightarrow \mathfrak{X}$, there is a perfectly proper $R^{\circ}$ scheme $Y_{R^{\circ}}$ and a finite étale $R^{\mathrm{e}}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]$-scheme $Z_{R^{\mathrm{e}}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]}$ with a morphism $Z_{R^{\mathrm{e}}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]} \rightarrow Y_{R^{\mathrm{e}}}$ such that we have the following commutative diagram
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
that is compatible with tilting equivalence $\operatorname{Spd}(R) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{\mathrm{e}}\right)$.
Then, $Z^{\mathrm{cl}}$ is representable by a unique reduced excellent distinguished p-adic formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover that is proper over $\mathfrak{X}$ with $\mathfrak{Y}_{\eta}$ finite étale over $\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}$.

Proof. First, suppose that $\mathfrak{X}=\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ with $R$ admitting a good cover $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$. Let $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ be the scheme-theoretic image of $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}\left[1 / \xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}\right]} \rightarrow Y_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ (resp. $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ ) be the $\xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}$-adic completion of $Y_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ (resp. $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ ). Since $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ is $\xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}$-torsion free, $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ is distinguished. Thus, $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ is thick by Lemma 3.6. Let $\mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}}$ (resp. $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}$ ) be the untilt of $\mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ (resp. $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}$ ) over $R_{\infty}$ (see Proposition 4.24). Then, $\mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}}$ represents $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ and $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\circ} \subset \mathfrak{Y}_{R_{\infty}}^{\circ}$ is a thick closed subsheaf. We will show that $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}, \eta}$ represents $Z \times_{\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}$.

By Lemma 3.2, we have $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}^{\diamond, \text { an }} \cong Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\infty}^{\circ}\right)^{\diamond}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}^{\diamond}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\infty}^{\circ}\right)^{\diamond}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}^{\diamond}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong$ $\left(Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}\left[1 / \xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}\right]\right)^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(R_{\infty}^{\circ}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]\right)^{\diamond}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}^{\diamond}\right)^{\text {an }}$. Since $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]} \rightarrow Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}\left[1 / \xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}\right]^{\diamond}$ is finite and surjective, $Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]}^{\diamond} \rightarrow Z_{R_{\infty}^{\circ}}\left[1 / \xi_{R_{\infty}, 0}\right]^{\diamond}$ is surjective on geometric points. In particular, $Z \times_{\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }} \rightarrow \mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}, \eta}^{\diamond}$ is surjective on geometric points. Since $Z \subset Y_{\eta}$, it is also injective, so $Z \times_{\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }} \cong \mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}, \eta}^{\diamond}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}$ represents the thick closure of $Z \times_{\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)^{\text {an }}$ in $Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$.

By the uniqueness of thick closures, $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\diamond} \subset Y \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ is stable under $\Gamma_{\infty}$. Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ is proper (as in Lemma 5.4), the image $Z^{\text {int }} \subset Y$ of $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\diamond}$ under the projection to $Y$ is closed. By Lemma 3.17, we have $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\diamond} \cong Z^{\text {int }} \times_{\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right)$ and $Z^{\text {int }}$ is a geometric quotient of $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\diamond}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}$.

Let $R^{+} \subset R_{(\underline{p})}^{[\underline{1}]}$ be the integral closure of $R$. Since $Z$ is finite étale over $\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\diamond}$, there is a unique finite étale homomorphism $\left(R_{p}^{[\underline{1}]} ; R^{+}\right) \rightarrow\left(S^{+}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S^{+}\right)$such that $Z \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(S^{+}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S^{+}\right)$ by [Sch17, Lemma 15.6]. Let $\left(R_{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], R_{\infty}^{+}\right) \rightarrow\left(S_{\infty}^{+}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right], S_{\infty}^{+}\right)$be the base change of the finite étale homomorphism. By Proposition 4.30, we have $\left(S_{\infty}^{+}\right)^{\diamond \circ} \subset \Gamma\left(\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}, \mathcal{O}\right) \subset S_{\infty}^{+}$. Let $S_{0}=R+\left(S^{+}\right)^{\diamond \circ} \subset S^{+}$. Since $R$ is reduced and excellent, $S^{+}$is finite over $R$ and $S_{0}$ is finite over $R$. Moreover, we have a $\Gamma_{\infty}$-invariant morphism $\mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{0}\right)$, so by Proposition 3.10, we get a morphism $Z^{\text {int }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{0}\right)$. By the proof of Lemma 5.17, the reduction of $\left(S_{0} \otimes_{R} R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a good cover and let $S_{\infty}$ be as in the condition (perfd). Since $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{\infty}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{0}\right)$, we have $Z^{\text {int }} \times_{\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{0}\right)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \mathfrak{Z}_{R_{\infty}}^{\diamond}$. By

Remark 5.42, the proof of Proposition 5.39 applies to $Z^{\text {int }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{0}\right)$ and we obtain the desired representability.

As in Corollary 5.34, the uniqueness of $\mathfrak{Y}$ follows from Lemma 5.33 thanks to [Sch17, Lemma 15.6]. Thus, in the general case, we can glue $\mathfrak{Y}_{R}$ for each $\operatorname{Spf}(R) \hookrightarrow \mathfrak{X}$ as above and the claim follows.

# 6. APPLICATIONS TO LOCAL SHTUKAS 

6.1. Local shtukas. In this section, we set up some notation and recall the definition of local shtukas introduced in [SW20].

Let $F$ be a non-archimedean local field over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ and let $O_{F}$ be the ring of integers of $F$ with a residue field $k$. Let $\pi$ be a uniformizer of $F$ and let $q$ be the number of elements of $k$. For a perfect $k$-algebra $R$, we set $W_{O_{F}}(R)=W(R) \otimes_{W(k)} O_{F}$.

Let $S=\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$be an affinoid perfectoid space over $k$ and let $\varpi \in R^{+}$be a pseudouniformizer. We set $\mathcal{Y}_{S}=\operatorname{Spa}\left(W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{+}\right)\right)-V([\varpi])$. It is an analytic adic space (see [FS21, Proposition II.1.1]). Let $\mathcal{Y}_{S,[0, n]} \subset \mathcal{Y}_{S}$ be the locus $\left\{\left|\pi^{n}\right| \leq|[\varpi]| \neq 0\right\}$ for a positive integer $n$. By the proof of [SW20, Proposition II.1.1], $\mathcal{Y}_{S,[0, n]}=\operatorname{Spa}\left(B_{S,[0, n]}, B_{S,[0, n]}^{+}\right) \subset \mathcal{Y}_{S}$ is an affinoid open subspace and the $p$-adic completion $B_{S,[0, n]}^{\wedge}$ of $B_{S,[0, n]}$ is isomorphic to $W_{O_{F}}(R)$. By [FS21, Proposition II.1.3], we can glue this construction analytic locally and obtain an analytic adic space $\mathcal{Y}_{S}$ for every perfectoid space $S$ over $k$.

Let $G$ be a connected reductive group over $F$ and let $\mathcal{G}$ be a parahoric group scheme of $G$ over $O_{F}$.

Definition 6.1. ([SW20, Section 23.1]) Let $S$ be a perfectoid space over $k$. A local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $S$ is a tuple $\left(\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right), \mathcal{P}, \varphi_{\mathcal{P}}\right)$ such that $\left(S^{\sharp}, \iota\right) \in \operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)(S)$ is an untilt of $S$ over $O_{F}, \mathcal{P}$ is a $\mathcal{G}$-torsor over $\mathcal{Y}_{S}$ and $\varphi_{\mathcal{P}}: \varphi^{*} \mathcal{P}\left|_{\mathcal{Y}_{S} \backslash S^{\sharp}} \cong \mathcal{P}\right|_{\mathcal{Y}_{S} \backslash S^{\sharp}}$ is an isomorphism of $\mathcal{G}$-torsors meromorphic along $S^{\sharp}$.

Let $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ be the $v$-site of perfectoid spaces over $k$. The functor taking a perfectoid space $S$ over $k$ to the groupoid of local $\mathcal{G}$-shtukas over $S$ is a $v$-stack on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ by [SW20, Proposition 19.5.3] and denoted by $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}$ (cf. [SW20, Definition 23.1.1]). There is a natural map $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$ of $v$-stacks on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$. Note that a $v$-stack on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ is identified with a $v$-stack on Perf with a map to $\operatorname{Spd}(k)$. For a $v$-stack $X$ on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$, we say that a map $X \rightarrow \operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}$ of $v$-stacks on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ is a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $X$. For a $v$-stack $X$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$, we say that a map $X \rightarrow \operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}$ of $v$-stacks over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{F}\right)$ is a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $X_{/ O_{F}}$.
Proposition 6.2. Let $\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}$ be the functor taking an affinoid perfectoid space $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$ over $k$ to the group $\mathcal{G}\left(W_{O_{F}}(R)\right)$. It is a small $v$-sheaf on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ and there is a natural map $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \rightarrow\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ of $v$-stacks on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$. Here, $*$ denotes the $v$-sheaf $\operatorname{Spd}(k)$.
Proof. Since $\mathcal{G}$ is affine, $\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}$ is a small $v$-sheaf on $\operatorname{Perf}_{k}$ by [Sch17, Theorem 8.7]. The quotient $v$-stack $\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ classifies the set of $\mathcal{G}$-torsors on $\operatorname{Spec}\left(W_{O_{F}}(R)\right)$ over an affinoid

perfectoid space $S=\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$over $k$ since $\mathcal{G}$-torsors on $W_{O_{F}}(R)$ satisfy $v$-descent by [SW20, Corollary 17.1.9]. As in [SW20, Section 20.3], we obtain a map $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \rightarrow\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ by pulling back $\mathcal{G}$-torsors on $\mathcal{Y}_{S,[0, n]}$ to $W_{O_{F}}(R)$.

Let $R$ be a perfectoid ring over $O_{F}$. The Frobenius map on $W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{\mathrm{s}}\right)$ is denoted by $\varphi_{R}$. By [Ito23b, Lemma 2.4.2], the kernel of the surjection $\theta_{R}: W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{\mathrm{s}}\right) \rightarrow R$ is principal. By an abuse of notation, a generator of $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\theta_{R}\right)$ is also denoted by $\xi_{R}$. The image of $\xi_{R}$ under the projection $W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{\mathrm{s}}\right) \rightarrow R^{\mathrm{s}}$ is denoted by $\xi_{R, 0}$.
Definition 6.3. A $\mathcal{G}$-Breuil-Kisin-Fargues ( $\mathcal{G}$-BKF) module over a perfectoid ring $R$ over $O_{F}$ is a pair $\left(P, \varphi_{P}\right)$ such that $P$ is a $\mathcal{G}$-torsor over $W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{\mathrm{s}}\right)$ and $\varphi_{P}$ is an isomorphism $\left(\varphi_{R}^{*} P\right)\left[1 / \xi_{R}\right] \cong P\left[1 / \xi_{R}\right]$
Proposition 6.4. ([Gü23], [GI23]) For a perfectoid ring $R$ over $O_{F}$, the category of local $\mathcal{G}$-shtukas over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)_{/ O_{F}}$ is equivalent to the category of $\mathcal{G}$-BKF modules over $R$.
6.2. Level structures. In this section, we introduce parahoric level structures on local shtukas. Let $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$ be another parahoric group scheme of $G$ over $O_{F}$ with a morphism $\mathcal{G}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}$ over $O_{F}$. It corresponds to a parahoric subgroup $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}\left(O_{F}\right) \subset \mathcal{G}\left(O_{F}\right)$.
Lemma 6.5. For a p-torsion free $O_{F}$-algebra $A$, we have $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathcal{G}(A) \rightarrow \mathcal{G}(A / \pi A)\right) \subset \mathcal{G}^{\prime}(A)$.
Proof. Let $\mathcal{G}_{1}$ be the first congruence group scheme of $\mathcal{G}$ as in [KP23, Definition A.5.12]. Since $A$ is $p$-torsion free, we have $\mathcal{G}_{1}(A)=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathcal{G}(A) \rightarrow \mathcal{G}(A / \pi A)\right)$. We show that there is a morphism $\mathcal{G}_{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}^{\prime}$ over $O_{F}$. Let $\bar{F}$ be the completion of the maximal unramified extension of $F$ and let $O_{\bar{F}}$ be the ring of integers in $\bar{F}$. By [KP23, Corollary 2.10.10], it is enough to show that $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathcal{G}\left(O_{\bar{F}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{G}\left(O_{\bar{F}} / \pi O_{\bar{F}}\right)\right) \subset \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\left(O_{\bar{F}}\right)$. The claim follows from [KP23, Corollary 8.4.12, Corollary 8.4.13].

Definition 6.6. Let $H_{1} \rightarrow H_{2}$ be a homomorphism of group schemes over a scheme $S$ and let $P_{2}$ be an $H_{2}$-torsor over $S$. An $H_{1}$-subtorsor of $P_{2}$ over $S$ is a pair $\left(P_{1}, \iota\right)$ such that $P_{1}$ is an $H_{1}$-torsor over $S$ and $\iota$ is an isomorphism $P_{1} \times{ }^{H_{1}} H_{2} \cong P_{2}$ of $H_{2}$-torsors.

For a section $s: S \rightarrow P_{2}$, we say that the $H_{1}$-subtorsor $\left(H_{1}, s \cdot(-): H_{2} \cong P_{2}\right)$ is the $H_{1}$-subtorsor generated by $s$. For any $h_{1} \in H_{1}(S)$, the $H_{1}$-subtorsor generated by $s \cdot h_{1}$ is isomorphic to the $H_{1}$-subtorsor generated by $s$.

By [KP23, Theorem 8.4.19 (2)], the image of $\mathcal{G}_{k}^{\prime}$ in $\mathcal{G}_{k}$ is a parabolic subgroup of $\mathcal{G}_{k}$. Let $\mathcal{H} \subset \mathcal{G}_{k}$ be the parabolic subgroup.
Lemma 6.7. Let $A$ be a p-torsion free and p-complete $O_{F}$-algebra and let $P$ be a $\mathcal{G}$-torsor over $A$. There is a natural bijection between the set of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsors of $P$ and the set of $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsors of $P_{A / \pi A}$.

Proof. The one direction is clear by taking the base change to $A / \pi A$. Suppose that we have an $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsor of $P_{A / \pi A}$. Since $A$ is $p$-torsion free, there are no nontrivial automorphisms of

$\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsors of $P$, so we may $p$-completely étale locally localize $A$. Thus, we may assume that $P$ is trivial and the $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsor of $P_{A / \pi A}$ is generated by the reduction of an element $x \in P(A)$. It is enough to show that the $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor generated by $x$ is independent of the choice of $x$. Let $x^{\prime} \in P(A)$ be another choice. The reduction of $x^{-1} x^{\prime}$ to $A / \pi A$ lies in $\mathcal{H}(A / \pi A)$. Now, the map $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}(A) \rightarrow \mathcal{H}(A / \pi A)$ is surjective because $\mathcal{G}(A) \rightarrow \mathcal{G}(A / \pi A)$ is surjective and $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$ is the dilatation (see [KP23, Section A.5]) of $\mathcal{G}$ along $\mathcal{H}$ by [KP23, Corollary 2.10.10] and [KP23, Theorem 8.4.19 (3)]. Thus, we may assume that the reduction of $x^{-1} x^{\prime}$ is trivial. Then, we have $x^{-1} x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{G}^{\prime}(A)$ by Lemma 6.5.

The following lemma is the basis of the representability of the moduli of subtorsors.
Lemma 6.8. Let $k$ be a field. Let $G$ be a connected linear algebraic group over $k$ and let $H$ be a parabolic subgroup of $G$. Let $R$ be a $k$-algebra and let $P$ be a $G$-torsor over $R$. The quotient fpqc sheaf $P / H$ is representable by a projective $R$-scheme.

Proof. Since the unipotent radical of $G$ is contained in $H$, we may assume that $G$ is reductive. A regular dominant cocharacter $\lambda$ of $H$ defines a $G$-equivariant ample line bundle $O(\lambda)$ on $G / H$. Take an étale $R$-algebra $R^{\prime}$ so that $P_{R^{\prime}} \cong G_{R^{\prime}}$. It gives a 1-cocycle valued in $G$ and it induces an étale descent datum $\left((G / H)_{R^{\prime}}, O(\lambda)\right)$ corresponding to $P / H$. Since $O(\lambda)$ is ample, it is effective (see [BLR90, Theorem 7]).

Definition 6.9. Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka on a $v$-stack $X$. A $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure on $\mathcal{P}$ is a commutative diagram
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

In other words, it consists of a local $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-shtuka $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ with an isomorphism $\mathcal{P}^{\prime} \times{ }^{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \mathcal{G} \cong \mathcal{P}$.
We have the following commutative diagram by Proposition 6.2.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Lemma 6.10. The following holds in the above diagram.
(1) $\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right] \rightarrow\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ is separated.
(2) $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta}$ is finite étale over $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}$ and locally isomorphic to the set $\mathcal{G}\left(O_{F}\right) / \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\left(O_{F}\right)$.
(3) $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, s}$ is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, s} \times_{\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]}\left[*/\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$.

Proof. By Lemma 6.7 and Lemma 6.8, the fiber $* \times_{\left[\star /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]}\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ is represented by the projective $k$-scheme $\mathcal{G}_{k} / \mathcal{H}$. The claim (1) follows from the $v$-descent of separatedness in [Sch17, Proposition 10.11].

Let $S$ be a perfectoid space over $F$ and let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $S_{/ O_{F}}$. By [SW20, Proposition 22.6.1], there is a pro-étale $\mathcal{G}\left(O_{F}\right)$-torsor $\mathbb{P}$ over $S$ corresponding to $\mathcal{P}$. The fiber product $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}} S$ is represented by the finite étale covering $\mathbb{P} / \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\left(O_{F}\right)$ of $S$. This proves (2).

On the other hand, let $S=\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$be an affinoid perfectoid space over $k$ and let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $S$. For every $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ of $\mathcal{P}$ on $\mathcal{Y}_{S}$, the Frobenius of $\mathcal{P}$ gives the structure of a local $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-sthuka on $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$. Since the map $\mathcal{P}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{P}$ is an isomorphism after inverting $p$, we see by applying the Beuville-Laszlo lemma (in the form of [SW20, Lemma 5.2.9]) to $B_{S,[0, n]}$ that $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ is determined by the restriction to $W_{O_{F}}(R)$. Thus, we have (3).

Proposition 6.11. The $v$-stack $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}}$ is a closed substack of $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \times_{\left[\star /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]}\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$.
Proof. Let $S=\operatorname{Spa}\left(R, R^{+}\right)$be an affinoid perfectoid space over $k$ with an untilt $S^{\sharp}=$ $\operatorname{Spa}\left(R^{\sharp}, R^{+}\sharp\right)$ over $O_{F}$. Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $S_{/ O_{F}}^{\sharp}$. A $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ on $\mathcal{P}$ is determined by the corresponding $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor on $\mathcal{Y}_{S,[0, n]}$. By the same argument as in Lemma 6.10, we see that $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ is determined by the restriction to $W_{O_{F}}(R)$ and $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}}$ is a substack of $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \times_{\left[\star /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]}\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$. We show that it is a closed substack.

A section of $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}} \times_{\left[\star /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right]}\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right]$ over $S^{\sharp}$ corresponds to a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ of $\mathcal{P}$ by the Beuville-Laszlo lemma. We determine when its pullback along a map $T=\operatorname{Spa}\left(A, A^{+}\right) \rightarrow$ $S$ factors through $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}}$. Since $\varphi_{\mathcal{P}}$ is meromorphic along $S^{\sharp}$, its pullback to $\mathcal{Y}_{T,[0, n]}$ is given by an isomorphism $\left.\left(\varphi^{*} \mathcal{P}\right)\right|_{B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]} \cong \mathcal{P}\left|{ }_{B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right.}\right|$. The $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ defines a local $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-shtuka over $T$ if and only if $\left.\varphi_{\mathcal{P}}\right|_{B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]}$ induces an isomorphism $\left.\left(\varphi^{*} \mathcal{P}^{\prime}\right)\right|_{B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]} \cong$ $\left.\mathcal{P}^{\prime}\right|_{B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]}$. By applying the Beauville-Laszlo lemma to $B_{T,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]$, it can be written as a condition that two $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsors of $\mathcal{P}$ are equal over the $p$-adic completion of $W_{O_{F}}(A)\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]$. Now, we have $W_{O_{F}}(A)\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right] /(\pi) \cong A\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. Let $P$ be a $\mathcal{G}$-torsor over $R$ corresponding to $\left.\mathcal{P}\right|_{S}$. By Lemma 6.7, $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsors of $\mathcal{P}$ over the $p$-adic completion of $W_{O_{F}}(A)\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]$ correspond to $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsors of $P \otimes_{R} A\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. By Lemma 6.8, they correspond to sections of $P / \mathcal{H}$ over $A\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. Now, through the isomorphism $\left.\left(\varphi^{*} \mathcal{P}\right)\right|_{B_{S,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]} \cong$ $\left.\mathcal{P}\right|_{B_{S,[0, n]}\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}}\right]}$, each of $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ and $\varphi^{*} \mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ corresponds to a section of $P / \mathcal{H}$ over $R\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. Since $P / \mathcal{H}$ is separated, the equalizer locus of the two sections is the zero locus of an ideal $I \subset R\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. Let $J \subset R$ be an ideal such that $I=J\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$. Since $A$ is perfect, the composition $R \rightarrow A \rightarrow A\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right]$ factors through $R\left[1 / \xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0}\right] / I$ if and only if $\xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0} \cdot J \subset \operatorname{Ker}(R \rightarrow A)$. Thus, the locus where $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ defines a local $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-shtuka is a Zariski closed subset of $S$ given by the ideal $\xi_{S^{\sharp}, 0} \cdot J$.

We can check that the condition in Proposition 5.44 holds in the following situation.

Proposition 6.12. Let $R$ be a perfectoid ring and let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)_{/ O_{F}}$. There is a perfectly projective $R^{e}$-scheme $Y$ and a finite étale $R^{b}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]$-scheme $Z$ with a morphism $Z \rightarrow Y$ such that we have the following commutative diagram
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)
that is compatible with tilting equivalence $\operatorname{Spd}(R) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{b}\right)$.
Proof. By Proposition 6.4, $\mathcal{P}$ is given by a $\mathcal{G}$-BKF module $P$ over $R$. Let $Y=\left(P \otimes_{W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{b}\right)}\right.$ $\left.R^{b}\right) / \mathcal{H}$. By Lemma 6.8, $Y$ is projective over $R^{b}$. For each perfect $R^{b}$-algebra $A, Y(A)$ classifies the set of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsors of $P \otimes_{W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{b}\right)} W_{O_{F}}(A)$ by Lemma 6.7. Thus, we see from Lemma 3.2 that $Y^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(R^{b}\right)^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{b}\right) \cong Y^{\diamond} \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(R^{b}\right)^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{b}\right)$ is isomorphic to $\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right] \times_{\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right], \mathcal{P}}$ $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$.

By Lemma 6.10, $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}, \mathcal{P}_{\eta}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$ is finite étale over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$. Let $R^{b,+} \subset$ $R^{b}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]$ be the integral closure of $R^{b}$ inside $R^{b}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right]$. By [Sch17, Lemma 15.6], there is a unique finite étale homomorphism $\left(R^{b}\left[1 / \xi_{R, 0}\right], R^{b,+}\right) \rightarrow\left(S, S^{+}\right)$such that $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S, S^{+}\right) \cong$ $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}, \mathcal{P}_{\eta}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)^{\text {an }}$ under tilting equivalence. Let $Z=\operatorname{Spec}(S)$. By construction, we have a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ of $\mathcal{P}$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S, S^{+}\right)$. By restricting to $W_{O_{F}}(S), \mathcal{P}^{\prime}$ gives a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor of $P \otimes_{W_{O_{F}}\left(R^{b}\right)} W_{O_{F}}(S)$. By the above argument, it corresponds to a morphism $Z \rightarrow Y$ and this morphism makes the given diagram commute by construction.

Now, we can define the flat moduli space of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on local $\mathcal{G}$-shtukas over reduced excellent $p$-adic formal schemes admitting good covers.
Theorem 6.13. Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a reduced excellent $p$-adic formal $O_{F}$-scheme admitting a good cover. Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $\mathfrak{X}_{/ O_{F}}^{\circ}$. The $v$-closure of the generic fiber in $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}}$ $\mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ is representable by a unique reduced excellent distinguished $p$-adic formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ admitting a maximal good cover that is proper over $\mathfrak{X}$ with $\mathfrak{Y}_{\eta}$ finite étale over $\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}$.

We say that $\mathfrak{Y}$ is the flat moduli space of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on $\mathcal{P}$.
Proof. Let $Y=\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}^{\prime}\right)^{\diamond}\right] \times_{\left[* /\left(L_{W}^{+} \mathcal{G}\right)^{\diamond}\right], \mathcal{P}} \mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$ and $Z=\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}, \mathcal{P}_{\eta}} \mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}$. By Lemma 6.10, $Y$ is separated over $\mathfrak{X}^{\diamond}$ and $Z$ is finite étale over $\mathfrak{X}_{\eta}^{\circ}$. By Proposition 6.12, we may apply Proposition 5.44 to $Z \hookrightarrow Y$ to see the representability of the $v$-closure of $Z$ in $Y$. By Proposition 6.11, the $v$-closure of $Z$ in $Y$ lies in $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}} \mathfrak{X}^{\circ}$, so the claim follows.
6.3. Integral models of local Shimura varieties. In this section, we prove the local representability of integral models of local Shimura varieties and the representability of the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagrams under hyperspecial levels.

From now on, we suppose that $\mathcal{G}$ is reductive over $O_{F}$. Fix an algebraic closure $\bar{k}$ of $k$ and let $O_{\bar{F}}=W_{O_{F}}(\bar{k})$ and $\bar{F}=O_{\bar{F}}\left(\frac{1}{p}\right)$. Let $b \in G(\bar{F})$ and let $\mu: \mathbb{G}_{m} \rightarrow G_{\bar{F}}$ be a minuscule cocharacter. The triple $(\mathcal{G}, b, \mu)$ is called a local Shimura datum at hyperspecial level. In [SW20, Lecture 24, 25], the local Shimura variety $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}$ and its integral model $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ is defined for each triple $(\mathcal{G}, b, \mu)$. They are constructed as small $v$-sheaves with moduli interpretation. It is known that $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}$ is uniquely represented by a smooth rigid analytic variety over $\bar{F}$. It is still not known whether $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ is representable by a suitable formal scheme over $O_{\bar{F}}$, outside the cases of abelian type (see [PR22]).

What is known in general is the local representability of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ (see [Bar22], [SW20]). Let $r$ be the dimension of the local Shimura variety $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}$ and set $R=O_{\bar{F}} \llbracket T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \rrbracket$. Let $\mathfrak{m}$ be the maximal ideal of $R$. We regard $R$ as a complete $p$-adic ring and $R^{\wedge}$ denotes the $\mathfrak{m}$-adic ring whose underlying ring is $R$.
Theorem 6.14. ([Ito23a]) For every $x \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$, the formal completion $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is represented by $R^{\wedge}$. The universal local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka on $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is induced by the universal $\left(\mathcal{G}, \mu^{-1}\right)$-display on the absolute prismatic site $(R)_{\mathbb{A}}$.

In particular, the universal local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka on $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is defined over the $p$-adic ring $R$.
Now, we will consider integral models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ at the parahoric level $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$. By Proposition 5.5 and Lemma 5.7, $R$ admits a very good cover. Thus, we may apply Theorem 6.13 to the local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka $\mathcal{P}$ over the $p$-adic ring $R$. Let $\mathfrak{Y}$ be the flat moduli space of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on $\mathcal{P}$ and let $\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge}$ be the $\mathfrak{m}$-adic completion of $\mathfrak{Y}$. Let $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ be the $v$-sheaf local model introduced in [SW20] and let $M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ be the $O_{\bar{F}}$-scheme representing $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ that is constructed in [AGLR22].
Theorem 6.15. The fiber product $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times{ }_{\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is represented by $\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge}$. In particular, for every $y \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$, the formal completion $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$ is representable by a unibranch $p$-torsion free complete local Noetherian ring.
Proof. Let $Z=\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ and let $Z^{\text {bdd }} \subset Z$ be the closed subsheaf parametrizing $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$-bounded $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures. Since $\mathfrak{Y}$ represents the $v$-closure of $Z_{\eta}$ in $Z$, there is an inclusion $\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge} \hookrightarrow Z^{\text {bdd }}$.

First, we show that $Z_{s}^{\text {bdd }}$ is represented by a perfect scheme. By Lemma 6.10 and Proposition 6.12, $Z_{s}$ is represented by a perfect scheme $Z_{s}^{\text {red }}$. The $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure over $Z_{s}$ is represented by an $F$-crystal with $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-structure $P_{s}^{\prime}$ on $Z_{s}^{\text {red }}$. By [Zhu17, Lemma 1.22], the locus $Z_{s}^{\text {bdd,red }} \subset Z_{s}^{\text {red }}$ where the Frobenius of $P_{s}^{\prime}$ is bounded by $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ is closed. For each geometric point $x: \operatorname{Spa}\left(C, C^{+}\right) \rightarrow Z_{s}$, the $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure is bounded by $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ at $x$ if and only if the corresponding morphism $\operatorname{Spec}(C) \rightarrow Z_{s}$ factors through $Z_{s}^{\text {bdd,red }}$. Thus, $Z_{s}^{\text {bdd }}$ is represented by $Z_{s}^{\text {bdd,red }}$. Since $\mathfrak{Y}$ is proper over $\operatorname{Spf}(R), \mathfrak{Y}_{s}^{\text {perf }} \hookrightarrow Z_{s}^{\text {bdd }}$ is a closed immersion.

By definition of integral models of local Shimura varieties, $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times_{\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is isomorphic to $Z^{\text {bdd }} \times_{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{\wedge}\right)$. For every closed point $y \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k}),\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$

is topologically flat by [PR24, Proposition 3.4.1 (1)], so $\left(\mathcal{M}_{Q^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$ is contained in $\left(\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ as we have $Z_{q}^{\text {bdd }}=\mathfrak{Y}_{q}^{\circ}$. Thus, we may apply Lemma 6.16 to the m-adic completion of $\mathfrak{Y}_{s}^{\text {perf }} \hookrightarrow Z_{s}^{\text {bdd }}$ and we see that $\mathfrak{Y}_{s}^{\text {perf }} \hookrightarrow Z_{s}^{\text {bdd }}$ is an isomorphism after the m -adic completion. Thus, $\left(\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M}_{Q^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times_{\mathcal{M}_{Q, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{Q, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x}^{\wedge}$ is an isomorphism on each fiber over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)$, so it is an isomorphism by [Sch17, Lemma 12.11].

Next, we prove the second claim. Let $y \in \mathcal{M}_{Q^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$ and take $x \in \mathcal{M}_{Q, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$ to be the image of $y$. Let $\operatorname{Spf}(S) \subset \mathfrak{Y}$ be an affine open neighborhood of $y$ and let $S^{+} \subset S_{[p]}^{[1]}$ be the integral closure of $S$. Since $R$ is normal and $\left(S, S^{+}\right)$is étale over $\left(R_{[p]}^{[1]}, R\right), S^{+}$is normal by Corollary 2.10. Since $S$ is $p$-torsion free, reduced and excellent, $S \subset S^{+}$is a finite extension. Let $\mathfrak{n} \subset S$ be the maximal ideal corresponding to $y$ and let $S^{\wedge}$ (resp. $S^{+, \wedge}$ ) be the $\mathfrak{n}$-adic completion of $S$ (resp. $S^{+}$). By [Mat80, Theorem 79], $S^{+, \wedge}$ is normal. Since $S_{[p]}^{[1]}=S^{+[1]}$ and $S \subset S^{+}$is a finite extension, $S^{\wedge}$ is $p$-torsion free and $S^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]=S^{+, \wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$.
