By construction, $\left(\mathcal{M}_{Q^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$ is represented by $S^{\wedge}$, so it is enough to show that $S^{\wedge}$ is unibranch.

By [EGA4-4, Proposition 18.6.12], it is enough to show that $S^{\wedge}$ has a unique minimal prime. Since $S^{\wedge}$ is $p$-torsion free, the set of minimal primes of $S^{\wedge}$ is bijective to that of $S^{\wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \cong S^{+, \wedge}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$. Let $S^{+, \wedge}=\prod_{i \in I} S_{i}^{+}$be the decomposition into normal domains. Since $S^{+, \wedge}$ is finite over $S^{\wedge}, S_{i}^{+}$is a $p$-torsion free complete local Noetherian ring. Now, we have $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta} \cong \prod_{i \in I} \operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{i}^{+}\right)_{\eta}$. Since $\operatorname{Spa}\left(S_{i}^{+}\right)_{\eta}$ is nonempty for every $i \in I$, it follows from [PR24, Proposition 3.4.1(2)] that $I$ is a singleton. Thus, $S^{+, \wedge}$ is a normal domain and the claim follows.

The following lemma is needed in the above proof. We say that a perfect formal scheme over $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$ is formally of finite type if it is Zariski locally isomorphic to $\operatorname{Spf}(A)$ with $A=\left(A_{0}^{\text {perf }}\right)^{\wedge}$ for some formally finite type $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$-algebra $A_{0}$. Note that such $A_{0}$ is an adic $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$-algebra obtained as the completion of a finite type $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$-algebra.

Lemma 6.16. Let $\mathfrak{Y}$ be a perfect formal scheme perfectly formally of finite type over $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$ and let $\mathfrak{Z} \subset \mathfrak{Y}$ be a closed perfect formal subscheme. If $\left(\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge} \subset \mathfrak{Z}^{\circ}$ as subsheaves of $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}$ for every $y \in \mathfrak{Y}\left(\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}\right)$, we have $\mathfrak{Y}=\mathfrak{Z}$.

Proof. We may assume that $\mathfrak{Y}$ is affine. Let $\mathfrak{Y}=\operatorname{Spf}(A)$ and $\mathfrak{Z}=\operatorname{Spf}(A / I)$. Suppose that $I \neq 0$ and let $a \in I$ be a nonzero element. Since $a$ vanishes at every closed point of $\mathfrak{Y}$, we see that $a$ is topologically nilpotent. Let $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n} \in A$ be a generator of an ideal of definition of $A$. By Proposition 4.27, $\operatorname{Spa}(A / a A) \subset \operatorname{Spa}(A)$ is a proper closed subspace and its complement is the union of $R\left(\frac{f_{1}^{k} \ldots f_{n}^{k}}{a}\right)$ for $k \geq 0$. Thus, there is some $k \geq 0$ such that $R\left(\frac{f_{1}^{k} \ldots f_{n}^{k}}{a}\right) \neq \phi$. The closure of $R\left(\frac{f_{1}^{k} \ldots f_{n}^{k}}{a}\right)$ in $\operatorname{Spa}(A)^{\text {an }}$ is contained in $R\left(\frac{f_{1}^{k+1} \ldots f_{n}^{k+1}}{a}\right)$, so in particular, it is away from $\operatorname{Spd}(A / a A)$. However, since the specialization map is closed, the image of the closure under the specialization map of $\operatorname{Spa}(A)$ is a closed subset of $\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{\text {red }}\right)$.

In particular, it contains a closed point $y \in \operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{\text {red }}\right)$. Then, we see that $\left(\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$ contains a point in $R\left(\frac{f^{k+1} \ldots f^{k+1}}{a}\right)$, and we get a contradiction.

Remark 6.17. We find several obstacles in running a similar argument to establish the repsentability of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ from that of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$. Suppose that $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ is representable and let $\operatorname{Spf}(R) \subset \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ be an affine open subspace. Let $R_{0}$ be the underlying $p$-adic ring of $R$. First, we need to extend the universal local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over $\operatorname{Spd}(R)$ to $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R_{0}\right)$ and then we need to show that $R_{0}$ admits a good cover. We think that the first property can be checked if the local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka comes from a $p$-divisible group, and the second property follows from Lemma 5.7 if the $p$-adic uniformization is available (cf. [Mie20, Corollary 4.9]).

Though we show the local representability of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$, it is hard to study the singularities of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ in this way. One way to study the singularities is to construct a local model diagram. For this reason, we reconstruct the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagram following [PR24, Section 4.9.3] with some modification, and show that the diagram can be represented by formal schemes. Note that the representability alone is insufficient for the study of singularities.

First, we will construct a refinement of the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagram in [PR24, Section 4.9.3]. Let $\mathfrak{U} \subset \mathfrak{Y}$ be an affine formal open subscheme. For every map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R, R^{+}\right) \rightarrow$ $\mathfrak{U}^{\circ}$ over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(O_{\tilde{F}}\right)$, it uniquely formalizes to a map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{+}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{U}^{\circ}$ and the $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{+}\right)$corresponds to a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-BKF module $P_{R^{+}}^{\prime}$ by Proposition 6.4. The functor taking such a pair $\left(R, R^{+}\right)$to the set of the trivializations of $\varphi^{*} P_{R^{+}}^{\prime} \otimes_{W_{\left.O_{F}\right)}\left(R^{+5}\right)} R^{+}$is a $v$-sheaf over $\mathfrak{U}^{\circ}$ by [Sch17, Theorem 8.7]. Let $\widetilde{\mathfrak{U}}^{\circ}$ denote that $v$-sheaf. By construction, we can glue $\widetilde{\mathfrak{U}}^{\circ}$ for all $\mathfrak{U} \subset \mathfrak{Y}$, and we obtain a $v$-sheaf $\widetilde{\mathfrak{Y}}^{\circ}$ over $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}$.

Let $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ be the $v$-sheaf local model introduced in [SW20]. Let $M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ be the $O_{\tilde{F}}$-scheme representing $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ that is constructed in [AGLR22]. By the same construction as in [PR24, Section 4.9.1], there is a natural map $\widetilde{\mathfrak{Y}}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$. Here, we briefly recall the construction.

Let $\left(R, R^{+}\right)$be as above and let $t: \mathcal{G}_{R^{+}} \cong \varphi^{*} P_{R^{+}} \otimes_{W_{\left.O_{F}\right)}\left(R^{+5}\right)} R^{+}$be a trivialization. By the smoothness of $\mathcal{G}, t$ can be lifted to a trivialization $\widetilde{t}: \mathcal{G}_{W_{\left.O_{F}\right)}\left(R^{+5}\right)} \cong \varphi^{*} P_{R^{+}}$. The composition of $\widetilde{t}$ with the Frobenius $\varphi^{*} P_{R^{+}}\left[1 / \xi_{R^{+}}\right] \cong P_{R^{+}}\left[1 / \xi_{R^{+}}\right]$gives rise to a map $\operatorname{Spd}\left(R^{+}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{G}_{\mathcal{G}}^{\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{GR}}^{+}}$. It factors through $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ by the boundedness condition on $\mathcal{P}$. Thus, we get a morphism $\widetilde{\mathfrak{Y}}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$.

From now on, we will prove the representability of the diagram
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

in the category of $p$-adic formal schemes. First, we prove the case where $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}=\mathcal{G}$.
Lemma 6.18. There is a $\mathcal{G}$-torsor $Q$ over $R$ with a $\mathcal{G}$-equivariant morphism $Q \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ that represents the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagram for $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}=\mathcal{G}$.
Proof. This can be proved by following the descent theory of prismatic $(\mathcal{G}, \mu)$-displays developed in [Ito23b, Section 6]. We use the notation in [Ito23b] without explanation. See e.g. [Ito23b, Definition 4.3.4, Definition 5.2.1]. We refer to [Ito23b] for details.

Let $(A, I)$ be a Breuil-Kisin $O_{E}$-prism of $R$ and let $\left(A^{(2)}, I^{(2)}\right)$ be the coproduct $(A, I) \times$ $(A, I)$ in $(R)_{\mathbb{A}}$. Let $p_{i}:(A, I) \rightarrow\left(A^{(2)}, I^{(2)}\right)(i=1,2)$ be the natural inclusion and let $m:\left(A^{(2)}, I^{(2)}\right) \rightarrow(A, I)$ be the multiplication map such that $m \circ p_{1}=m \circ p_{2}=\operatorname{id}_{(A, I)}$.

The structure map of $(B, J) \in(R)_{\mathbb{A}}$ is denoted by $g_{(B, J)}: R \rightarrow B / J$. Let $\mathfrak{Q}^{\text {univ }}$ be the universal $\left(\mathcal{G}, \mu^{-1}\right)$-display over $(R)_{\mathbb{A}}$. The $\mathcal{G}$-torsor $\mathfrak{Q}_{(B, J)}^{\text {univ }} \times{ }^{\mathcal{G}_{\mu}, B, J} \mathcal{G}_{B}$ over $B$ is denoted by $\mathcal{Q}_{(B, J)}$ and its pullback to $B / J$ is denoted by $Q_{B / J}$.

For a morphism $f:(B, J) \rightarrow\left(B^{\prime}, J^{\prime}\right)$ in $(R)_{\mathbb{A}}$, let $\bar{f}: B / J \rightarrow B^{\prime} / J^{\prime}$ be the quotient map and let $\psi_{f}: Q_{B^{\prime} / J^{\prime}} \rightarrow \bar{f}^{*} Q_{B / J}$ be the map induced by the functoriality of $\mathfrak{Q}^{\text {univ }}$.

By [Ito23b, Proposition 6.4.1], there is a unique isomorphism $\iota: p_{1}^{*} \mathfrak{Q}_{(A, I)}^{\text {univ }} \cong p_{2}^{*} \mathfrak{Q}_{(A, I)}^{\text {univ }}$ such that $m^{*} \iota=\operatorname{id}_{\mathfrak{Q}_{(A, I)}^{\text {univ }}}$. If we write $\mathfrak{Q}_{(A, I)}^{\text {univ }}=\mathfrak{Q}_{Y}$ with $Y \in \mathcal{G}(A)_{I}$, the proof of [Ito23b, Proposition 6.4.1] shows that $\iota$ is given by an element $g \in \mathcal{G}(I K)$ (corresponding to the claim $\beta \in G(d K)$ in the cited proof). It implies that the map $\left(\overline{p_{1}}\right)^{*} Q_{A / I} \cong\left(\overline{p_{2}}\right)^{*} Q_{A / I}$ induced by $\iota$ is equal to $g_{(A^{(2)}, J^{(2)})}^{*} \operatorname{id}_{Q_{A / I}}$. This means that $\psi_{p_{1}}=\psi_{p_{2}}$.

Now, let $(B, J)$ be a perfect $O_{E}$-prism over $R$. The $\mathcal{G}$-torsor $\mathcal{Q}_{(B, J)}$ is canonically isomorphic to $\varphi^{*} P_{B / J}$ where $P_{B / J}$ is the corresponding $\mathcal{G}$-BKF module over $B / J$ (see the construction in [Ito23b, Definition 5.5.2]). By André's flatness lemma (see [BS22, Theorem 7.14]), there exists a faithfully flat cover $(B, J) \rightarrow\left(B^{\prime}, J^{\prime}\right)$ that admits a morphism $f:(A, I) \rightarrow\left(B^{\prime}, J^{\prime}\right)$.

We show that $\psi_{f}$ is independent of the choice of $f$. Let $f^{\prime}:(A, I) \rightarrow\left(B^{\prime}, J^{\prime}\right)$ be another map and let $f \times f^{\prime}:\left(A^{(2)}, I^{(2)}\right) \rightarrow\left(B^{\prime}, J^{\prime}\right)$ be the product map. Then, we have

$$
\psi_{f}=\psi_{f \times f^{\prime}} \circ\left(\overline{f \times f^{\prime}}\right)^{*} \psi_{p_{1}}=\psi_{f \times f^{\prime}} \circ\left(\overline{f \times f^{\prime}}\right)^{*} \psi_{p_{2}}=\psi_{f^{\prime}}
$$

Thus, we see that $\psi_{f}$ is independent of $f$. This implies that $\psi_{f}$ descends to an isomorphism $\psi_{(B, J)}: Q_{B / J} \cong g_{(B, J)}^{*} Q_{A / I}$. This isomorphism is compatible with any transition map, so $Q_{A / I}$ represents $\widehat{\operatorname{Spd}(R)}$ in the above diagram. It is easy to see from construction that $\widehat{\operatorname{Spd}(R)} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ is represented by the Hodge filtration $Q_{A / I} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ of $\mathfrak{Q}_{(A, I)}^{\text {univ }}$ (see [Ito23b, Section 5.4]).
Proposition 6.19. For every affine open formal subscheme $\operatorname{Spf}(S) \subset \mathfrak{Y}$, there is a finite type affine $S$-scheme $Q_{S}^{\prime}$ with a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-action and a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-equivariant morphism $Q_{S}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ that represents the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagram over $\operatorname{Spd}(A)$. Moreover, the $v$-sheaf theoretic local model diagram is representable in the category of p-adic formal schemes.

Note that the proof does not show that $Q_{S}^{\prime}$ is a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-torsor, nor that $Q_{S}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ is formally smooth after completion (Grothendieck-Messing theory).

Proof. We follow the notation in Proposition 5.39. Let $\left(R_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ be a good cover of $R$ (see Proposition 5.5). Let $\mathfrak{U} \subset \mathfrak{Y}$ be an affine open formal subscheme. Since $\mathfrak{U}_{\infty}$ is an affine perfectoid formal scheme, $\mathfrak{U}$ admits a maximal good cover $\left(S_{\bullet}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ constructed as in Corollary 5.28 .

First, we will construct $Q_{S}^{\prime}$. The $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure over $\operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right)$ corresponds to a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-BKF module $P_{S_{\infty}}^{\circ}$ by Proposition 6.4. Let $Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}=\varphi^{*} P_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime} \otimes_{W_{O_{F}}\left(S_{\infty}^{\prime}\right)} S_{\infty}$. By construction, we have $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \times \mathfrak{P}^{\circ} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{\infty}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}\right)$. Now, we have a natual $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-equivariant map $Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime} \rightarrow Q \otimes_{R} S_{\infty}$. By Lemma 6.7, this map corresponds to an $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsor of $Q \otimes_{R}\left(S_{\infty} / \pi S_{\infty}\right)$. By Lemma 5.21, $S_{\infty} / \pi S_{\infty} \cong \operatorname{colim}_{n \geq 0} S_{n} / \pi S_{n}$. Thus, the $\mathcal{H}$-subtorsor of $Q$ can be defined over $S_{n} / \pi S_{n}$ for some sufficiently large $n \geq 0$. Again by Lemma 6.7, it corresponds to a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-subtorsor $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}$ of $Q \otimes_{R} S_{n}$ and we have $Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime} \cong Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \otimes_{S_{n}} S_{\infty}$. Let $Q_{S_{n}}^{\wedge}$ be the $p$-adic completion of $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}$. By Lemma 3.9, $\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ is a geometric quotient of $\left(Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ by $\Gamma_{\infty}^{n}$, so we see that $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \times \mathfrak{P}^{\circ} \operatorname{Spd}\left(S_{n}\right) \cong\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$.

Now, we have a natural map $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow Q \otimes_{R} S_{n}$ and it is an isomorphism outside $V(p)$. In particular, we have $\Gamma(Q, \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{n} \hookrightarrow \Gamma\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right) \hookrightarrow \Gamma\left(Q_{[p]}^{[\underline{1}]}\right], \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{n}$. Since $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}$ is flat over $S_{n}$ and $S_{\infty} / S_{n}$ is $p$-torsion free, we have $\Gamma\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right)=\Gamma\left(Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right) \cap \Gamma\left(Q_{[p]}^{[\underline{1}]}\right], \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{n}$ inside $\Gamma\left(Q_{[p]}^{[\underline{1}]}\right], \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{\infty}$. Since $\Gamma_{\infty}$ acts on $P_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}, \Gamma_{\infty}$ also acts on $Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}$ and the action is compatible with the natural action on $Q \otimes_{R} S_{\infty}$. Thus, $\Gamma\left(Q_{S_{\infty}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right)$ is $\Gamma_{\infty}$-stable in $\Gamma\left(Q_{[p]}^{[\underline{1}]}\right], \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{\infty}$, so $\Gamma\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right)$ is $\Gamma_{n}$-stable in $\Gamma\left(Q_{[p]}^{[\underline{1}]}\right], \mathcal{O}) \otimes_{R} S_{n}$. Let $A_{S}=\Gamma\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}, \mathcal{O}\right)^{\Gamma_{n}}$. By Proposition 3.11, $\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(A_{S}\right)$ is a geometric quotient by $\Gamma_{n}$, so we see that $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \times \mathfrak{P}^{\circ} \operatorname{Spd}(S) \cong \operatorname{Spd}\left(A_{S}\right)$. Since $S_{n}$ is finite over $S$ and $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}$ is of finite type over $S_{n}, A_{S}$ is of finite type over $S$.

Let $A_{S}^{\wedge}$ be the $p$-adic completion of $A_{S}$. We will show that $\operatorname{Spf}\left(A_{S}^{\wedge}\right)$ can be glued to a $p$-adic fomal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$ over $\mathfrak{Y}$. Let $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S^{\prime}\right) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spf}(S)$ be a distinguished affine formal open subscheme. Let $S_{n}^{\prime}=S_{n} \otimes_{S} S^{\prime}$. Since $S_{n}$ is finite over $S, S_{n}^{\prime}$ is $p$-adically complete, and $\left(S_{\bullet}^{\prime}, \Gamma_{\bullet}\right)$ is a maximal good cover of $S^{\prime}$ by Lemma 5.31. By construction, we have $Q_{S_{n}^{\prime}}^{\prime} \cong Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \otimes_{S_{n}} S_{n}^{\prime}$. Since $S \rightarrow S^{\prime}$ is flat, we see that $A_{S^{\prime}} \cong A_{S} \otimes_{S} S^{\prime}$. In particular, $\operatorname{Spf}\left(A_{S^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spf}\left(A_{S}^{\wedge}\right)$ is a disguised open immersion. Thus, we can glue $\operatorname{Spf}\left(A_{S}^{\wedge}\right)$ for all $\operatorname{Spf}(S) \hookrightarrow \mathfrak{Y}$ to get a $p$-adic formal scheme $\mathfrak{Y}$. By construction, $\mathfrak{Y}$ represents the $v$-sheaef $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}$.

Next, we show that $\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ is representable by a morphism $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$. Since $R$ is a complete local ring with an algebraically closed residue field, $Q$ is a trivial $\mathcal{G}$-torsor. Since $\mathcal{G}_{\overline{\mathrm{E}}} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}_{\overline{\mathrm{E}}} / \mathcal{H}_{\overline{\mathrm{E}}}$ is Zariski locally split, for every sufficiently small affine open subset $\operatorname{Spf}(B) \subset$ $\operatorname{Spf}\left(S_{n}\right)$, we can lift the element of $(Q / \mathcal{H})(B / \pi B)$ corresponding to $Q_{B}^{\prime}=Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \otimes_{S_{n}} B$ to an element of $Q(B / \pi B)$. Since $Q$ is smooth, it can be lifted to an element of $Q(B)$, so $Q_{B}^{\prime}$ is a trivial $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-torsor. Let $t: \operatorname{Spec}(B) \rightarrow Q_{B}^{\prime}$ be a trivialization. The composition $\operatorname{Spd}(B) \rightarrow$ $\left(Q_{B}^{t \wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$ can be represented by a morphism $\operatorname{Spf}(B) \rightarrow\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}\right)^{\wedge}$ by Lemma 5.33 since

its generic fiber can be represented by $\operatorname{Spa}(B)_{\eta} \rightarrow Q_{B, \eta}^{\prime \wedge} \rightarrow Q_{B, \eta}^{\wedge} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu, \eta}^{\mathrm{loc}} \cong M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu, \eta}^{\mathrm{loc}}$. Thus, we get a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-equivariant morphism $Q_{B}^{\prime \wedge} \rightarrow\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}$ that represents $\left(Q_{B}^{\prime \wedge}\right)^{\diamond} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$. It is easy to see that this map is independent of the choice of $t$. Thus, we can glue these morphisms to get a morphism $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge} \rightarrow\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}$. By construction, it represents $\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge}\right)^{\diamond} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$.

Now, we have the following diagram.
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Since $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow Q_{S_{n}}$ and $M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ are isomorphisms outside $V(p)$, we may apply [Stacks, Tag 0ARB] to $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime}$ and $Q_{S_{n}} \times_{M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}} M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ to see that $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge} \rightarrow Q_{S_{n}}^{\wedge} \times_{\left(M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}}\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}$ is uniquely algebraizable. Thus, we can uniquely fill the middle vertical arrow $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$.

Since $Q_{S_{n}} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ is invariant under $\Gamma_{n}$ by construction, $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$ is also invariant under $\Gamma_{n}$. Since $Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{S}\right)$ is a coarse moduli space by [Con05, Theorem 3.1], the map factors through $\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{S}\right) \rightarrow M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$. Since $\left(Q_{S_{n}}^{\prime \wedge}\right)^{\diamond} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spd}\left(A_{S}\right)$ is surjective, the map represents $\operatorname{Spd}\left(A_{S}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}$. By the previous argument, we see that $\operatorname{Spf}\left(A_{S}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}$ can be glued to a morphism $\mathfrak{\mathfrak { Y }} \rightarrow\left(M_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\mathrm{loc}}\right)^{\wedge}$.
6.4. Canonical integral models of Shimura varieties. In this section, we construct canonical integral models of Shimura varieties under hyperspecial levels assuming the existence of those at hyperspecial levels. In this section, $(-)^{\wedge}$ denotes the $p$-adic completion.

Let $(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ be a Shimura datum satisfying the axiom (SV5). Let $\mathrm{K}=\mathrm{K}_{p} \mathrm{~K}^{p} \subset \mathbf{G}\left(\mathbb{A}_{f}\right)$ be a compact open subgroup such that $\mathrm{K}^{p} \subset \mathbf{G}\left(\mathbb{A}_{f}^{p}\right)$ is a sufficiently small (or neat) compact open subgroup and $\mathrm{K}_{p} \subset \mathbf{G}\left(\mathbb{Q}_{p}\right)$ is a parahoric subgroup. Let $\mathbf{E}$ be the reflex field of $(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$. Let $v$ be a place of $\mathbf{E}$ over $p$ and set $E=\mathbf{E}_{v}$. The Shimura variety $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ is expected to admit an integral model $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ over $O_{E}$. In the abelian type, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is constructed in [Kis10], [KP18] and [KPZ24] under mild assumptions.

The theory of canonical integral models is developed to characterize a family $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$. In [PR24], canonical integral models are characterized in terms of local shtukas. Let us briefly recall the theory of canonical integral models after [PR24].

Let $G=\mathbf{G}_{Q_{p}}$ and let $\mathcal{G}$ be a parahoric group scheme of $G$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ with $\mathcal{G}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)=\mathrm{K}_{p}$. Let $\{\mu\}$ be a geometric conjugacy class of minuscule cocharacters of $G$ corresponding to $\mathbf{X}$. Then, $E$ is the reflex field of $\{\mu\}$. Let $k$ be the residue field of $E$ and fix an algebraic closure $\bar{k}$ of $k$. Let $O_{\bar{E}}=W_{O_{E}}(\bar{k})$ and $\bar{E}=\left.O_{\bar{E}}\right|_{\bar{p}} ^{\frac{1}{2}}$. For each $b \in B\left(G, \mu^{-1}\right)$, we have a local Shimura datum $(\mathcal{G}, b, \mu)$ and an integral model $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}$ over $O_{\bar{E}}$ of the local Shimura variety $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b, \mu}$ over $\bar{E}$. The axioms of canonical integral models $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$, which is a family of normal flat separated $O_{E}$-scheme of finite type, are as follows (see [PR24, Theorem 1.3.2]):

(0) $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ admits finite étale prime-to- $p$ Hecke correspondences.
(1) For every discrete valuation ring $R$ of mixed characteristic over $O_{E}$,

$$
\left(\underline{\lim }_{\mathrm{K}^{p}} \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})\right)\left(R\lfloor\frac{1}{p}\rceil\right)=\left(\underline{\lim }_{\mathrm{K}^{p}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right)(R)
$$

(2) The local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}, E}$ over $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ extends to a local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$ over $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$.
(3) For every $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(\bar{k})$, there exists an isomorphism

$$
\Theta_{x}:\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{\lrcorner x_{0}}^{\wedge} \cong\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K} \mid x}^{\wedge}\right)^{\diamond}
$$

for a suitable $b_{x} \in G\left(\overline{\mathbb{Q}}_{p}\right)$ and a base point $x_{0} \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$ that is compatible with local $\mathcal{G}$-shtukas on each side.
Note that in the condition (2), $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$ (resp. $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}, E}$ ) is defined over the $v$-sheafification of the $p$-adic completion $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}^{\wedge}$ (resp. the adic space $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\underline{E}}^{\mathrm{ad}}$ ).

Now, by [DHKZ24b], [IKY23] and [DY24], most of the integral models $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ constructed in [Kis10], [KP18] and [KPZ24] are verified to be canonical in the sense of [PR24]. Here, we explain a relation between integral models at two different parahoric levels in terms of level structures on local shtukas, which can be expected from the diagram in [DHKZ24a, Theorem VII].

Let $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$ be another parahoric group scheme of $G$ over $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ with a morphism $\mathcal{G}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}$. It corresponds to a parahoric subgroup $\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime} \subset \mathrm{K}_{p}$. Let $\mathrm{K}^{\prime}=\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime} \mathrm{K}^{p}$ for each $\mathrm{K}^{p}$.

Theorem 6.20. Suppose that $\mathrm{K}_{p}$ is hyperspecial and there exists a system of canonical integral models $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ of $\left\{\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ in the sense of Pappas-Rapoport. For every $\mathrm{K}^{p}$, there is a normal flat separated algebraic space $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ of finite type over $O_{E}$ with $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, \mathrm{E}} \cong$ $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ such that
(1) $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is proper and surjective over $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$, and
(2) $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}$ is the flat moduli space of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$.

Moreover, $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ satisfies the above axioms (0)-(3) of canonical integral models.
Proof. Let $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(\bar{k})$ be a closed point. By the axiom (3), we have $\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K} \mid x}^{\wedge}\right)^{\diamond} \cong\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{\lrcorner x_{0}}^{\wedge}$. By [Bar22] and [Ito23a], $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{\lrcorner x_{0}}^{\wedge}$ is represented by $O_{\bar{E}}\left\llbracket T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right\rrbracket$ for some $r \geq 0$. Note that $E$ is unramified over $\mathbb{Q}_{p}$ since $G$ splits over $\overline{\mathbb{Q}}_{p}$. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is normal, flat and of finite type, it follows from [SW20, Proposition 18.4.1] that $\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right)_{\lrcorner x}^{\wedge} \cong \operatorname{Spf}\left(O_{\bar{E}} \llbracket T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \rrbracket\right)$. Thus, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is smooth over $O_{E}$.

By Proposition 5.9, we may apply Theorem 6.13 to the local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$. Let $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ be the flat moduli space of $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$. Let $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(\bar{k})$ be a closed point and take $b_{x}$ and $x_{0}$ as in the axiom (3). Here, we follow the notation in Section 6.3. Let $R=O_{\bar{E}} \llbracket T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r} \rrbracket$ and take the local $\mathcal{G}$-shtuka over the $p$-adic ring $R$ to be the one induced from $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$ by the pullback $\operatorname{Spec}(R) \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$. By Theorem $6.15, \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times{ }_{\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{\lrcorner x_{0}}^{\wedge}$ is

represented by $\mathfrak{Y}^{\wedge}$. By construction, we have a map $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}^{\circ}$. Since there is a natural morphism $\mathfrak{Y}_{\eta} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, \eta}$ of adic spaces by [Sch17, Lemma 15.6], that map is uniquely represented by a morphism $\mathfrak{Y} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ by Lemma 5.33. Thus, we have a morphism $\mathfrak{Y} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}^{\wedge}} \operatorname{Spf}(R)$. Since $\operatorname{Spec}(R) \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}$ is flat, $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}} \operatorname{Spf}(R)$ is flat over $O_{\bar{E}}$. Since $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ}$ and $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}^{\circ} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$ are both thick closed subsheaves of $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{K}}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$, it follows from the uniqueness of thick closures that $\mathfrak{Y}^{\circ} \cong \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}^{\circ} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}} \operatorname{Spd}(R)$. Thus, we have

$$
\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}^{\circ} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K} / x}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \cong \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times_{\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x_{0}}^{\wedge}
$$

In particular, for every $y \in \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k})$, there exists an isomorphism $\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime} / y}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \cong\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{y}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y_{0}}^{\wedge}$ with $b_{y}=b_{x}$ and $y_{0} \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}(\bar{k})$ where $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}(\bar{k})$ is the image of $y$.

Now, since $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, \eta}$ is finite etale over $\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta}, \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, \eta}$ is smooth, so in particular, normal. It follows from [AGLR22, Lemma 2.13] and Lemma 5.33 that $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ is absolutely weakly normal. Thus, it follows from [PR24, Proposition 3.4.1 (2)] and [AGLR22, Proposition 2.38] that $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ is normal.

Next, we show that $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, \eta} \rightarrow\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta}$ is the pullback of $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$. By construction in [PR24, Proposition 4.1.2], $\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{K}, E}$ corresponds to the pro-étale $\mathrm{K}_{p}$-cover $\underset{\leftarrow}{\lim }_{\mathcal{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}} \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}} \mathrm{K}^{p}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ of $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$. By the proof of Lemma 6.10, we see that $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}, \mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{K}, E}}$ $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\bar{E}}^{\text {ad }}$ classifies $\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime}$-subcovers of that pro-étale $\mathrm{K}_{p}$-cover, and $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}} \mathrm{K}^{p}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ is isomorphic to $\left(\underline{\lim }_{\mathcal{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}} \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}} \mathrm{K}^{p}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})\right) / \mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime \prime}$. Thus, we have $\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \eta} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}, \eta}, \mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{K}, E}} \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\bar{E}}^{\text {ad }} \cong$ $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\bar{E}}^{\text {ad }}$ and we get the claim.

Finally, we construct an algebraic model $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ of $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$. Let $U \subset \mathscr{S}_{k}$ be an arbitrary affine open subset and let $U=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$. Let $A\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \rightarrow B$ be the finite étale morphism representing $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ over $U_{\eta}$. Let $B^{+} \subset B$ be the integral closure of $A$. Let $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U} \subset \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ be the open formal subscheme over $U^{\wedge} \subset \mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}^{\wedge}$. Since $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}$ admits a maximal good cover by construction, it follows from Lemma 5.30 that $\Gamma\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U, \eta}, \mathcal{O}^{\circ \circ}\right) \hookrightarrow \Gamma\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}, \mathcal{O}\right) \hookrightarrow$ $\Gamma\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U, \eta}, \mathcal{O}^{+}\right) \cong\left(B^{+}\right)^{\wedge}$. Thus, there is a finite $A$-subalgebra $B_{0} \subset B^{+}$such that $B_{0}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]=B$ and there is a homomorphism $B_{0}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}, \mathcal{O}\right)$. By Proposition 2.18, $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}\left(B_{0}^{\wedge}\right)$ is a formal modification. By [Art70, Theorem 3.2], there is a unique proper morphism $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(B_{0}\right)$ of algebraic spaces that is an isomorphism outside $V(p)$ and induces $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spf}\left(B_{0}^{\wedge}\right)$ by taking the $p$-adic completion. It is easy to see from the uniqueness of $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}$ that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}$ is independent of the choice of $B_{0} \subset B$ and its construction is functorial in $U$. In particular, we can glue them to obtain an algebraic space $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ over $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}}$ such that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \cong \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \cong \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$.

We prove that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ is normal. Take an étale cover $V \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ from a scheme $V$ and consider the $p$-adic completion $V^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}, U}$. Since any $p$-adically completely étale homomorphism can be written as the $p$-adic completion of an étale homomorphism by [Elk73], it follows from [Mat80, Theorem 79] and the normality of $\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{K}^{\prime}}$ that $V^{\wedge}$ is normal. For any affine open subscheme $\operatorname{Spec}(C) \subset V, C \rightarrow C^{\wedge} \times C\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$ is faithfully flat, so $C$ is normal by [Mat80,

Corollary 21.3]. Thus, $V$ is normal, and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is normal. Moreover, since $\mathcal{S}_{K^{\prime}, U}$ is $p$-torsion free, $V^{\wedge}$ is $p$-torsion free. Thus, $C$ is $p$-torsion free and $V$ is flat over $O_{E}$.

Now, we have an integral model $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ of $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$. By construction, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is proper over $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is flat over $O_{E}$ and $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ is surjective, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is surjective. Thus, the condition (1) and (2) is verified for $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$. We will verify that $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ satisfies the axioms $(0)-(3)$.

First, we check the axiom (1). Let $R$ be a discrete valuation ring of mixed characteristic over $O_{E}$. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is proper over $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$, it follows from the valuative criterion that any element $y \in \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathrm{G}, \mathrm{X})\left(R_{[p]}^{(\underline{1})}\right)$ can be uniquely lifted to $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(R)$ as soon as we have a lift to $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(R)$ of the image of $y$ in $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathrm{G}, \mathrm{X})\left(R_{[p]}^{(\underline{1})}\right)$. Thus, the extension property of $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ follows from that of $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$. The axiom (2) follows from the construction because the universal $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure over $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is the unique extension of $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, E}$. The axiom (3) is already proved for $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$. Thus, it is enough to check that $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ admits finite étale prime-to- $p$ Hecke correspondences.

Let $\mathrm{K}_{i}^{p}(i=0,1)$ be sufficiently small (or neat) compact open subgroups with $g \mathrm{~K}_{0}^{p} g^{-1} \subset$ $\mathrm{K}_{p}^{1}$ for $g \in G\left(\mathbb{A}_{f}^{p}\right)$. Let $\mathrm{K}_{i}=\mathrm{K}_{p} \mathrm{~K}_{i}^{p}$ (resp. $\mathrm{K}_{i}^{\prime}=\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime} \mathrm{K}_{i}^{p}$ ) for $i=0,1$. By assumption, we have a finite étale prime-to- $p$ Hecke correspondence $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}$ associated with $g$. By [PR24, Theorem 2.7.7, Proposition 4.1.2], $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}$ is isomorphic to the pullback of $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}$ along the Hecke correspondence of $g$. Thus, we have a closed immersion $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ by construction. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}$ is finite étale, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}$ is normal and flat over $O_{E}$. In particular, $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ is thick, so $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ is an isomorphism. By [SW20, Proposition 18.4.1], $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}^{\wedge}$ is an isomorphism, so it follows from [Art70, Theorem 3.2] that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}}$ is an isomorphism. In particular, we obtain a finite étale Hecke correspondence $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{0}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}_{1}^{\prime}}$ associated with $g$.

As a result, we obtain the following corollary. We keep the notation in Theorem 6.20.
Corollary 6.21. The p-adic completion $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}$ represents the $v$-sheaf parametrizing $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structures on $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$ bounded by $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, \mu}^{\text {loc }}$. Moreover, $\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ y}^{\wedge}$ is representable by a normal $p$-torsion free complete local Noetherian ring if $b=b_{x}$ and $y$ is over $x_{0}$ for some $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(\bar{k})$. Proof. The claim follows from $\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \times_{\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K} / x}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \cong \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }} \times_{\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}}\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{G}, b_{x}, \mu}^{\text {int }}\right)_{/ x_{0}}^{\wedge}$.

Even if $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, E}$ is a scheme and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, \mathbb{F}_{p}}$ is locally projective over a scheme $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}, \mathbb{F}_{p}}$, it does not directly follow that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is a scheme (for example, see [Mat15, Section 5.2]). We will show that $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is a canonical integral model of $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ if there exists one by partially following the proof of uniqueness of canonical integral models (see [Pap23, Theorem 7.1.7]).
Proposition 6.22. Under the situation in Theorem 6.20, if there is a system of canonical integral models $\left\{S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}$ of $\left\{\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}\right\}$, we have an isomorphism $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \cong \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$.
Proof. By [PR24, Corollary 4.3.2], there is a natural map $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$. Since $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is a $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$ level structure on $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}$ over $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$, we have a map $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}^{\prime}} \times_{\operatorname{Sht}_{\mathcal{G}}, \mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$. Since

$S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is flat over $O_{E},\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, \eta}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ is dense in $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ (see [Lou20, Lemma 4.4]), so we have a map $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right)^{\circ}$. By [SW20, Proposition 18.4.1], it is representable by a morphism $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$.

Let $U \subset \mathscr{S}_{k}$ be an affine open subset and let $U=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$. Let $A\left[\frac{1}{p}\right] \rightarrow B$ be the finite étale morphism representing $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ over $U_{\eta}$. Let $B^{+} \subset B$ be the integral closure of $A$. Let $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U} \subset S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ be the inverse image of $U$. Since $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, E} \cong \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$, we have $p^{N} \cdot B^{+} \subset \Gamma\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U}, \mathcal{O}\right)$ for some $N \geq 0$. By setting $B_{0}=A+p^{N} \cdot B^{+}$for sufficiently large $N \geq 0$, we get a finite $A$-algebra $B_{0}$ admitting $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(B_{0}\right)$ and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}\left(B_{0}\right)$ that are isomorphisms outside $V(p)$. By [Stacks, Tag 0ARB], $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U}$ is uniquely algebraizable to $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U}$. By gluing these morphisms, we see that $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is uniquely algebraizable to $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$. We will show that this is an isomorphism.

Let $y \in S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, U}(\bar{k})$ be a closed point and let $x \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(\bar{k})$ be the image of $y$. By [PR24, (4.7.1), (4.8.2)], we have the following commutative diagram for a unique $y^{\prime} \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k})$.
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

Since $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ is induced by the $\mathcal{G}^{\prime}$-level structure $\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$, the isomorphism $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \cong$ $\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$ commutes with $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ} \rightarrow\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)^{\circ}$. In particular, $y^{\prime}$ is the image of $y$ and we have $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y}^{\wedge} \cong \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y^{\prime}}^{\wedge}$ by [SW20, Proposition 18.4.1]. It follows that $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k}) \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k})$ is injective since if $y_{0}, y_{1} \in S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k})$ maps to $y^{\prime} \in \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\bar{k})$, both of $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y_{i}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta}(i=0,1)$ isomorphically map to $\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime} / y^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta}$, so the injectivity of $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta} \rightarrow\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}^{\wedge}\right)_{\eta}$ implies $y_{0}=y_{1}$.

Let $V \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ be an étale cover by an $O_{E}$-scheme $V$ and let $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V}=S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \times_{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}} V$. Since $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V}(\bar{k}) \rightarrow V(\bar{k})$ is injective and $\left(S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V}\right)_{E} \rightarrow V_{E}$ is an isomorphism, $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V} \rightarrow V$ is quasi-finite by [EGA4-4, Corollaire 13.1.4]. Since $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ are separated over $O_{E}$, we may apply Zariski's main theorem to $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V} \rightarrow V$. Since it is birational and $V$ is normal, $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V} \rightarrow V$ is an open immersion.

Suppose that there is a closed point $y_{0} \in V(\bar{k})$ outside $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V}$. Since $V$ is flat over $O_{E}$, $y_{0}$ can be lifted to a point $y \in V(R)$ with $R$ a complete discrete valuation ring of mixed characteristic over $O_{E}$. Since $R$ is strictly henselian and prime-to- $p$ Hecke correspondences are finite étale, $y$ can be lifted to $y^{p} \in \lim _{\mathrm{K}^{p}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(R)$. By the extension property of $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$, $\left\{y_{R[1 / p]}^{p}\right\}$ can be lifted to an $R$-valued point of $\lim _{\mathrm{K}^{p}} S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$. In particular, $y_{R[1 / p]}$ can be lifted to $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(R)$. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is separeted, this contradicts the assumption on $y_{0}$. Thus, we see that $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}, V} \cong V$ and $S_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}$ is an isomorphism.

In particular, Proposition 6.22 implies that the functoriality of canonical integral models automatically satisfies [HR17, Axiom 3.1] under hyperspecial levels. In fact, this can be checked for every $\mathrm{K}_{p}^{\prime} \subset \mathrm{K}_{p}$ directly by following the proof of [Pap23, Proposition 7.1.9].

Proposition 6.23. Let $\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ (resp. $\left.\left\{\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}\right)$ be a system of canonical integral models of $\left\{\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}$ (resp. $\left.\left\{\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}\right\}_{\mathrm{K}^{p}}\right)$. The morphism $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ constructed in [PR24, Corollary 4.3.2] is proper and surjective.

Proof. Let $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \xrightarrow{j} Y \xrightarrow{\pi} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ be a Nagata compactification of $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ (see [Con07, Theorem 4.1]). By replacing $Y$ with the Zariski closure of $j\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right)$, we may assume that $j$ has a dense image. Since $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ is finite étale, we have $Y_{E} \cong \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{E}$ and $Y-j\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right)$ lies in the special fiber of $Y$. Suppose that we have a closed point $y_{0} \in Y(\bar{k})$ outside $j\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right)$. Since $Y$ is flat over $O_{E}, y_{0}$ can be lifted to a point $y \in Y(R)$ with $R$ a complete discrete valuation ring of mixed characteristic over $O_{E}$. Let $x \in \mathscr{S}_{K}(R)$ be the image of $y$. Since $R$ is strictly henselian, $x$ can be lifted to some $x^{p} \in \lim _{\mathrm{K}^{p}} \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}(R)$. Then, $x_{R[1 / p]}^{p} \times y_{R[1 / p]}$ defines an element of $\lim _{\mathrm{K}^{p}} \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})(R[1 / p])$, so we see that $y_{R[1 / p]}$ extends to $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(R)$. Since $Y$ is separated, $y$ lies in $j\left(\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}\right)$, but this is a contradiction. Thus, $j$ is an isomorphism and $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is proper. Since $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is flat over $O_{E}$ and $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ is surjective, $\mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathscr{S}_{\mathrm{K}}$ is a proper surjection.

Note that Proposition 6.23 does not rely on the axiom (SV5). However, the proof of Theorem 6.20 relies on (SV5) in that $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})$ is a finite étale covering locally isomorphic to the finite set $\mathcal{K}_{p} / \mathcal{K}_{p}^{\prime}$. Without (SV5), there is a contribution of the center of $\mathbf{G}$ and $\operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}^{\prime}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\mathrm{E}}^{\mathrm{ad}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sh}_{\mathrm{K}}(\mathbf{G}, \mathbf{X})_{\mathrm{E}}^{\mathrm{ad}}$ cannot be directly interpreted as a moduli space of level structures.

abstract:
We establish a representability criterion of $v$-sheaf theoretic
modifications of formal schemes and apply this criterion to moduli spaces of
parahoric level structures on local shtukas. In the proof, we introduce nice
classes of equivariant profinite perfectoid covers and study geometric
quotients of perfectoid formal schemes by profinite groups. As a corollary, we
obtain a construction of (part of) integral models of local and global Shimura
varieties under hyperspecial levels from those at hyperspecial levels.
